201 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Wesselman v. Board of Elections


No. 36265


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 30; 162 N.E.2d 118; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 474; 9 Ohio Op. 2d 364



October 21, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This action was instituted in the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County by the filing of a petition against the board of elections of that county and the Secretary of State, alleging that relator "is a citizen, taxpayer and qualified elector" of Hamilton County, that the respondents propose to print and arrange the names of candidates on voting machines in accordance with the amendment to Section 3507.07, Revised Code, which will become effective on October 15, 1959, and praying for a writ of mandamus directing respondents to arrange the names of candidates for the general election on November 3, 1959, on voting machines in Hamilton County as required by the provisions of Section 2a of Article V of the Ohio Constitution.

The foregoing statutory amendment reads:

"On each voting machine the names of the candidates of each political party at any general election shall be arranged in a separate horizontal row or vertical column under or opposite the title of the office so that on each voting machine the names of all candidates of each political party will appear in the same horizontal row or vertical column. The [***2] order of such rows or columns shall be rotated by precincts in regular serial sequence, so that the names of the candidates of each political party shall appear, in so far as may be reasonably possible, substantially an equal number of times in each of the rows or columns appearing on the voting machines of the voting district under the titles of the offices for which they are candidates. Where there is more than one candidate for the same office of the same political party the names shall be rotated as equally as possible in the bracket [sic] under the title of the office sought." (Emphasis added.)

Section 2a of Article V of the Constitution of Ohio reads:

"The names of all candidates for an office at any general election shall be arranged in a group under the title of that office, and shall be so alternated that each name shall appear (in so far as may be reasonably possible) substantially an equal number of times at the beginning, at the end, and in each intermediate place, if any, of the group in which such name belongs. Except at a party primary or in a nonpartisan [***3] election, the name or designation of each candidate's party, if any, shall be printed under or after each candidate's name in lighter and smaller type face than that in which the candidate's name is printed. An elector may vote for candidates (other than candidates for electors of President and Vice-President of the United States) only and in no other way than by indicating his vote for each candidate separately from the indication of his vote for any other candidate." (Emphasis added.)

The judgment of the Court of Appeals held that the foregoing amendment to Section 3507.07, Revised Code, is unconstitutional and therefore allowed the writ of mandamus prayed for.

The cause is now before this court on appeal from that judgment of the Court of Appeals, pursuant to the provisions of Section 2, Article IV of the Constitution, giving this court "appellate jurisdiction * * * in cases which originated in the Courts of Appeals." *


* The final order of the Court of Appeals further finds that its judgment is in conflict with the judgment rendered upon the same question by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County in State, ex rel. Graf, v. Brown, Secy. of State, and certifies its record to the Supreme Court for review and final determination (see Section 6 of Article IV of the Ohio Constitution).

 [***4]



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator citizen filed an action in the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) against respondents, a county board of elections and the secretary of state, seeking a writ of mandamus directing respondents to arrange the names of candidates for a general election in accordance with the provisions of Ohio Const. art. V, § 2a, rather than Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3507.07. The court of appeals allowed the writ. Respondents appealed.


OVERVIEW: The court first addressed the arguments that the citizen did not have standing to attack the constitutionality of the statute and that the citizen had an adequate remedy by way of injunction or declaratory judgment. The court held that the citizen had the capacity to maintain a proper action to enforce the performance of a public duty relating to elections and affecting himself and citizens generally, even where such act involved an attack on the constitutionality of a statute. The court further held that the court of appeals did not abuse its discretion in allowing the writ merely because the citizen also had an adequate remedy in the ordinary course of law. With regard to the substantive issue, the court of appeals determined that § 3507.07, which set forth a method for arranging the names of candidates for general elections on voting machines, was in conflict with Ohio Const. art. V, § 2a, and was, therefore, unconstitutional. The court upheld that determination and affirmed the judgment. The court noted that the constitutional provision was self-executing and applied instead of the provisions of the statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that allowed the writ.

 

202 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Graf v. Brown


No. 36263


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 37; 162 N.E.2d 123; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 475; 9 Ohio Op. 2d 367



October 21, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [**1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This action was instituted in the Court of Appeals for Franklin County by the filing of a petition against the Secretary of State and the board of elections of that county. The petition contains substantially the same allegations and prayer for relief described in the report of State, ex rel. Wesselman, v. Board of Elections of Hamilton County, ante, 30. The Court of Appeals determined that the amendment to Section 3507.07, Revised Code, which became effective on October 15, 1959, is constitutional, sustained a demurrer to the amended petition and rendered judgment for respondents.

The cause is before this court on appeal from that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.

 

203 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co. v. Euclid


No. 35907


Supreme Court of Ohio


169 Ohio St. 476; 159 N.E.2d 756; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 632; 8 Ohio Op. 2d 480



July 15, 1959, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Motion for rehearing allowed, August 12, 1959. For later report in this litigation, see 170 Ohio State Reports.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This action in mandamus originated in the Court of Appeals, wherein the relator, The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, seeks to compel the respondent city of Euclid to issue a permit for the construction of an overhead electric transmission line to carry electrical energy at a voltage of 132,000 volts over certain streets in the respondent city.

The city refuses to issue such permit primarily for the reason that the application is for a permit to construct overhead transmission lines carrying electrical energy in excess of 33,000 volts, which would be contrary to ordinance No. 78-1957 of such city requiring such lines to be placed underground. That ordinance reads as follows:

"Whereas, this council finds that it is necessary to provide for the safety, welfare, comfort and convenience of inhabitants of the city of Euclid, and

"Whereas, this council further finds that increasingly higher voltages of electric power are being carried to and through urban centers and cities such as the city of Euclid,  [***2] and that provision must be made whereby such power lines are so constructed and maintained as to provide the greatest safety factors for persons using the public streets and ways, as well as those persons occupying private property and to provide quiet and peaceable possession of the same, and

"Whereas, making provision for such high tension lines also provides for the usual daily operation of municipal departments.

"Now, therefore, be it ordained by the Council of the City of Euclid, state of Ohio:

"Section 1: That ordinance No. 288-1956, passed December 3, 1956, be and the same is hereby amended and supplemented by adding the following new section, to be known as Section 2.1, which shall read as follows:

"Section 2.1: Permit issued by council.

"It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain an electric power line carrying greater voltage than 33 KV, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the council. No charge shall be made for such permit. The applicant shall first file plans and specifications, which shall show the course and route of such proposed line in or through the city of Euclid. Such line shall be installed underground, at a minimum depth of six feet [***3] below grade. It shall be backfilled by and laid in at least six inches of sand. It shall be standard underground pipe-type cable, lead covered, to be no less than the standard minimum A. E. I. C. specification as to voltage, herein adopted. Such line shall be encased in an enclosed sealed and welded steel pipe with protective sheath, having a somatic coating. Such pipe may either be oil or gas filled and shall be capable of withstanding any maintained pressure."

The Court of Appeals referred the case to a special master who found such ordinance unconstitutional on the basis that it is not a lawful exercise of the police power and recommended that a writ of mandamus issue. The Court of Appeals adopted the special master's report as its conclusions of law and fact and issued the writ.

The cause is before this court on an appeal as of right from the judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent city appealed from the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which had issued a writ of mandamus requiring the city to issue a permit for construction of overhead electric lines to relator electric company. The city contended that the court of appeals erred in its determination that its ordinance requiring the line be constructed underground was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The city passed an ordinance requiring that high-voltage electric lines be installed underground. Statutes required the electric company to obtain the consent of the city before constructing electric transmission lines through the city. The electric company sought to construct a high-voltage line above ground in an industrial area of the city. The city denied the request and the electric company brought an action in mandamus in the court of appeals. The court held that the requirement of consent necessarily implied that the city could regulate the construction of electric transmission lines. It took judicial notice that high-voltage lines were dangerous and held that the city's ordinance was a reasonable exercise of the police power. Even if it were assumed that the original ordinance granting the electric company a franchise to install power lines created a contract, the contract was subject to the reasonable exercise of the police power. The electric company had no right to erect a high-voltage transmission line above ground.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

204 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Chadwell v. Cain


Nos. 35653, 35763, 35785, 35786


Supreme Court of Ohio


169 Ohio St. 425; 160 N.E.2d 239; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 625; 8 Ohio Op. 2d 449



July 8, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Cause No. 35653 was originated in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County as an action to enjoin the defendant, Cain, City Clerk of the city of Columbus, from forwarding to the city council the transcript of the proceedings of the Board of County Commissioners of Franklin County approving the annexation to the city of approximately 84 acres in Mifflin Township. The proceeding before the Board of County Commissioners was initiated by the filing of a petition signed by 16 resident adult freeholders living in territory proposed to be annexed. Although the petition before the board stated that 19 adult freeholders resided in the territory, there were admittedly 21 such freeholders.

Upon receipt of the petition on April 20, 1956, the board on April 24, 1956, adopted a formal order (1) directing that the petition be filed with the county auditor, (2) fixing the date of public hearing as June 26, 1956, and (3) directing notification of the agent of the petitioners as to the time and place of hearing. Later, the date of hearing was postponed to August 14, 1956.

After April [***2] 24 and before August 14, signers withdrew their signatures (some of whom withdrew their withdrawals) in such numbers as to leave the petition signed by ten freeholders as of the date of hearing, which was one less than a majority of the adult resident freeholders residing in the territory.

At the time of public hearing before the Board of County Commissioners, the withdrawals were disregarded and the annexation was approved.

The Court of Common Pleas denied the injunction which was sought and the Court of Appeals affirmed the decision of the lower court.

Causes Nos. 35763, 35785 and 35786 were originated in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County by the various plaintiffs as actions to enjoin the defendants, Director of Finance, City Clerk and the city of Cincinnati, from reporting to the council of that city the transcript of the proceedings of the Board of County Commissioners, map and petition, in connection with annexation to the city of a portion of Green Township in said county.

The petition for annexation bearing signatures of 340 adult resident freeholders of the area described therein was filed with the Board of County Commissioners of Hamilton County on July 1, 1955,  [***3] and on July 5 was referred by that board to the county engineer for checking signatures and description. That officer, under date of July 25, 1955, made a return to the Board of County Commissioners finding that the petition contained valid signatures which represented 55.3 per cent of the resident freeholders of the area for which annexation was sought, and that the descriptions were correct. On July 26, 1955, the Board of County Commissioners set the petition for annexation for public hearing on October 11, 1955. At the hearing, certain withdrawals of signatures and additions thereto presented in the interim between July 26 and October 11 were considered together with the evidence, and the matter was again referred to the county engineer who reported on October 24, 1955, that he found 52.2 per cent of the resident freeholders in the territory proposed for annexation signed on the petition in favor of the annexation. At the October 11 hearing, proponents and opponents of the annexation presented additional signatures supplementing the original petition and seeking withdrawal therefrom, respectively. As of October 24, a further request for the withdrawal of 28 more signatures [***4] was submitted, which further request the Board of County Commissioners refused to consider.

On November 19, 1956, a little more than a year later, the petition for annexation was approved and a transcript of the proceedings was forwarded to the Director of Finance of the city of Cincinnati by the Board of County Commissioners of Hamilton County. Before action could be taken by the city council these three causes were instituted in the Court of Common Pleas. They were consolidated for trial in that court, and at their conclusion the petitions for injunction were dismissed.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgments of the Court of Common Pleas.

The Franklin County cause and the three Hamilton County causes are before this court on allowance of motions to certify the records, and two of the Hamilton County cases (Nos. 35785 and 35786) are here also on appeals as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated actions, appellants, some of the residents in their respective unincorporated areas, challenged the judgments of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County and the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed the lower court's denial of injunctive relief to stop the annexations of the unincorporated areas by appellee city and county officials pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 707.01 to 707.30 and § 709.02 et seq.


OVERVIEW: In five separate actions brought in two counties, the issue was whether the respective city and county officials could continue with the annexation of previously unincorporated areas once the residents of those areas withdrew or attempted to withdraw their approval. In one county, residents withdrew their signatures on the authorizing petition to where there was no longer a majority approval. In the other county, the residents challenged the technical sufficiency of the petition. Both the trial court and the intermediate appellate court denied the residents their request for an injunction and they sought review. The court held that the ability to annex unincorporated areas into a municipality was an inherent and discretionary power of any city that did not violate any constitutional voting or property rights of the residents of the unincorporated areas. Once "official action" was begun, the petitioners no longer had the right to withdraw their approval; it was at the discretion of the city to go forward, or not, or to permit "withdrawal" of the residents' approval as it saw fit, but in any event the residents could not stop the process once the city had obtained jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the intermediate appellate courts and the trial courts.

 

205 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Adoption of Uniform Rules & Regulations, etc.


No. 35943


Supreme Court of Ohio


169 Ohio St. 445; 160 N.E.2d 275; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 627; 8 Ohio Op. 2d 465



July 8, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

By entry dated December 6, 1957, the Board of Tax Appeals, appellee herein and hereinafter called the board, adopted ten rules under the caption, "Ohio Real Property Valuation Rules." Under the provisions of the board's entry, nine of these rules (Nos. 100 through 108) became effective on January 1, 1959. The tenth, rule No. 109, became effective January 1, 1958. Because so much of the present litigation evolved from rule No. 100, it is set forth in full as follows:

"Pursuant to the provisions of Amended Senate Bill No. 109, adopted by the 102nd Ohio General Assembly, and particularly Revised Code Sections 5713.03 and 5715.01, which must be read together to the end that uniformity be obtained, the Board of Tax Appeals does hereby define the term 'taxable value.'

"The term 'taxable value' means such percentage of 'true value' as the Board of Tax Appeals shall determine, from time to time by journal entry, as to all taxable real property.

"The 'true value' of real property, as here used, means the value to be determined, in the first instance, by the county auditor as the assessor of real property in his county on consideration [***2] of all the facts relating to the physical nature and construction of the property, its availability for the purpose for which it was acquired or constructed, or for the purpose for which it is, or may be, used, and every other applicable factor which may tend to indicate the value of the property such as actual cost, value as indicated by reproduction cost, physical and functional depreciation and obsolescence, if any, market value, and the income capacity of the property, if any. The assessor shall likewise take into consideration the location of the property and the valuations of similar properties in the same locality.

"The county auditor shall not be concerned with 'taxable value' until such time as the Board of Tax Appeals shall determine the percentage of 'true value' usable for a given period."

As is stated in the first paragraph of rule No. 100, it was promulgated pursuant to the provisions of Amended Senate Bill No. 109 adopted by the 102nd General Assembly, amending Sections 5713.03 and 5715.01, Revised Code. The first of these sections requires that the county auditor shall make a determination of the "taxable value" of the various parcels of real property within [***3] his jurisdiction in accordance with the provisions of other named sections of the Revised Code and "in accordance with the uniform rules and methods for valuing and assessing of real property as adopted, prescribed, and promulgated by the Board of Tax Appeals."

The second section of the Revised Code referred to in rule No. 100 (Section 5715.01) reads as follows:

"The Board of Tax Appeals shall direct and supervise the assessment for taxation of all real property. The board shall adopt, prescribe, and promulgate rules for the assessment of real property by uniform rule according to value. Such uniform rules shall prescribe methods of determining the taxable value of such real property. Such rules shall provide that such taxable value be determined on the basis of all facts and circumstances which the board finds necessary in order to achieve uniformity and avoid overvaluation and discrimination. The value of each tract, lot, or parcel of real property and improvements thereon, determined in accordance with such uniform rules and the methods prescribed thereby shall be the taxable value thereof for all purposes of Sections 5713.01 to 5713.26, inclusive, of the Revised Code, of [***4] Sections 5715.01 to 5715.99, inclusive, of the Revised Code, and of Sections 5717.01 to 5717.06, inclusive, of the Revised Code. County auditors shall, under the direction and supervision of the board, be the chief assessing officers of their respective counties, and shall list and value the real property within their respective counties for taxation in accordance with such rules and methods. There shall also be a board in each county, known as the County Board of Revision, which shall hear complaints and revise assessments of real property for taxation.

"On or before the first Monday in August, in the year 1959, and each sixth year thereafter, it shall be the duty of the Board of Tax Appeals to transmit to each county auditor a statement which specifies the amount or per cent to be added to or deducted from the valuation of the real property or any class thereof, in the county, township, municipal corporation or other taxing district in his county for the current tax year so that every class of real property shall be listed and valued for taxation by an equal and uniform rule, in each county in the state."

John J. Carney as the auditor and as a citizen and taxpayer of Cuyahoga [***5] County, appellant herein and hereinafter called the auditor, appealed from the entry of the board to the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County, which held that rules Nos. 100, 101, 104-D-24, 105 and 106 adopted by the board in such entry are unreasonable and unlawful and, therefore, invalid.

The board thereupon perfected an appeal to the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, which reversed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court.

The cause is before this court by virtue of the allowance of a motion to certify the record filed by the auditor.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county auditor challenged a decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed a trial court's judgment holding that an entry by appellee Board of Tax Appeals adopting valuation rules under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5715.01 was invalid.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to legislative authority, the Board adopted a series of valuation rules for assessing taxes on real property. The auditor charged that the rules were unlawful and unreasonable in setting different valuation dates for land and the improvements thereon. He also alleged that the statute under which the rules were promulgated amounted to an unconstitutional delegation of the legislative power, and that the Board's rules violated the constitutional cap on property taxes. In affirming the intermediate court's decision upholding the rules, the court held that different dates for valuing improvements and land were consistent with the legislative purpose and were reasonable and lawful. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5715.01 was not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority because it contained sufficient standards for the Board's guidance in enacting subordinate rules. The Board's rules basing tax assessments on taxable values did not violate the one-percent limitation on property taxes contained in Ohio Const. art. XII, §2 so long as the taxable value was uniformly applied and did not exceed the constitutional maximum.


OUTCOME: The court held that the Board's rules were reasonable and lawful, and affirmed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court.

 

206 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland, Columbus & Cincinnati Highway, Inc. v. Public Utilities Com.


Nos. 35610, 35611, 35612, 35613


Supreme Court of Ohio


169 Ohio St. 195; 158 N.E.2d 362; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 567; 8 Ohio Op. 2d 161



May 6, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Public Utilities Commission.

This action originated in the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio on February 21, 1956, when The Cleveland, Columbus & Cincinnati Highway, Inc., a motor transportation company, filed a petition requesting the establishment of a commercial zone for the city of Niles, Ohio, under the provisions of Section 4921.26, Revised Code.

After an extended hearing and also a rehearing, the commission unanimously granted the petition and created a commercial zone for the city of Niles after finding that the area is commercially a part of that city within the purview of the statute.

From the order of the commission appeals have been perfected to this court.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant carrier filed a petition with appellee, the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, requesting the establishment of a commercial zone for a certain city under the provisions of Ohio Rev. Code § 4921.26. After a hearing, the Commission granted the petition after finding that the area was commercially a part of that city within the purview of § 4921.26. Appellant other carriers sought review.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the carriers claimed that the Commission's order was arbitrary and unreasonable. The court rejected this claim and upheld the Commission's order. Contrary to the carriers' claim, the court found that under § 4921.26, the Commission had authority to create a commercial zone, even in the absence of a showing and finding of public convenience and necessity. In addition, the court rejected the carriers' challenge to the reciprocity provision of the Commission's order that was made in conformity with Ohio Pub. Utilities Comm'n R. 28. The court found that reciprocity of a commercial zone made the carriers' service uniform throughout the zone, which was in the best interest of shippers and receivers of commodities. Further, such reciprocity was more equitable and fair to the carriers themselves. In addition, the court refused to address the carriers' claim that the Commission's order violated several constitutional protections because the carriers did not provide any argument or authority to support these claims.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's order.

 

207 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Tri-City Broadcasting Co. v. Bowers


No. 35571


Supreme Court of Ohio


169 Ohio St. 126; 158 N.E.2d 203; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 556; 8 Ohio Op. 2d 118



April 22, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Belmont County.

This cause originated after the issuance of a use-tax assessment against the appellee Tri-City Broadcasting Company, an Ohio corporation, which owns and operates a television station with studios in Wheeling, West Virginia, and a transmitter at Bridgeport, Ohio. The transmitter broadcasts over a tristate area, including Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania, under a license granted by the Federal Communications Commission, and began transmitting operations on July 30, 1953.

The appellee purchased certain transmitting equipment outside Ohio to be used in the transmitter at Bridgeport. These items, purchased between August 7, 1953, and October 27, 1954, as set forth in the stipulation, were shipped by motor freight directly from Camden, New Jersey, to Bridgeport ready for installation and were installed within one to three days after arrival at the transmitter.

The appellee paid the use tax and thereafter made application for refund of the tax so paid, claiming the assessment to be unconstitutional for the reason that the items and equipment assessed are used in interstate commerce for radio and television broadcasting.

The Tax [***2] Commissioner, appellant here, refused to refund this tax and entered his order accordingly. An appeal was taken to the Board of Tax Appeals, which affirmed the order of the Tax Commissioner. Tri-City Broadcasting Company then appealed to the Court of Appeals for Belmont County, which reversed the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals, without opinion. In the journal entry it held "that the Ohio use tax levied by Section 5741.02, Revised Code, is an excise tax levied only against personal property purchased for and used principally and primarily in a taxable way; that broadcast transmitting is an interstate commerce activity; that broadcast transmitting equipment purchased by appellant Tri-City Broadcasting Company is used principally and primarily in interstate commerce; that therefore such equipment is exempted under the provisions of Section 5741.02 (C) (3), Revised Code; that to impose a use tax on the equipment would violate Article I, Section 8, clause 3 of the Constitution of the United States; that to impose a use tax on the equipment would discriminate against interstate commerce and burden such commerce in violation of Article I, Section 8, clause 3 of the Constitution of [***3] the United States; that therefore, appellant's broadcast transmitting equipment can not constitutionally be subjected to the use tax levied by Section 5741.02, Revised Code; and that a contrary holding would bring Section 5741.02, Revised Code, into conflict with Article I, Section 8, clause 3 of the Constitution of the United States."

The cause is here as a result of the allowance of the motion of the Tax Commissioner to certify the record and on an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Ohio Tax Commissioner challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Belmont County (Ohio), which reversed the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals, affirming the Commissioner's decision to refuse to refund the use tax appellee broadcasting company paid.


OVERVIEW: The company operated a television station. It had studios in West Virginia and a transmitter in Ohio. The company purchased transmitting equipment outside Ohio to be used in the transmitter in Ohio. It paid the use tax and applied for a refund, claiming that the assessment was unconstitutional because the equipment assessed were used in interstate commerce for radio and television broadcasting. The Commissioner refused to refund the tax, and the Board affirmed its decision. The lower court reversed the Board's determination. The court held that there was no interference by the State of Ohio with interstate commerce under the circumstances. The use tax imposed on the company's personal property was imposed in every instance where a person in Ohio used goods purchased at retail outside Ohio and brought into the State for use there. Real estate in Ohio was not tax exempt solely because it could be used in interstate commerce. Transmitting equipment purchased in interstate commerce and shipped from a point outside Ohio to a point within the State for immediate installation in a radio and television transmitter was subject to the use tax levied by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5741.02.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and rendered final judgment for the Commissioner.

 

208 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Groh v. Board of Education


No. 35812


Supreme Court of Ohio


169 Ohio St. 54; 157 N.E.2d 325; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 544; 8 Ohio Op. 2d 13



March 25, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Clermont County.

This action in mandamus originated in the Court of Appeals.

Relators are residents of the village of Amelia, Ohio, which village in 1955 was a part of the Amelia Local School District. In that year, the Board of Education of Clermont County initiated a reorganization in which was proposed the consolidation of the Amelia school district with Withamsville-Tobasco and Mt. Carmel-Glen Este Local School Districts. In November 1956, an election was held on the reorganization, resulting in a vote the count of which is not disputed in the pleadings except as to the Mt. Carmel district, wherein the respondents aver some 31 more affirmative votes and 10 more negative votes than relators allege.

The tabulation as shown by respondents is as follows:

 

YES

NO

Amelia district

734

1385

Withamsville district

1297

438

Mt. Carmel district

1088

551

The affirmative vote (under either allegation) being greater than the 55-per-cent majority required by law, the reorganization was accordingly made.

The West Clermont Local School District Board of Education was thereafter organized and became the board of education for [***2] the newly reorganized district, composed of the above three districts, and relators allege it has received revenue from the taxes imposed as an operating levy in the entire district which in the area previously known as the Amelia school district was greater in amount than the taxes levied on the property of the Amelia school district prior to the reorganization and consolidation.

The relators in their first cause of action claim that the reorganization election of 1956 and the action of respondents taken thereafter were pursuant to Section 3311.31, Revised Code, and further claim "that said legislative enactment is unconstitutional and invalid in that it imposes a tax on the citizens of the Amelia Local School District for the maintenance of the school district of territory outside of said village of Amelia over the vote and will and wish of the people of Amelia." Relators then ask "that said election results and said reorganization and merger under said statute be declared and held unconstitutional and void."

For their second cause of action, relators assert that on or about December 9, 1957, there was filed with respondent Board of Education of Clermont County a petition containing [***3] a total of 2,320 names of voters, 2,056 being voters of the Amelia school district, 149 of the Withamsville district and 115 of the Mt. Carmel district, which petition requested the county board of education to "take immediate action under the provisions of the Ohio Revised Code, R. C. 3311.26 and R. C. 3311.26 as amended and related sections, so as to create a new local school district or districts or as to dissolve a school district and return it to its original districts, Amelia, Withamsville-Tobasco and Mt. Carmel-Glen Este school district."

Relators allege that the county board "failed and refused to carry out the provisions of said sections of the Revised Code of Ohio and to take such action so as to duly certify said issue for a vote in accordance with and as required by law."

For their third cause of action, relators assert that the Board of Education of West Clermont Local School District "whose existence and validity is questioned" on or about March 19, 1958, initiated a proposed bond issue and tax levy authorizing the issuance of bonds by such board of education for the purpose of construction of new fireproof school buildings and improvements and additions to present [***4] plants.

An election was held May 6, 1958, and the bond issue was approved by a vote of 2,218 for and 1,471 against, the vote in the territory formerly comprising Amelia Local School District being 580 for the issue and 762 against.

Relators in their third contention allege that the Board of Education of the West Clermont Local School District was not legally constituted to take such action and in addition "that the action it took was contrary to the express provisions of R. C. 133.04, which requires that prior consent be obtained from the Department of Taxation before such question is certified for a vote and was in violation of other provisions of the Revised Code of Ohio."

Relators pray for a writ of mandamus against the Board of Education of the West Clermont Local School District and the Board of Education of Clermont County, "holding and commanding said respondents (1) that the action taken in 1956 following the election held in November, 1956, and causing the reorganization and consolidation of the various school districts and the inclusion of the Amelia Local School District in said West Clermont County, Ohio School District is invalid, and that the same should be severed [***5] and said Amelia Local School District parted from, separated from and re-established as a school district of itself; that said respondents take such action as provided by the provisions of the several sections of the Revised Code of Ohio in order to certify for a vote of the voters and citizens of the several districts, causing the separation, dissolution and disorganization of the West Clermont County school district so as to restore each of said districts and, particularly, to release and restore the Amelia Local School District; that respondents disregard any further action on the issuance of said bonds, said action leading to the election having been contrary to and in violation of the Revised Code of Ohio; and for such other and further relief as may be proper in the premises."

Answers were filed by the respondents which contain certain admissions of the facts pleaded and denials of a general nature as to the allegations that the reorganization election and subsequent administrative acts, the refusal to act on the petition to separate Amelia Local School District from the reorganized district, and the proceedings to issue the bonds were illegal and invalid.

As to the relators'  [***6] third cause of action, the answer of the West Clermont local board states:

"Answering respondents further state by way of affirmative allegation that the matter was submitted to a popular vote at the primary election on Tuesday, May 6, 1958, that the Department of Taxation of the state of Ohio had consented to the issue and submission, as provided in Section 133.04 of the Revised Code on the 29th day of April, 1958, which consent had been received in the office of the respondent West Clermont Local School District Board of Education on Thursday the 1st day of May, 1958, prior to the date of the election, as provided by law."

The Court of Appeals held that the petition is not well founded and dismissed it.

The cause is now in this court on an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator residents sought review of the judgment from the Court of Appeals for Clermont County (Ohio) that found in favor of respondent board of education and dismissed the residents' action claiming that the legislative enactment was unconstitutional and invalid in that it imposed a tax on the citizens of the school district for the maintenance of the school district territory outside of the village over the vote of the people.


OVERVIEW: The residents were residents of the village, which was part of the school district. The board had initiated a reorganization in which a consolidation of school districts was proposed and completed. The residents sought a declaration that the election results and the reorganization and merger be declared and held unconstitutional and void. The appellate court dismissed the petition and the residents appealed. In affirming, the court held that the requirement in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 133.04 that bonds shall not be submitted to popular vote in an amount which would have made the net indebtedness after the issuance of such bonds exceed four per cent of the total value of all property in such school district as listed and assessed for taxation, unless the Department of Taxation consented thereto, was fully met where such consent was secured before the election held thereon. The statute simply forbade submission of the question unless the Department of Taxation consented thereto. Accordingly, the petition was properly dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the appellate court.

 

209 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Superior Foundry, Inc. v. Industrial Com.


No. 35520


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 537; 156 N.E.2d 742; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 669; 7 Ohio Op. 2d 419



March 4, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action in mandamus brought originally in this court by the Superior Foundry, Inc., an Ohio corporation and a contributor to the State Insurance Fund, against the Industrial Commission of Ohio and involves a challenge of certain orders made by the commission against relator with respect to a former employee of relator who contracted silicosis. The cause is submitted upon the petition, answer and a stipulation of facts.

It appears that on April 28, 1955, pursuant to his application therefor, respondent awarded compensation to Peter Bobich, a former employee of relator, after determining that he was totally disabled by the disease of silicosis contracted while in relator's employ. Respondent found that Bobich had become disabled on August 10, 1954, some two years and ten months after the termination of his services with relator, which occurred on October 12, 1951. Subsequently relator filed motions with respondent requesting reconsideration and disallowance of the award to Bobich or, if the award stood, an allocation of the charge against relator's account, because of such award, to the year 1951 instead of the year 1954. Such motions were overruled, whereupon [***2] the present action was instituted. In its petition relator charges respondent with a violation of Section 4123.68, Revised Code, upon the claim that such section, by its terms, excludes Bobich's disability as a compensable one. In the alternative, the petition alleges that, if the disability is compensable, the award, when made, should have been allocated to relator's account as a 1951 award and not as a 1954 award, and that, by selecting and fixing the latter date and so charging the award against relator, respondent made an unlawful and arbitrary distinction between occupational-disease awards and awards for injuries, contrary to statute and respondent's administrative general rating rule III, with the result that relator and other employers in a similar position are subjected to unconstitutional discrimination.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator employer, a foundry corporation, brought an action in mandamus against respondent, the Industrial Commission of Ohio, challenging certain orders made by the Commission against the employer with respect to a former employee's award of compensation for contracting silicosis.


OVERVIEW: The Commission awarded compensation to the former employee after determining that he was totally disabled by the disease of silicosis contracted while working for the employer. In its petition, the employer charged the Commission with a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.68, upon a claim that such section, by its terms, excluded the employee's disability as a compensable one. In the alternative, the petition alleged that the Commission made an unlawful and arbitrary distinction between occupational-disease awards and awards for injuries, contrary to statute and an administrative general rating rule. The court rejected the employer's contentions and denied the writ. The court held that § 4123.68(W), dealing specifically with silicosis, had to be given full force and effect and, therefore, the specific provision relating to silicosis took precedence over and controls the general provisions, which had reference to occupational diseases generally. The court noted that it would not undertake to control the lawful exercise of the discretion vested in the Commission with respect to determinations covering classifications, establishment of basic rates, and merit ratings.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ.

 

210 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Leach v. Redick


No. 35728


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 543; 157 N.E.2d 106; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 670; 7 Ohio Op. 2d 422



March 4, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action in mandamus originating in this court.

Relator is Russell Leach, City Attorney of Columbus, and respondent is Floyd C. Redick, Director of the Department of Public Service of Columbus.

In his petition relator alleges that the city of Columbus adopted a charter on May 5, 1914, which charter, with the amendments adopted thereafter, remains in full force and effect; that included in such charter are sections 1, 2, 3, 17, 18, 19, 20, 24, 25, 73, 97, 115, 116 and 117, copies of which are attached to the petition, marked exhibit A and made a part thereof; and that relator brings this action pursuant to Section 73 of the Charter of Columbus, which reads as follows:

"In case any officer, board or commission fail to perform any duty required by law, the City Attorney shall apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for a writ of mandamus to compel the performance of such duty."

Relator says that on April 14, 1958, the Council of the City of Columbus passed ordinance No. 546-58, a copy of which is attached to the petition, marked exhibit B and made a part thereof, which authorizes and directs the Director of the Department of Public Service to execute, on [***2] behalf of the city, a lease of land to the Linden Veterans' Center Association, a nonprofit organization under the laws of Ohio, which land is owned by the city and known as 2682 Cleveland Avenue, on the terms and conditions set forth in the lease agreement, the provisions of which are contained in full in the ordinance above referred to.

Relator says that on April 23, 1958, the Mayor of Columbus vetoed ordinance No. 546-58, but that such ordinance was passed over his veto on May 12, 1958. Relator says that the lease as set forth in ordinance No. 546-58 was properly authorized and executed by the proper officials of the Linden Veterans' Center Association and was delivered to respondent on June 12, 1958, for execution by him as directed by the ordinance; that respondent, in violation of the duties specifically enjoined upon him by law, failed and refused and still fails and refuses to sign such lease; and that relator has no plain and adequate remedy in the ordinary course of law.

Relator prays that a writ of mandamus issue from this court commanding respondent to execute the lease as set forth in ordinance No. 546-58 and for all further relief to which relator may be entitled.

 [***3] To relator's petition respondent filed a general demurrer and supports such demurrer by the contentions (1) that ordinance No. 546-58 is invalid for the reasons (a) that it fails to comply or show compliance with the Ohio statutes requiring competitive bidding for a sale or lease of real property owned by a municipal corporation and (b) that it represents an unlawful interference with the administrative function and, more particularly, with the discretion given the respondent by the statutes of the state of Ohio and the Columbus Charter in his capacity as Director of Public Service of the City of Columbus; and (2) that by reason of the fact that an ordinance is not a law within the meaning of Section 73 of the Columbus Charter, as shown by the journal of the commission, no duty required by law of the respondent is involved herein and, hence, an action in mandamus will not lie.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator city attorney filed a petition for a writ of mandamus seeking an order requiring respondent Director of the Department of Public Service of Columbus to execute a lease as set forth in ordinance No. 546-58. The Director filed a general demurrer and argued that ordinance No. 546-58 was invalid because it failed to comply with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 721.01, 721.03, and it represented an unlawful interference with the administrative function.


OVERVIEW: The city attorney alleged that the Council of the City of Columbus passed ordinance No. 546-58, which authorized the Director to execute, on behalf of the city, a lease of land to the a nonprofit organization under the laws of Ohio, which land was owned by the city. The city attorney sought a writ of mandamus commanding the Director to execute the lease as set forth in the ordinance. The Director filed a demurrer and argued that the ordinance failed to comply with §§ 721.01, 721.03, the statute that required competitive bidding for a sale or lease of real property owned by a municipal corporation. The court held that §§ 721.01, 721.03 were not followed in reference to the lease, but that it was not necessary that they be followed. The court held that the lot was owned by the city and presented only a local problem, and therefore §§ 721.01, 721.03 did not apply. The court held that the city's charter gave the city council full authority to enact the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court allowed the city attorney's writ of mandamus seeking an order that required the Director to execute a lease.

 

211 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Appropriation for Highway Purposes


No. 35606


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 517; 156 N.E.2d 731; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 664; 7 Ohio Op. 2d 387



February 25, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Harrison County.

On February 27, 1957, the Director of Highways of the State of Ohio, acting under the provisions of Section 5519.01, Revised Code, filed in the Court of Common Pleas a "resolution and finding" for the appropriate of certain parcels of land located in Harrison County, Ohio, needed for the construction of a public highway.

Named as the owners of the land were Charles Long, Blanche Long, and Edgar Long. The required statutory notice was mistakenly issued first to the sheriff of Tuscarawas County for service on the three parties. As soon as this error was discovered, it was corrected by the issuance of another notice to the sheriff of Harrison County, and personal service was obtained on Charles and Edgar Long on March 29, 1957. As to Blanche Long, the sheriff's return read, "Blanche Long of Dennison, Ohio, Route No. 1, is deceased," and subsequently the court dismissed her as a party to the proceeding.

On April 10, 1957 -- twelve days after Charles and Edgar Long were served with the notice -- they filed their petition appealing from the findings and the amount fixed by the Director of Highways as compensation for their [***2] land to be taken and the damage to the residue thereof.

Thereafter the court granted a motion to dismiss the appeal for the reason that it was not filed within ten days as then required by Section 5519.02, Revised Code (Recodification Act of 1953).

On an appeal to the Court of Appeals on questions of law, the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was affirmed.

The cause is in this court for a review by reason of the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowners filed a petition challenging the amount that appellee Director of Highways of the State of Ohio fixed as compensation for their land to be appropriated for construction of a public highway. The landowners appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Harrison County (Ohio), which affirmed the common pleas court's judgment dismissing their petition as untimely under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5519.02 (1953).


OVERVIEW: The landowners contended that the 10-day limitation for filing a petition challenging the amount of compensation fixed by the Director under § 5519.02 was directory rather than mandatory and that they should have received an extension to file their petition within 12 days. The court found no merit in the contention. The landowners did not request an extension. Thus, the common pleas court's action was not erroneous even if the limitation was merely directory. Further, the summonses issued to the landowners contained the required statutory warning that there was a 10-day limit on their right of appeal. Regardless, the landowners' failure to timely file their petition and request an extension of the deadline were not their only omissions. Nearly two months elapsed before they filed their bond, even though § 5519.02 required them to file it within five days after its amount was determined; and the landowners never filed a brief in opposition to the motion to dismiss their appeal, even though they were granted a continuance so that they could file a brief. Accordingly, the court concluded that the court of appeals did not err in affirming the judgment of the common pleas court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

212 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Saxbe v. Alexander


No. 35853


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 404; 155 N.E.2d 678; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 641; 7 Ohio Op. 2d 251



January 21, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This action in quo warranto, instituted in the Court of Appeals, presents the question of the constitutionality of the act (Sections 5538.01 to 5538.21, inclusive, and Section 5538.99, Revised Code) providing for the construction, maintenance, repair and operation of an underground parking lot under the Statehouse grounds; creating the Underground Parking Commission and defining its powers and duties; and providing for the financing of such construction. The prayer of the petition is for a judgment "ousting respondents from the exercise" of all powers, privileges, franchises and rights purportedly conferred upon them by the act.

Respondents demurred to the petition "for the reason, apparent on the face thereof, that it does not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action."

The Court of Appeals sustained the demurrer and, relator electing not to plead further, dismissed the petition.

An appeal as of right brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a quo warranto action, relator Attorney General sought review of a judgment by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which sustained the demurrer of respondent Ohio Underground Parking Commission to the Attorney General's petition challenging the Underground Parking Lot Act (Act).


OVERVIEW: The Attorney General sought to oust the Commission from the exercise of all it powers conferred on it by the Act. The petition alleged that the Act was invalid because it was a law of general nature that did not have uniform operation throughout the State of Ohio and was therefore in contravention of Ohio Const. art. II, § 26. In the alternative, the Attorney General claimed that Act was invalid because it was a special act conferring corporate powers contrary to Ohio Const. art. XIII, § 1. The Commission demurred on the ground that the law was uniform and that the corporate powers given to it were not such that would invalidate the Act. The Court of Appeals sustained the demurrer. The court found that the operation and effect of the Act was local. The court also found that the garage would have to be a parking garage open to the general public and competitive in every respect with existing commercial parking facilities in order to accumulate sufficient revenue to repay the bondholders for money advanced to construct it.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and allowed the writ of quo warranto.

 

213 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland v. Betts


No. 35615


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 386; 154 N.E.2d 917; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 464; 7 Ohio Op. 2d 151



December 31, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Defendant, Joseph Betts, appellee herein, by affidavit filed in the Cleveland Municipal Court was charged with the violation of Section 11.2314 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Cleveland, which, so far as it affects the instant case, provides:

"Whoever carries a pistol, revolver, bowie knife, dirk or other dangerous weapon concealed on or about his person, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than $ 200 nor more than $ 500, and imprisoned not less than three months nor more than six months * * *."

It appears from the evidence that in the early morning of July 9, 1957, Betts, a private citizen, was driving his automobile on the streets of the city of Cleveland and was stopped by the police who found a loaded pistol in the locked glove compartment of his car. He entered a plea of not guilty to the charge, was tried, found guilty and sentenced. (See Porello v. State, 121 Ohio St., 280, 168 N. E., 135; 94 Corpus Juris Secundum, 493, Weapons, Section 8.)

An appeal on questions of law was thereupon taken to the Court of Appeals, which found, according to its judgment [***2] entry, "that the ordinance under which this defendant was charged, namely, Section 11.2314 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Cleveland, is in direct conflict with the Revised Code of Ohio, Section 2923.01, defining the crime of carrying concealed weapons. Therefore, the ordinance being unconstitutional as a result of such conflict, the court finds that the Municipal Court of Cleveland is without jurisdiction to entertain the action. The judgment imposing sentence on the defendant is reversed and set aside and ordered held for naught and the case remanded with instructions to discharge the defendant on the affidavit filed in this case. Further, the case is remanded to the Cleveland Municipal Court with instructions to institute further proceedings under the proper statute as provided by law."

The cause is now in this court for disposition on its merits, pursuant to an appeal as of right and the allowance of a motion to require the Court of Appeals to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, by affidavit, was charged with a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.01. He entered a plea of not guilty, was found guilty, and sentenced. Defendant sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which found that § 11.2314 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Cleveland was unconstitutional, reversed and set aside the judgment imposing sentence, and remanded the action to discharge defendant.


OVERVIEW: Section 11.2314 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Cleveland provided that whoever carried a dangerous weapon concealed on or about his person was guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction would be fined not less than $ 200 nor more than $ 500 and imprisoned not less than three months nor more than six months. The issue to be decided was whether a municipality, under the police power given it by Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3, could validly enact and enforce an ordinance prohibiting the carrying of concealed weapons and making the violation thereof a misdemeanor, in face of a statute covering the same subject and providing that a convicted offender might be sentence to the penitentiary. Where the punishment could be imprisonment in the penitentiary, the offense was a felony. The court affirmed the judgment. The court reasoned that, although the ordinance in issue did not permit what the Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.01 prohibited, and vice versa, it contravened the expressed policy of the state with respect to crimes by deliberately changing an act which constituted a felony under state law into a misdemeanor, and this created and unconstitutional conflict.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals which found the ordinance unconstitutional and which reversed and set aside the judgment convicting defendant.

 

214 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Kaplan Trucking Co. v. Bowers


No. 35325


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 141; 151 N.E.2d 654; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 546; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 436



July 2, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The appellant is an Ohio corporation engaged in the motor transportation business as a common carrier operating over the highways of Ohio and neighboring states in both intrastate and interstate commerce.

The appellant filed a highway use tax return for the third and fourth quarters of the year 1955, based on its use of Ohio highways during that period of six months. However, it refused to pay the tax on the contention that the effect of the tax as administered was discriminatory and hence violative of the federal and state Constitutions.

On February 15, 1956, the Tax Commissioner levied an assessment against the appellant in the amount of $ 44,549.67, plus a penalty. A petition for a reassessment was denied.

On an appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals, the assessment was affirmed.

On a further appeal to the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County, the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals was affirmed.

The cause is in this court for a further review by reason of an appeal as of right and also the allowance of the appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action contesting a tax, appellant taxpayer challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed a decision of the Ohio Board of Tax Appeals, which affirmed an assessment by appellee Ohio Tax Commissioner.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was an Ohio corporation engaged in the motor transportation business as a common carrier operating over the highways of Ohio and neighboring states in both intrastate and interstate commerce. It filed a highway use tax return for the third and fourth quarters of 1955, based on its use of Ohio highways during that time. It refused to pay the tax on the ground that the effect of the tax as administered was discriminatory and thus unconstitutional. The Board affirmed the assessment, and the appellate court affirmed the Board's decision. The taxpayer argued that its equal protection guarantees were violated by the administrative classification of motor vehicle common carriers according to state residency, namely, requiring the Ohio highway use tax to be paid by carriers domiciled in Ohio but not by those domiciled in Michigan or Indiana. The Commissioner argued that residency was not the only test but that a second was the place of maintenance and registry of vehicles. The court held that the classification in effect during the subject limited period was not such as to warrant the court in holding it without reason under the particular circumstances.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

215 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Eaton v. Price


No. 35488


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 123; 151 N.E.2d 523; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 389; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 377



June 18, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

On March 20, 1957, one Earl Taylor was served by a police officer with an instrument, captioned "Affidavit and Warrant," issued out of the Dayton Municipal Court. The affidavit, sworn to and signed by one George Cooper on March 19, states that "on or about the 12 day of March A. D. 1957 * * * Earl Taylor being the owner of premises located at 130 Henry Street, did unlawfully refuse to permit a duly authorized agent of the Division of Housing Inspection of the City of Dayton, to enter and survey the said premises for the purposes of repairs or alteration as are necessary to comply with the provisions of minimum housing standards contrary to the form of the ordinances to wit: Section 806.30 of Dayton, Ohio * * *."

It appears from the record that Taylor had previously received a notice from the office of the Prosecutor in the criminal division of the Dayton Municipal Court, dated March 12, notifying him to appear at that office on March 19, 1957, to answer a complaint made against him for refusing entry for housing inspection, to which notice Taylor did not respond.

When served with the affidavit and warrant he was not physically [***2] placed under arrest but was ordered to appear in Municipal Court on March 26. On that day he appeared in court, entered a plea of not guilty and, bond having been fixed in the sum of $ 1,000, was placed in the city jail. Late in the afternoon of the same day a writ of habeas corpus was sought in the Common Pleas Court of Montgomery County against the Chief of Police of Dayton on the application of Arthur T. Eaton to produce the body of Taylor, at which time he was released on his own recognizance by order of the court, and the matter was set for hearing on April 8.

Following the hearing, the writ was allowed on May 26, 1957, and Taylor was discharged from custody, the court finding in its entry that "Section 806.30 of the Code of General Ordinances of the City of Dayton, Ohio, being ordinance No. 18099 * * * is unconstitutional as it applies to the facts in this case as violative of the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States and Article I, Section 14 of the Constitution of the state of Ohio."

An appeal on questions of law was taken by the City Attorney of Dayton, representing the Chief of Police, from the judgment of the Common Pleas Court to the Court of Appeals,  [***3] which court, with one judge dissenting, reversed the judgment of the trial court and remanded the cause.

It is now before this court on an appeal as of right and upon the allowance of a motion to certify. Further facts as required are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator attorney appealed from the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio) that reversed the judgment of the trial court granting his petition for a writ of habeas corpus against respondent police chief, seeking the release of his client, who was charged with refusing entry for a housing inspection, in violation of Dayton, Ohio, Code of General Ordinances § 806-30.


OVERVIEW: The client owned certain property and he was detained in jail when he refused to allow a housing inspector to come onto his property without a warrant. His attorney obtained a writ of habeas corpus and the trial court ordered his discharge upon ruling that § 806-30 was invalid under the Fourth Amendment and Ohio Const. art. I, § 14. The appellate court reversed and the attorney appealed. The supreme court noted first that the case should not have been brought in the relation of the state and the client, not the attorney, should have been designated as the party in interest. In affirming, the court ruled that the Fourth Amendment applied only to the federal government and not the states and the housing inspection ordinance did not violate the similar prohibition against unreasonable searches under Ohio Const. art. I, § 14. The city was authorized to adopt such ordinances under its police power under Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3, and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 715.26 and 715.29, and the right of the client, as homeowner, to the inviolability of his castle was subordinate to the general health and safety of the community.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals was affirmed.

 

216 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Second Federal Sav. & Loan Ass'n v. Bowers


No. 35434


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 65; 151 N.E.2d 223; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 380; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 311



June 4, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

This case involves the 1957 tax return of the appellant, The Second Federal Savings & Loan Association of Cleveland, an incorporated financial institution without shares of capital stock. In making its return for 1957, the appellant listed no taxable amount for book value of capital employed, for the reason that the federal securities held by it exceeded the value of the capital employed. The only matter in issue is the tax of $ 19,730 assessed against the "ownership interests of the depositors," upon the basis of the surplus or reserve and undivided profits without deduction of federal securities owned by the appellant.

The appellant filed an application for review and redetermination, contending that the statutory provisions under which ownership interests of depositors were assessed are unconstitutional. The Tax Commissioner found that he was without authority to pass on the question of the constitutionality of the statutes involved; that as an administrative official he must proceed in accord with the statutory provisions; and that the assessment was correct.

The confirmance of the assessment by the Tax Commissioner was made pursuant [***2] to certain statutory provisions relative to the taxation of shares of, and capital employed by, financial institutions, contained in an act (126 Ohio Laws, pt. 2, 12) amending, among others, Sections 5709.02, 5719.09, 5719.10, 5725.04 and 5725.07, Revised Code.

On appeal, the Board of Tax Appeals held that it was without authority to declare a statute unconstitutional, considered all applicable sections of the Revised Code to be constitutional, and affirmed the order of the Tax Commissioner.

An appeal from the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a financial institution incorporated in the state, sought review of a decision from the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed an order of appellee tax commissioner who assessed a tax against the ownership interests of depositors upon the basis of the surplus or reserve and undivided profits without deduction of federal securities owned by the financial institution.


OVERVIEW: The financial institution contended that the taxation of ownership interests of depositors was unconstitutional. The Board held that all the statutes pertaining to such tax assessment were constitutional, and it affirmed the order of the tax commissioner. The financial institution appealed, and the court affirmed the decision of the Board. The court determined that any confusion regarding the issue of taxing depositors was resolved when certain statutes were amended. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5709.02 (amended) provided that ownership interests of the depositors in the financial institution, the capital of which was not divided into shares or which had no capital stock as such ownership interests as defined in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5725.04, 5725.07, were subject to taxation. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5725.04, 5725.07 (amended) also provided for taxation of the depositors. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 57109.09 (amended) provided that the taxes assessed were a lien on ownership interests. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5719.10 provided that the financial institution could charge the amount of the tax paid by it to the depositors.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decree of the Board.

 

217 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Martin


No. 35323


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 37; 151 N.E.2d 7; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 376; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 293



May 28, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Stark County.

Two separate but similar affidavits were filed in the Canton Municipal Court against Edward H. Martin, appellant herein, hereinafter designated defendant, by an inspector of the Division of Water, Ohio Department of Natural Resources, in which defendant was charged with two violations of Section 1521.05, Revised Code, for failure to file, within 30 days after the completion of two different water wells, copies of his logs relative to the drilling of such wells. Defendant demurred to both affidavits upon the ground that they do not set forth facts constituting an offense under the laws of Ohio, for the reason that Section 1521.05 is unconstitutional, null and void.

The Municipal Court sustained the demurrers and dismissed the affidavits, whereupon an appeal was taken to the Court of Common Pleas, which court affirmed the judgment of the Municipal Court.

From the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas an appeal was taken to the Court of Appeals, and that court reversed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court.

The cause is in this court on an appeal as of right involving a debatable constitutional question.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed [***2] .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Stark County (Ohio), which reversed a lower court's order that sustained the demurrers filed by defendant and dismissed charges against him for violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1521.05 by failing to file, within 30 days after the completion of two different water wells, copies of his logs relative to the drilling of such wells.


OVERVIEW: The Division of Water, Ohio Department of Natural Resources, determined that defendant, a professional water well digger, had failed to provide the Division with drilling logs. Subsequently, defendant was charged with violations of § 1521.05. The municipal court granted his motion to dismiss the affidavits against him on the grounds that § 1521.05 was unconstitutional, the common pleas court affirmed, and the appellate court reversed. Defendant appealed, and the court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, holding that § 1521.05 was not unconstitutional. Although the statute had made a distinction between professional and private well diggers, the court found that the classification was reasonable in light of the purpose behind its enactment, namely, the monitoring of water supplies within the state. Further, § 1521.05 was a proper use of police power because the public had a supreme interest in preservation and conservation of the natural resource of clean water, and the statute was enacted to provide the Division with information regarding that water.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment and its ruling to reverse the lower courts' judgments that sustained the demurrers filed by defendant and dismissed the charges against him.

 

218 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Mahoning County Bar Ass'n v. Franko


D. D. No. 3


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 17; 151 N.E.2d 17; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 375; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 282



May 28, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*18contd]

 [**20contd]

[EDITOR'S NOTE: The page numbers of this document may appear to be out of sequence; however, this pagination accurately reflects the pagination of the original published document.]

 [***1] ON CERTIFIED REPORT by the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline.

This is a disciplinary proceeding arising under and by virtue of Rules XXVII and XXVIII of the Rules of Practice of the Supreme Court of Ohio (see statement of facts in Cleveland Bar Association v. Pleasant, 167 Ohio St., 325, regarding the reason for and purpose of Rule XXVII), wherein the respondent, Judge Frank R. Franko, is alleged to be subject to discipline by virtue of his breach of one or more of the Canons of Judicial Ethics duly adopted by this court and made a part of Rule XXVIII in 1954.

Upon complaint being made according to the procedure outlined in Rule XXVII, a panel of three commissioners was appointed by the Chairman of the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline, pursuant to the provisions of Rule XXVII, Section 10, and a hearing was had during which the relator, the Mahoning County Bar Association, and the respondent presented evidence.

Subsequent to such hearing, it was the finding of the board of commissioners that the respondent was guilty of a violation of the Canons of Judicial Ethics adopted by this court, and that discipline is merited. It is the board's [***2] recommendation that respondent be suspended.

To this report and recommendation respondent duly filed his objections, pursuant to the provisions of Rule XXVII, Section 17, and a hearing was had before this court.

Further facts will be stated hereinafter.



DISPOSITION: Report confirmed and judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner bar association filed a disciplinary action against respondent attorney.


OVERVIEW: During hi campaign for judge, the attorney stated that he disagreed with the practice of marking drivers licenses for minor traffic offenses. After he was elected, the attorney held unscheduled court on Saturdays where he accepted guilty pleas to traffic offenses. The attorney gave a low fine, did not assess costs, and did not mark licenses. The attorney dismissed all parking tickets. The attorney campaigned for the position of prosecuting attorney by publishing a newsletter, sending letters, and giving every defendant at traffic court a letter referring to his record and position as a judge. The association filed a disciplinary action. The court suspended the attorney from the practice of law for an indefinite period. The court held that it had jurisdiction to disbar the attorney for actions taken while he was a judge. The attorney violated Ohio Code Jud. Conduct Cannon 30 by failing to resign his bench when he began to run for prosecutor. The court held that the attorney's conduct regarding the traffic court was not protected as judicial discretion. The court held that the attorney's conduct was an inexcusable violation of the ethical foundation of the judicial system.


OUTCOME: The court suspended the attorney from the practice of law indefinitely.

 

219 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Latham


No. 35566


Supreme Court of Ohio


168 Ohio St. 14; 150 N.E.2d 857; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 372; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 263



May 21, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Madison County.

The petitioner, Latham, appellant herein, on his plea of guilty to two counts of an indictment charging sodomy, was ordered committed to the Lima State Hospital for observation as provided in Section 2947.25, Revised Code. Thereafter, petitioner was returned to court, and, upon consideration of a report of the superintendent of the hospital and other evidence, the court found him to be psychotic and sentenced him to the Ohio Penitentiary. Under the provisions of Section 2947.25, Revised Code, sentence was suspended, and petitioner was committed indefinitely to Lima State Hospital. He was later transferred to the penitentiary under authority of Section 2947.27, Revised Code, and later to the London Prison Farm.
