By this proceeding in habeas corpus, brought in the Court of Appeals, petitioner seeks his release from the London Prison Farm on the grounds that Sections 2947.25 and 2947.27, Revised Code, are unconstitutional, and that the trial court, on petitioner's plea of guilty, was without authority to determine petitioner's mental condition without the intervention of a jury or a waiver of a jury trial.

The Court of Appeals [***2] found that petitioner was lawfully in custody, denied the relief sought, and ordered him remanded to the custody of respondent.

An appeal as of right brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

220 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Kidd


Nos. 35215, 35216, 35233, 35317, 35318


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 521; 150 N.E.2d 413; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 534; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 202; 34 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P71,512



April 30, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Butler County.

In the several causes now here for review the defendants, storekeepers and one clerk, were charged with and convicted in various Municipal Courts of violating Section 3773.24, Revised Code, commonly known as the Sunday closing law or blue law, and all the convictions were affirmed on appeal.

Causes Nos. 35215 and 35216 originated in the Cincinnati Municipal Court. Defendant Kidd was a co-owner and operator of a self-serve food market in the city of Cincinnati, and defendant Mills was clerk at the check-out counter in such store. Purchases consisting of groceries, soap, an electric iron and insect spray were made in the store on a Sunday afternoon by police officers, who then advised Kidd and Mills that they were being cited to court -- Kidd for opening and conducting a business on Sunday and Mills for engaging in common labor on that day. Affidavits were subsequently filed against the two. The cases were tried concurrently, and some of the evidence introduced is to the effect that the store was located in a neighborhood [***2] inhabited and frequented by those who lacked facilities for storing and preserving food.

Cause No. 35233 originated in the Cleveland Municipal Court. Leff, the defendant, was president of the Three Bears Super Stores, Inc., an Ohio corporation, engaged in a number of stores in selling a variety of products. The store here involved was opened on a Sunday, sales of flashlight bulbs were made and prosecution followed.

Causes Nos. 35317 and 35318 had their inception in the Hamilton Municipal Court. One of the affidavits charges the defendant, Ullner, with opening or causing to be opened a building for the transaction of business on Sunday, and the other charges him with requiring a person (his employee) to engage in common labor on Sunday.

Causes Nos. 35215 and 35216 were appealed on questions of law from the Municipal Court to the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County. Cause No. 35233 went from the Municipal Court to the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County. Causes Nos. 35317 and 35318 went from the Municipal Court to the Court of Common Pleas of Butler County and from there to the Court of Appeals for that county.

In all causes, the Courts of Appeals affirmed the judgments of [***3] the lower courts.

All the causes are now here for disposition on appeals as of right and on the allowance of motions to require the respective Courts of Appeals to certify the records.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a consolidated appeal, three defendants sought review of a judgments by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), and the Court of Appeals for Butler County (Ohio), which affirmed their convictions for violating the Sunday Closing Law, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3773.24.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were two co-owners of a self-serve food market and one clerk at the market's counter. Purchases consisting of groceries, soap, an electric iron and insect spray were made in the store on a Sunday afternoon by police officers, who then advised two of them that they would be cited for opening and conducting a business on Sunday in violation of § 3773.24. All three defendants were convicted. On appeal, they challenged the constitutionality and validity of § 3773.24. The court found that § 3773.24 did not interfere and was not designed to interfere with the freedom of religious worship or the free exercise of religious beliefs. Furthermore, the court did not find any reason to overturn the trial court's finding that none of the three defendants showed their work to be of necessity on the day in question. Moreover, the court ruled that whether the Sunday Closing Law was outmoded, obsolete, and unrealistic and should be eradicated was essentially a legislative and not a judicial problem.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendants' convictions.

 

221 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Appropriation for Highway Purposes


No. 35230


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 463; 150 N.E.2d 30; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 549; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 149



April 23, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County.

In the Court of Common Pleas the city of Youngstown and the Director of Highways of the state of Ohio instituted this action to appropriate a lot of land 50 feet wide and 150 feet long located in the city of Youngstown, Ohio.

The land was owned by the defendant, the Joseph Evans Ice Cream Company, a corporation.

However, the situation was complicated by the fact that the land was under a lease assigned to the Evans Dairy Company, hereinafter called the lessee, also a corporation and also a party defendant in this action.

The jury returned a verdict reading in part as follows:

"Compensation for land taken

$  2,000

Compensation for building taken

$ 30,000

Total compensation of land and buildings

$ 32,000

The Evans Dairy Company interest in the

 

above total compensation is

$ 5,000"

The Court of Common Pleas rendered a judgment on the verdict.

On an appeal to the Court of Appeals on questions of law, the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was affirmed.

The cause is in this court for a review by reason of the allowance of the plaintiff's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant director sought review of the judgment from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County (Ohio) that was granted in favor of appellees, lessee and lessor in an action to appropriate a lot of land that was under a lease assigned to the lessee. The issue raised was whether the trial court was erred in admitting certain evidence and in permitting the jury to determine the lessee's compensation for the leasehold interest as a separate item.


OVERVIEW: The director instituted an action to appropriate a lot of land that was owned by the lessor and that was leased by the lessee. Following the judgment that was granted in favor of appellees in an action to appropriate a lot of land, the director sought review of the decision. The director argued that the trial court erred in admitting evidence of removing, moving, reinstalling personal property, and expense of establishing new quarters. The court held that the trial court was in error in admitting the questioned evidence and in permitting the jury to determine the lessee's compensation for the leasehold interest as a separate item in the total compensation for the land and building taken. Further, the court held that it was unable to construe the unambiguous mandatory provision in Ohio Rev. Cove Ann. § 5519.02 as meaning that it does not preclude a trial court from allowing a separate presentation by each individual with respect to his separate interest in the appropriated property. Additionally, the court founds itself unable to so view the matter in the light of the requirement that the owners of the various interests in the property shall be considered as one party.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that was granted in favor of appellees in an action to appropriate a certain lot of land. Additionally, the cause was remanded for a retrial.

 

222 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Miller v. Brown


No. 35550


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 452; 150 N.E.2d 46; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 522; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 142



April 16, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

The present case is an action originating in this court.

On March 10, 1958, the relator, John F. Miller, filed a petition for a writ of mandamus against respondents, Ted W. Brown, Secretary of State, and the four members of the Board of Elections of Cuyahoga County, to compel the Secretary of State to order and the board to provide a separate place on the ballot for the office of county commissioner of Cuyahoga County "for the full term commencing upon the earliest date in January 1959 and next succeeding the expiration of the existing term which began the third day of January 1955," and to compel the board of elections to accept the petition and declaration of candidacy of relator for such office for that term.

Relator claims the right to be a candidate for a particular membership on a multimember board. He seeks to be a candidate for a particular "slot" in the board membership or, to use another commonly accepted expression, to "run in an alley," as distinguished from "running against the field."

Respondents demurred to relator's petition upon the ground that, on the face thereof, the petition does not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.



DISPOSITION:  [***2] Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator candidate filed a petition for a writ of mandamus against respondents, the Secretary of State of Ohio and four members of a county election board, seeking to compel them to place him on the ballot for the office of county commissioner..


OVERVIEW: The candidate claimed the right to be a candidate for a particular membership on a multimember board. He sought to be a candidate for a particular "slot" in the board membership or, to use another commonly accepted expression, to "run in an alley," as distinguished from "running against the field." Respondents demurred to the candidate's petition, contending that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 305.01 was unconstitutional or that it did not apply to them. The court allowed the writ, holding that § 305.01 violated Ohio Const. art. II, § 26 and that it was so confused, vague, unworkable, and discriminatory that it amounted to no effective legislation and was void. Under such circumstances, it followed that the former § 305.01 was in effect, and that there was but one county commissioner to be elected for a full term in each of all the state's counties in the general election in November 1958. Because of the enactment of the new law, many persons of both parties had filed nominations, and it was only fair and logical that the candidate be given a chance to run in the election. Because of its decision, the court treated as surplusage the reference to a term in the candidate's petition.


OUTCOME: The court allowed the writ.

 

223 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Beachwood v. Board of Elections


No. 35285


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 369; 148 N.E.2d 921; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 505; 5 Ohio Op. 2d 6



March 19, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This action arose in the following manner. On March 25, 1957, a petition was filed with the Board of Elections of Cuyahoga County, an appellee herein, for the detachment of a certain portion of the village of Beachwood, appellant herein, and the formation of this territory into a new township under the provisions of Section 709.39, Revised Code. The board of elections having determined that such petition complied with the provisions of the statute relating to detachment ordered an election to be held on April 30, 1957. Thereupon the village instituted this action seeking to enjoin the election, on the theory that the petition for detachment and the proceeding thereunder were null and void for the reason that the petitioners had failed to comply with the charter provisions of the village of Beachwood relating to detachment of territory but instead had brought such proceeding under the general statutes of the state. The village's basic contention is that detachment proceedings are matters of local self-government under the home-rule provisions of Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution, and that the charter provisions relating [***2] to detachment supersede the general statutory provisions.

The Court of Common Pleas denied the injunction, and upon appeal to the Court of Appeals the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was affirmed.

The cause is before this court on an appeal as of right and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant village challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the decision of the trial court, denying an injunction against appellee county board of elections to enjoin the election for the detachment of a certain portion of the village.


OVERVIEW: A petition was filed with the Board for the detachment of a certain portion of the village and the formation of this territory into a new township under Ohio Rev. Code § 709.39. The Board ordered an election to be held. The village sought to enjoin the election on the theory that the petition and the proceeding were null and void for the reason that the petitioners failed to comply with the charter provisions of the village relating to detachment of territory but instead had brought such proceeding under the general statutes of the state. The village's contention was that detachment proceedings were matters of local self-government under the home-rule provisions of Ohio Const. art. XVIII and that the charter provisions relating to detachment superseded the general statutory provisions. The trial court denied the injunction, which was affirmed on appeal. The court held that the detachment of the territory from the township was not a subject which fell within the sphere of local self-government, but was a matter which required the establishment of a uniform procedure throughout the state and was exclusively within the control of the general assembly.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.

 

224 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland Bar Ass'n v. Pleasant


D. D. No. 1


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 325; 148 N.E.2d 493; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 497; 4 Ohio Op. 2d 433



March 5, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] ON CERTIFIED REPORT by the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline.

The present cause is before this court upon objections to the final report of the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline, including its findings of fact and recommendations.

This court, having determined to exercise more fully original disciplinary powers over the Bar of this state and the members thereof, amended its Rule XXVII, effective January 1, 1957.

Under such amendment, the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline is set up, empowered and charged to receive, entertain, inquire into, take proofs, make findings, and submit recommendations to this court concerning complaints of misconduct of attorneys and concerning petitions for reinstatement as attorney. Such board is empowered to investigate upon its own motion and refer any matters to a grievance committee of an appropriate local bar association or to the Committee on Legal Ethics and Professional Conduct of the Ohio State Bar Association.

The commissioners are appointed by this court, one from each of 17 districts. The board has exclusive jurisdiction concerning the investigation of complaints and grievances as to [***2] attorneys and judges, and all proceedings for reinstatement of an attorney, although nothing is to be construed to prevent any committee of a regularly organized bar association or the Ohio State Bar Association from investigating and reporting on any complaint filed with either of them.

The rule defines misconduct as a violation of the oath of office taken upon admission to practice law, or as any violation of the Canons of Professional Ethics or the Canons of Judicial Ethics as adopted by this court from time to time, or as the commission of or conviction for a crime involving moral turpitude.

The following four grades of discipline are established:

(a) A permanent disbarment from the practice of law.

(b) Suspension for an indefinite period from the practice of law, subject to reinstatement upon certain conditions.

(c) A public reprimand.

(d) A private reprimand.

The rule sets forth the manner of making a complaint and the duty of the board upon the filing of the complaint as to notice to respondent and time for answer, provides for a hearing of the complaint by a panel of three commissioners, no one of whom shall be a resident of the district from which the complaint originated,  [***3] and sets forth the power of the panel to dismiss the complaint if found without merit or to administer a private reprimand. If the panel finds that a more severe disciplinary action is merited, it shall make a certified report, including its findings and recommendations, to the board of commissioners, which must review such findings, and, if the board finds that a public reprimand, suspension or disbarment is merited, the board shall make a final certified report of its proceedings, including its findings of fact and recommendations, and shall file the same, together with the transcript of testimony taken, with the clerk of this court. The rule then provides for the filing of objections to the report of the board by the one against whom the charges have been filed and for a review and final order in respect thereto by this court.

The rule provides further that all proceedings shall be private until filed in this court, unless the one against whom the charges are made shall request in writing that they be public.

The rule provides in detail for petitions for reinstatement and proceedings incident thereto, which provisions are not of importance in the present case.

The present case [***4] originated by the filing of charges by the Cleveland Bar Association against Henry H. Pleasant, and, after the matter was considered by the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline, that board made findings of fact and recommendations, as follows:

"This matter came on for consideration before the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline on the pleadings, the evidence, the exhibits, on the briefs of counsel, and on the transcript of the proceedings before the hearing panel. Said board of commissioners hereby makes the following findings of fact:

"1. The respondent, Henry H. Pleasant, on February 19, 1949, was duly appointed by the Probate Court of Cuyahoga County as administrator of the estate of William A. Wright, deceased.

"2. The respondent also acted as attorney for the estate of William A. Wright, deceased.

"3. The respondent also represented, as attorney, one of the claimants, William Wright, who was later determined by the court to be the sole heir of the estate of William A. Wright, deceased.

"4. The respondent represented the claimant, William Wright, as attorney, from on or about the 15th day of March 1949, until the termination of said estate.

 [***5] "5. The respondent at no time made full and complete disclosure to the judge or any officer of the Probate Court of Cuyahoga County of his representation of William Wright, claimant or sole heir of said estate.

"6. The respondent made a fee arrangement on a percentage basis with William Wright for a share of his recovery from the estate of William A. Wright, deceased, as evidenced by a written contract dated September 20, 1949, of which no disclosure was made.

"7. The respondent, as a result of his conduct with reference to said estate, was, as a matter of record, found guilty of perpetrating a fraud on the Probate Court of Cuyahoga County, which finding remains unreversed and unmodified.

"8. The respondent violated the statutory requirements provided for in Section 10509-193, Ohio General Code ( Section 2113.36, Ohio Revised Code), relative to the further allowance of counsel fees to be charged against an estate.

"9. The respondent violated the established practice in the Probate Court of Cuyahoga County relative to the procedure pertaining to the allowance of counsel fees to be charged against an estate.

"10. It is therefore the determination of the board of commissioners that [***6] the respondent, Henry H. Pleasant, has violated Section 5 of Rule XXVII on disciplinary procedure of the Supreme Court of Ohio. The respondent is guilty of misconduct in that he violated his oath of office and the Canons of Professional Ethics, more particularly sections 6, 29, 32, and 38 of said canons.

"RECOMMENDATION

"The Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline hereby recommends that the respondent, Henry H. Pleasant, be suspended from the practice of law for an indefinite period."

Henry H. Pleasant was admitted to the Bar of the state of Ohio in 1931 and has been practicing law ever since that date, except that in 1941 he was suspended from practice for eight months by the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County.

In 1949, much of Pleasant's practice consisted of Probate Court work.

On February 16, 1949, one William A. Wright, whom Pleasant had known since 1944 but had never represented, died intestate.

A Bessie Hansen called Pleasant to come to a funeral home, which he did, taking with him an application for the appointment of an administrator. Upon arrival at the funeral home, he met Hansen and two others who claimed to be second cousins of the deceased. Pleasant [***7] had never before known these people and took it for granted that they were second cousins. These second cousins requested Pleasant that he be appointed administrator, they signed waivers on the application for appointment, and, on February 19, Pleasant obtained such appointment.

On February 20, Pleasant and the second cousins went to the deceased's house to search for a possible will, bankbooks, or papers.

Shortly thereafter, a woman by the name of Helen Pavloski came to Pleasant's office and claimed to have been the commonlaw wife of the deceased, and a few days later she returned with a young man whom she claimed was her son by the deceased.

Pleasant told her he would not recognize her claim and if she wished to press the matter she would have to obtain a lawyer and have the court decide.

On February 22, Pleasant prepared a petition to determine heirship, an application to determine succession tax, and a petition to sell real estate.

About two months after Pleasant's appointment as administrator, William Wright came to Pleasant's office and claimed to be a friend of the family. About 10 days later, Wright returned and claimed to be a first cousin of the deceased.

This happened [***8] between March 10 and 15.

The petition to determine heirship was not filed until March 21, 1949.

Pleasant did not advise Wright to obtain a lawyer to represent him as he had done with reference to Pavloski.

Pleasant wrote letters to England and elsewhere and eventually obtained a birth certificate on May 15, 1949, establishing that William Wright was the first cousin of the deceased.

On May 24, 1949, Pleasant amended his petition to determine heirship by adding, in longhand, the following, "Unknown heirs, devisees, legatees, administrators, executors of William A. Wright, deceased, and Agnes Boltz," and in addition the following was written, "William Wright, new party deft."

The petition to sell real estate, which was prepared on February 22, 1949, but not filed until March 22, 1949, failed to set forth the claim and interest of William Wright as first cousin, but was amended May 24, 1949, by adding "William Wright, new defendant."

On June 3, 1949, there was a hearing on the petition to determine heirship, at which time William Wright was found to be the sole heir, and the real estate was ordered sold. On the same date, in Pleasant's office, William Wright discussed with him [***9] a new claim made by Pavloski for alleged services. Such claim had been filed on May 19, and, although Pleasant denied that he agreed to act as Wright's individual attorney, apparently, according to testimony Pleasant gave in a previous hearing, he had agreed to be Wright's lawyer with reference to the Pavloski claim.

On September 20, 1949, Pleasant and Wright signed an agreement, which stated that Wright had retained and employed Pleasant to act for and on his behalf in various legal matters pertaining to the estate of the deceased, and that Wright had agreed to pay Pleasant 40 per cent of whatever sums Wright might receive from the estate.

Based upon the wording of the agreement, an inference can be drawn that it was simply a written memorandum of an agreement entered into long before, and such inference, of course, is strengthened by the fact that, although Wright had told Pleasant before March 15 that he was a first cousin of the deceased, and the petition to determine heirship was filed on March 24, Wright was not made a defendant in such petition until May 24.

The final account filed in the administration of the estate shows administrator's fees of $ 235, and that [***10] William Wright was paid $ 3,612.10.

The final account was prepared on September 20, 1949, and, on September 21, Pleasant and Wright went to the Second Federal Savings & Loan, whereupon Wright was given a check for $ 3,612.10, Pleasant being designated as the maker. The check was approved by an officer of the Second Federal Savings & Loan, and then two checks were issued, one to Pleasant for $ 1,444.84, being 40 per cent of $ 3,612.10, and the other to Wright for the balance of $ 2,167.26, or 60 per cent.

The final account does not show that Pleasant received 40 per cent of the estate, nor was it ever brought to the court's attention.

As a result of the proceedings in the settlement of the estate, the Probate Court of Cuyahoga County found that Pleasant had perpetrated fraud upon it, and he was held in contempt. The matter finally reached this court in the case of In re Estate of Wright, 165 Ohio St., 15, 133 N. E. (2d), 350, where this court held in the syllabus as follows:

"1. It is a fundamental principle of law that, where parties having different interests are involved, no lawyer can represent or receive compensation from such parties without a full disclosure, to all [***11] the parties involved, of his dual representation and the arrangements as to the compensation to be received therefrom.

"2. Where an attorney is administrator of an estate and is likewise acting as attorney in such administration, in the absence of a full disclosure concerning an arrangement for compensation from a claimant against the estate and the consent of all interested parties, he impliedly represents that he has no such arrangement.

"3. Where an attorney, who is administrator of an estate, enters into a contract with a claimant against such estate for a percentage of the proceeds which such claimant may receive from the estate, makes no disclosure of such arrangement to the Probate Court in whose jurisdiction such estate is being administered, and such court proceeds to confirm the final account of such administrator, which it probably would not have done had it known of the arrangement, such administrator thereby perpetrates a fraud upon the court, for which the order confirming the final account may be vacated and which may constitute a direct contempt upon the court punishable under Section 2705.01, Revised Code."

Pleasant has presented four objections to the finding of [***12] the Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline:

"1. This entire procedure, it is humbly suggested, is based upon an erroneous assumption that respondent occupied an adverse position and represented adverse and conflicting interests.

"2. The panel, and all of the courts that have had anything to do with this matter, assumed the existence of a rule in the Probate Court of Cuyahoga County, which rule in fact did not exist.

"3. The respondent was not afforded a fair legal hearing before the panel inasmuch as he was not advised of the charges he was called upon to answer and certain requests and motions made by the respondent were never acted upon by the panel before, during, or after the hearing.

"4. The entire proceeding before the panel, as well as the rule of this court under which the proceeding was brought and conducted, is unconstitutional."



DISPOSITION: Report confirmed and judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent attorney filed objections to the complaint of relator bar association and the report and recommendation of the Ohio Board of Commissioners on Grievances and Discipline, which found that he had perpetrated a fraud on a court with regard to a probate proceedings and recommended his indefinite suspension from the practice of law.


OVERVIEW: The attorney was appointed administrator of a deceased's estate and thereafter undertook representation of one of the heirs with regard to his claims against the estate. The heir received the assets of the estate and paid the attorney a 40 percent fee. The attorney never advised the other potential heirs or the probate court of his duel representation and was thereafter found guilty of committing a fraud on the probate court. The bar association filed a grievance against the attorney, and the board recommended his indefinite suspension. The attorney objected to the report and recommendation, and the court confirmed the report. The attorney's actions in representing the estate and an heir created a conflict of interest that was required to be disclosed to the probate court and other potential heirs. The fee for the attorney's services to the estate was required to be approved by the probate court pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2113.36 and the private agreement with the heir circumvented the statute. Finally, the court had the power under the rules of court and Ohio Const. art. IV, § 1 to disbar the attorney, and the rules of the court were not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the report and recommendation of the board and suspended the attorney from the practice of law for an indefinite period.

 

225 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. McCann v. Defiance


No. 35284


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 313; 148 N.E.2d 221; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 492; 4 Ohio Op. 2d 369



February 19, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Defiance County.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator challenged judgment of the Court of Appeals for Defiance County (Ohio), which denied her a writ of mandamus to compel appellee city pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 743.13 to issue her a permit to tap into a water line and furnish water service to relator's premises from the municipal waterworks system owned and operated by the city at a rate not in excess of that permitted or provided by § 743.13.


OVERVIEW: A pipe line company had, at its own expense, laid down and extended mains and water pipes to its compressor station about four miles beyond the city's limits. By resolution, the city authorized the proper officer of the waterworks to superintend or supervise such laying and extension. Relator, a property owner who lived outside the city on the extended line, sought a writ of mandamus to compel the city to allow her to tap into the water line and have the city furnish her with water pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 743.13. The appeals court denied the writ by finding that § 743.13 was unconstitutional. On appeal, the court affirmed the denial of the writ by holding that § 743.13 unconstitutionally imposed limitations and restrictions on the power conferred on a municipality by Ohio Const. art. XVII, § 6 by requiring the municipality to furnish water to non-inhabitants, whether or not the city was willing and able to do so, but also by limiting the price which it could charge for such water. To the extent that § 743.13 did limit and restrict the city's power to sell and deliver to non-inhabitants its surplus product, § 743.13 conflicted with Ohio Const. art. XVIII and was void.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appeals court's denial of relator's action for a writ of mandamus.

 

226 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Union Carbide & Carbon Corp. v. Bargain Fair, Inc.


No. 35097


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 182; 147 N.E.2d 481; 1958 Ohio LEXIS 467; 4 Ohio Op. 2d 252



January 22, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

This cause involves a part of the Ohio Fair Trade Act (Section 1333.05 et seq., Revised Code) and originated in the Court of Common Pleas of Lake County in November of 1954, when the Union Carbide & Carbon Corporation, plaintiff and the appellee herein, sought an injunction against Bargain Fair, Inc., and Mentor Brands, Inc., defendants and the appellants herein, to restrain them from selling at a price less than the minimum resale price set by plaintiff under the Ohio Fair Trade Act an antifreeze solution for the radiators of motor vehicles, bearing the trade or brand name of Prestone and produced by the plaintiff.

A general demurrer to the amended petition was filed and overruled, whereupon, after the filing of an answer, the cause was tried on its merits, and the court issued a permanent injunction against defendants in conformity with the prayer of the amended petition.

Thereafter, the cause was appealed on questions of law and fact to the Court of Appeals, which court likewise granted a permanent injunction against the defendants, almost identical in context to the one secured in the court below.

Allowance of a motion [***2] to require the Court of Appeals to certify the record and an appeal as of right place the controversy before this court for decision on the merits.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant retailers challenged an order from the Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio), which enjoined them from selling a certain antifreeze solution at certain at prices less than the plaintiff manufacturer's minimum resale price as provided for in the manufacturer's agreements with the brand name antifreeze solution and dealers in Ohio. The retailers challenged the validity of § 1333.07.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer sought an injunction against two retailers to restrain them from selling at a price less than the minimum resale price set by the manufacturer under the Ohio Fair Trade Act (Act), specifically at Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.07, for the antifreeze solution for the radiators of motor vehicles, bearing a certain trade or brand name and produced by the manufacturer. The trial court tried the case on its merits and issued a permanent injunction against the retailers in conformity with the manufacturer's prayer. The retailers had purchased it at a certain undisclosed price and were selling it to customers, "over the counter" and without additional service, at a price lower than that for which the manufacturer had contracted. The retailers challenged the validity of § 1333.07. The court concluded that § 1333.07, which prohibited those who were not parties to the stipulated-price contract from selling trademarked items at a price lower than that stipulated by the manufacturer, was unreasonable and unenforceable and constituted an unauthorized exercise of the police power in that there was no substantial relation to the public safety, morals or general welfare.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court below and remanded the cause to that court with instructions to dissolve the injunction issued, having found in favor of the retailers, that the statutory provisions of the Act were unenforceable.

 

227 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Benjamin v. Columbus


Nos. 35179, 35180


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 103; 146 N.E.2d 854; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 337; 4 Ohio Op. 2d 113



December 18, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

These two actions for declaratory judgment and injunction were heard together by the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County under a stipulation that any evidence competent in one case should be competent in the other, and that the validity of three ordinances of the city of Columbus should be treated as being involved in each case. The plaintiffs in both cases, herein referred to as plaintiffs, have for varying numbers of years owned and operated in Columbus varying numbers of pin-game machines having very substantial values.

The three ordinances, the validity of which are questioned and which are now incorporated in the Code of the City of Columbus, are ordinance No. 156-53, relative to licensing of mechanical amusement devices but containing some provisions relative to seizure of machines tending to encourage gambling, ordinance No. 157-53, relative to gambling but containing some provisions declaring as a nuisance the exhibition for the purpose of operation of machines merely tending to encourage gambling and authorizing their seizure, and ordinance No. 1615-54 which reads so far as pertinent:

"Section 29.69-1. * * * Whoever [***2] shall within the city have in his possession, or in his custody or under his control any table game or device commonly known as a 'pin game,' 'pin-ball game,' or 'marble game,' the operation, use or play of which is controlled by placing therein any coin, plate, disk, plug, key or other token, or by the payment of a fee, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor * * *."

In the preamble to the ordinance enacting that section of the Code of the City of Columbus, it is stated in part:

"Whereas, the operation of pin-ball machines and similar machines involving chance or skill or reward encourages gaming and the general disorder incident thereto, and is a threat or menace to the peace and morals of the community; and,

"Whereas, even the so-called amusement-only pin-ball machines are so constructed as to be almost identical in appearance and operation to certain gambling devices, per se; and

"Whereas, even the vast majority of such so-called amusement-only devices are readily convertible to gambling devices; and,

"Whereas, the operation of even amusement-only pin-ball machines has become and now constitutes a nuisance in that it encourages a false sense of values, idling, and loitering * * *."

 [***3] This latter ordinance was enacted in December 1954, immediately after the Court of Appeals in Ferguson v. City of Columbus, 70 Ohio Law Abs., 277, 128 N. E. (2d), 198, had cast doubt upon the effectiveness of the two earlier ordinances in discouraging the ownership or exhibition of machines which, although not gambling devices per se or shown to have been used for gambling, either tended to encourage gambling, were adapted for gambling, might readily be converted to be so adapted, or registered odds or a score.

The Common Pleas Court determined that all these ordinances are "invalid, unconstitutional and void, insofar as they prohibit the ownership, possession, custody, control and operation of pin games for amusement purposes only" and decreed that defendants should be enjoined from interfering under these ordinances "with the ownership, possession, custody, control and operation of said pin games by * * * plaintiffs * * * as well as interfering with or molesting any merchant with whom said plaintiffs have either heretofore had, or may now or hereafter have, contracts for the operation of said games, so long as said games are not used for gambling." Benjamin v. City  [***4] of Columbus, 73 Ohio Law Abs., 143, 136 N. E. (2d), 641.

On appeal to the Court of Appeals on questions of law and fact, that court determined that the three ordinances are valid and that plaintiffs were "not entitled to an injunction restraining the enforcement of said ordinances" and dismissed the petitions.

These two causes are now before this court on appeal from the judgments of the Court of Appeals, both as appeals involving constitutional questions and pursuant to allowances of motions to certify the records.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff pin-game machine owners appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed a determination that three ordinances prohibiting the ownership of such machines passed and enforced by defendants, the city and others, were invalid and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, in two separate cases, brought an action for declaratory judgment and injunction, seeking to have the ordinances held invalid. The cases were consolidated and the trial court found in plaintiffs' favor. Defendants appealed and the appellate court reversed the decision of the trial court. Plaintiffs appealed and the court concentrated its attention on Columbus, Ohio, Code § 29.69-1 (1954), disagreeing with plaintiffs' contention that, although the city had power to make regulations with respect to pin-game machines, it had no power to prohibit them. The court also disagreed that the ordinance was arbitrary and unreasonable and took plaintiffs' property without due process. The court held that the breadth of the prohibition of possession of the machines had a reasonable basis and could reasonably have been determined by the city to bear a real and substantial relationship to the health, morals, safety, and welfare of the people of the city. The court concluded that the allegations of plaintiffs' petitions and the provisions of § 29.69-1 required the dismissal of the petitions and declined to rule on the validity of the other ordinances.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment in favor of defendants.

 

228 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Wetterer v. Hamilton County Bd. of Health


No. 35084


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 127; 146 N.E.2d 846; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 340; 4 Ohio Op. 2d 127



December 18, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This is an appeal on questions of law from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, modifying and affirming a declaratory judgment of the Court of Common Pleas of that county that the "Hamilton County District Board of Health has the right, power and duty to enact reasonable rules and regulations to provide for licensing and registration of plumbers."

The parties will be referred to as they appeared in the Court of Common Pleas.

Plaintiffs Wetterer, Kellogg, Gerde and Nordeman have worked at the pipe-fitting trade, including the installation of pipe fixtures and other apparatus for processing industrial waste products, for varying periods of years ranging from 11 to 27, and at the time this action was begun they were so employed in the construction of certain additional test facilities for the completion of the manufacture of jet engines on the premises of the General Electric Company, at Lockland, Ohio.

The other plaintiffs are the Journeymen Pipe Fitters' Local Union No. 392 of the United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipe Fitting Industry of the United States and Canada, A.  [***2] F. of L., and James P. Maher, individually and as an officer and member of said union.

The defendants are the Hamilton County Board of Health, herein called defendant, and E. J. Nolan Corporation, the subcontracting company engaged by the General Electric Company to construct a part of the test cells, which corporation filed no answer.

The facts are undisputed and may be summarized as follows:

The plans and specifications of the proposed test facilities were submitted to the Hamilton County Board of Health for approval and permit. A building permit was issued and work begun. The plumbing inspector of the Hamilton County Board of Health designated the piping work as plumbing, in accordance with the definition thereof in the "Rules and Regulations for Installation and Inspection of Plumbing within the Hamilton County General Health District," adopted by the Hamilton County Board of Health in 1951 and amended in 1953.

The 1953 amendment provided for a Board of Plumbing Examiners authorized to examine and license master and journeyman plumbers and provided that "all plumbing and private sewer disposal installations, repairs and replacements within the * * * district" were to be made [***3] by a certified licensed master plumber licensed by the Hamilton County Health Department.

By the standards of eligibility fixed by the Board of Plumbing Examiners, the plaintiffs were ineligible for examination as journeyman plumbers and therefore forbidden to perform jobs and work which admittedly they have performed capably and competently for many years.

The plaintiffs claim that the board of health "has no authority whatsoever to license persons to perform plumbing work" or "to require licenses of persons performing plumbing work within the Hamliton County General Health District," and pray for an order restraining the Hamilton County Board of Health from enforcing said regulations.

A temporary restraining order was issued by the Court of Common Pleas, and when the matter was heard on the merits the court made this finding:

"1. The legislation creating the health districts in Ohio is a valid exercise of legislative power;

"2. The Hamilton County District Board of Health has the right, power and duty to enact reasonable rules and regulations to provide for licensing and registration of plumbers;

"3. The Hamilton County Board of Health exceeded its authority when it created [***4] and delegated to the Board of Examiners of Plumbers powers and duties restricted to the board of health and the actions of the board of examiners are a nullity;

"4. The prerequisites for eligibility to take an examination for plumbers' license are not shown to be an unreasonable exercise of discretion by the board of health;

"5. The rules and regulations set forth in sections 1 and 2, which restrict to plumbers only work in connection with plumbing which does not have a reasonable relation to the health and general welfare of the public are invalid."

The restraining order was made permanent.

An appeal was prosecuted to the Court of Appeals, which court affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, with the modification that "there is a requirement that reasonable standards be set up by which the eligibility for license as a plumber might be ascertained by those seeking such a license, with standards for examination."

The cause is before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record and on appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, pipe fitters and a pipe fitters' local union, appealed from the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) that held that defendant board of health had the right, power, and duty to enact reasonable standards by which the eligibility for license as a plumber could be ascertained.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs filed a declaratory judgment action, asserting that the board of health had no authority to license persons to perform plumbing work and praying for an order restraining it from enforcing its regulations to that effect. The action arose after plaintiffs were declared ineligible to perform certain piping work on a project in which the board of health was the subcontractor. The court of common pleas declared that the board of health had the right, power, and duty to enact reasonable rules and regulations to provide for licensing and registration of plumbers. The court of appeals affirmed, but modified the judgment by stating that reasonable standards had to be set up by which the eligibility for license as a plumber might be ascertained. The court reversed, holding that there was neither express, nor implied power in a board of health of a general health district to enact rules and regulations providing for the licensing of plumbers, and that the board of health was a creature of statute and had such powers only as were expressly conferred on it, together with such powers as were necessarily implied in order to effectuate such expressly granted powers.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment, which held that the board of health had the right, power, and duty to enact reasonable standards by which the eligibility for license as a plumber could be ascertained.

 

229 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Pompei Winery, Inc. v. Board of Liquor Control


No. 35094


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 61; 146 N.E.2d 430; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 325; 4 Ohio Op. 2d 29



November 27, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The class A-2, B-4 and B-5 permits of appellant herein were suspended by order of the Board of Liquor Control, appellee herein, pursuant to a hearing by said board and a finding that appellant was guilty of specified violations of a certain regulation adopted by the board and fixing minimum prices at which bottled wine might be sold in the state of Ohio.

The regulation of the board which the appellant was found to have violated is Section 1, Article VII of Regulation 3, which article is in part as follows:

"This article is promulgated pursuant to the provisions of Section 6064-3a of the General Code [Section 4301.13, Revised Code], to avoid economic and social consequences which flow from unfair competition and improper practices in the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages. It is hereby declared to be the policy and intent of the board, in promulgating this article to advance the social control of an alcoholic beverage and to stabilize the sale and distribution of bottled wine in Ohio. It is intended to eliminate practices in the sale and distribution of wines in Ohio which cause intemperance and improper usage [***2] of bottled wines.

"Section 1. In determining the 'minimum wholesale price' at which bottled wine, except champagne, sparkling wines and aperitif wine, shall be sold or distributed in Ohio by the holders of A-2, B-5 and B-2 permits for resale to holders of C-2, D-2, D-3, D-3a, D-4 or D-5 permits, the board will take into consideration and will be guided by the current selling price of wine in bulk in California, the current selling prices for California wines in bulk in the principal markets of the United States, the charges for the necessary transportation and delivery of wine in bulk from the place of origin to Ohio, all taxes and assessments and levies on wine (both federal and state or states), and the general prevailing cost of labels, containers, crowns, caps and seals. The cost so determined will be termed the 'prevailing cost' of such wine bottled in Ohio and there will be added to the cost above referred to, a bottling cost markup of 16% (sixteen per cent) of such 'prevailing cost' and which price so determined will be termed the 'minimum base cost.' The 16% markup is to cover in part, but without limitation, the cost for such items as labor, salaries of executives and officers,  [***3] rent, depreciation and maintenance of equipment and property, selling costs, insurance, license fees, property taxes, delivery charges (if any), shrinkage, breakage, evaporation and general overhead expenses. There will be added to the 'minimum base cost' of wine a wholesaler's markup of 20% (twenty per cent) of the minimum base cost; which price will be deemed the 'minimum wholesale price' to class C-2, D-2, D-3, D-3a, D-4 or D-5 permit holders and which markup is to cover in part, but without limitation, the cost of doing business by a distributor at wholesale of bottled wine for such items as labor, salaries of executives and officers, rent, depreciation, and maintenance of equipment and property, selling cost, insurance, license fees, property taxes, delivery charge (if any), breakage and general overhead cost.

"The board will fix as the 'minimum wholesale price' to class C-2, D-2, D-3, D-3a, D-4 and D-5 permit holders for wine produced outside the United States and imported into Ohio, the same 'minimum wholesale price' as is fixed for wine produced or bottled in Ohio.

"The 'minimum wholesale price' to class C-2, D-2, D-3, D-3a, D-4 and D-5 permit holders for wine produced in [***4] the United States, but bottled outside of Ohio, will be fixed by the board to be the same as the 'minimum wholesale price' fixed for wine produced or bottled in Ohio."

Appellant contends that this regulation is defective, but the board asserts that such regulation represents a valid exercise of the power given it by the General Assembly through the enactment of that part of Section 6064-3a, General Code, which, as present Section 4301.13, Revised Code, is, in part, as follows:

"The board [of liquor control] may determine and fix the minimum markups at wholesale or retail, or both, for bottled wine, and fix the minimum prices at which the various classes of bottled wine shall be distributed and sold in Ohio either at wholesale or retail, or both."

The Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County affirmed the finding of the board as to this aspect of the charges made against appellant, reversed the finding of the board on a point not in issue herein, and rendered a judgment to that effect.

The judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The cause is before this court as an appeal as of right and pursuant to the allowance of a [***5] motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wine company challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) affirming a lower judge's ruling favoring appellee Board of Liquor Control's decision terminating the company's liquor license.


OVERVIEW: The wine company's alcohol sales permits were revoked by the board owing to the company's refusal to sell its wine at the minimum price specified by regulations. The company sued, contending the various statutes and regulations authorizing the board to set such a price were unconstitutional. A trial judge held for the board, and a panel of intermediate appellate judges upheld that ruling. A further appeal was taken. The court affirmed, holding that although U.S. Const. amend. XI revoked prohibition, it expressly authorized the states to continue to regulate alcohol as they saw fit. Consequently, the State was authorized to regulate alcohol up to the point of banning it and that included the lesser action of setting a minimum price for it. The decision to delegate to the board the power to establish the applicable regulations for alcohol was not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power to an executive body, as there were sufficient legislative guidelines on how that power was to be employed. Finally, the board's regulations did not contradict applicable state statutory law.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed. The board had the constitutional power to regulate the price of alcohol, and the guidelines provided by the state legislature for the adoption of regulations were sufficiently concrete to avoid a separation of powers problem.

 

230 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Harley


No. 35306


Supreme Court of Ohio


167 Ohio St. 48; 146 N.E.2d 121; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 320; 4 Ohio Op. 2d 11



November 20, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN HABEAS CORPUS.

Harley, whose release from the Ohio Penitentiary is sought by this habeas corpus proceeding instituted in this court, was indicted on a charge of rape, pleaded guilty and was ordered sent to Lima State Hospital for examination for a period not to exceed 60 days, under authority of Section 2947.25, Revised Code. Thereafter he was returned to court, found not to be mentally ill or a mentally deficient or psychopathic offender, and was sentenced to the Ohio Penitentiary.



DISPOSITION: Petitioner remanded to custody.

 

231 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Curtiss v. Cleveland


No. 34906


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 509; 144 N.E.2d 177; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 438; 3 Ohio Op. 2d 1



July 10, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This is an action for a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief originating in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County.

The plaintiff appellee is the owner of real estate improved with a gasoline service station located at 17700 Lake Shore Boulevard in the city of Cleveland, Ohio. These premises were originally acquired by her in 1931, and, when so acquired, such premises were zoned for retail business use by a comprehensive zoning ordinance of the city of Cleveland, effective as of November 5, 1929. Under the ordinance, all the parcels of real estate on both sides of Lake Shore Boulevard between points at and near the intersections therewith of Nottingham and Windward Roads, respectively, were included in a "retail business district," which encompassed the premises of the plaintiff appellee.

Effective April 15, 1945, the council of the city of Cleveland adopted an ordinance, No. 1159-A-44, known as Section 210-109 of the Municipal Code of Cleveland, which provided that this retail business district should be changed into an apartment house district, designated as a "C-residence district." On December 19, 1949, Section [***2] 210-109 and other kindred provisions of the Municipal Code of Cleveland were repealed by the council of the city of Cleveland, and Sections 981 to 981-63, Municipal Code of Cleveland, were enacted to replace them. By Section 981-8 the designation "C-residence district" was changed to "multi-family districts."

Sections 981-29, 981-31 and 981-32 of the Municipal Code of Cleveland (now Sections 5.1132, 5.1134 and 5.1135 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Cleveland, 1951) are summarized by the Court of Appeals in its findings of fact, as follows:

"Section 5.1132 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Cleveland permits each property owner to continue the use existing on the effective date of ordinance No. 1159-A-44, April 15, 1945, but prevents the enlargement or expansion of such uses if they are nonconforming uses, that is, not a residential use. Section 5.1134 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Cleveland imposes limitations upon a nonconforming use which is abandoned and, upon abandonment, prevents the use of the premises for purposes other than those permitted in a multifamily district. Section 5.1135 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Cleveland prevents [***3] the restoration of nonconforming buildings or structures which have been more than 50 per cent destroyed or removed by whatever cause, including acts of God, but not including acts of malicious mischief or vandalism."

The plaintiff commenced this action in the Court of Common Pleas on November 29, 1950, against the city of Cleveland and the owners and lessees of other business premises located within the district included in the zoning ordinance. In her amended petition she asserts that the effect of the adoption of the zoning ordinance of 1945, of itself and construed in connection with the other applicable provisions (1949) of the Municipal Code of Cleveland, is impairment and depreciation of the economic use value and marketability of her property; that said amendatory ordinance is null and void, in that it deprives plaintiff and all other owners of real estate to which it appertains of their property and interest therein and of their possession and enjoyment thereof, without due process of law, in violation of the pertinent provisions of the state and federal Constitutions; and that the ordinance bears no substantial relation to the public health, safety, morals, convenience,  [***4] comfort, prosperity and general welfare.

The prayer of the petition seeks a declaration by the court that the zoning ordinances of 1945 and 1949 are unconstitutional, that said ordinances do not and shall not in any manner or degree impair, restrict or affect the full right and power of the plaintiff to improve and use her property for all the purposes and uses and in the manner prescribed as lawful therefor in the original zoning ordinance in force when she acquired and improved her property, and that said ordinances shall likewise not affect the owners of all parcels on Lake Shore Boulevard within reasonable proximity to her property; and asks that the city of Cleveland and all its officers, representatives and employees be restrained and enjoined from enforcing the amendatory ordinances against her property or that in the proximate vicinity of her property, and for further relief.

Answers and cross-petitions were filed by some of the defendants named in the petition as owners of real estate located in the vicinity of the plaintiff's property, which answers and cross-petitions in effect joined them with the plaintiff in her claims.

The answer of the city of Cleveland to the plaintiff's [***5] petition and the cross-petitions of the defendants sets forth fully the applicable provisions of the Charter of the City of Cleveland empowering it to enact said zoning ordinances, which charter provides for the creation of a Board of Zoning Appeals; sets forth the prior applicable zoning ordinances, together with present ordinances, which apply to the premises of the plaintiff; and states further that the City Planning Commission adopted the general plan of Cleveland May 6, 1949, under which this area is to be limited to apartment use, that the business district is to be situated on E. 185th Street (some distance from plaintiff's premises), and traffic is to be routed to Lakeland Freeway instead of the presently used Lake Shore Boulevard, that, since the passage of the 1945 and 1949 ordinances, residence buildings have been constructed in the vicinity in accord with the 1945 ordinance, and that the city was fully authorized by law to enact the 1945 ordinance in question.

All other allegations in the plaintiff's petition and the cross-petitions of the defendants are denied generally.

Upon trial in the Court of Common Pleas, the court found for the plaintiff and for the cross-petitioning [***6] defendants and held that the amending ordinances No. 1159-A-44 (1945) and No. 2204-A-48 (1949), known as Sections 981 to 981-63 of the Municipal Code of Cleveland, and all subsequently enacted ordinances of similar import and effect, so far as the same purport to restrict the improvement and use of the properties of plaintiff and the cross-petitioning defendants differently than the same were restricted by the original zoning ordinance of 1929, are unconstitutional, void and of no effect; and that the amendatory and subsequently enacted ordinances do not and shall not in any manner or degree impair, restrict or affect the full right and power of the plaintiff, the cross-petitioning defendants or the owners of all parcels on Lake Shore Boulevard between Nottingham Road and Windward Road to improve and use their properties in the manner prescribed as lawful therefor under the original zoning ordinance. The court then enjoined the city and its officers from enforcing the provisions of the amendatory ordinances against the plaintiff and the other owners above mentioned.

An appeal on questions of law and fact was prosecuted to the Court of Appeals by the city of Cleveland. Some defendant [***7] cross-petitioners did not join in the proceedings in the Court of Appeals.

The case was submitted to the Court of Appeals on the official court reporter's transcript of the testimony adduced in the Court of Common Pleas and the exhibits offered at such trial, and the transcript of the testimony and the exhibits offered at a hearing before a master commissioner appointed by the Court of Appeals, and other stipulated evidence.

The Court of Appeals heard the appeal of the city of Cleveland de novo and entered a judgment, accompanied by findings of fact and conclusions of law. The judgment of the Court of Appeals holds that the amendatory ordinances and enactments by the council of the city of Cleveland and all amendments and codifications thereof, specifically set forth in its findings of fact, to the extent that they affect certain listed properties that were substantially improved for business use prior to April 15, 1945, and owned by any of the appellees herein, as found in said separate findings of fact, so far as they purport to restrict the improvement, use and enjoyment of any such parcels differently than was lawful under the original zoning ordinance (effective November [***8] 5, 1929) and the amendments thereto effective before April 15, 1945, are unconstitutional, null and void, and that "the same shall not, in any manner or degree, impair, restrict or affect the full right and power of the owner or owners of such parcels of land, his or their heirs, legal representatives, successors and assigns, to improve, use and enjoy the same for all purposes and uses and in the manner prescribed as lawful therefor in such original zoning ordinance."

The judgment contains thereafter a list of the parcels so improved, by auditor's parcel number, and of their present owners. The city of Cleveland and all its officers, representatives and employees were "forever" enjoined from enforcing the provisions of the 1945 zoning ordinance and subsequently enacted amendatory ordinances as against the owners of any of the parcels listed or any persons claiming through or under such owners.

An appeal was prosecuted by the city of Cleveland to this court as a matter of right on the ground that a constitutional question is presented, which appeal was heard. A motion to certify the record was overruled.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which found, on a de novo review of a decision of the Court of Court of Common Pleas, that the city's zoning ordinances which rezoned plaintiff property owner's land were unconstitutional, null, and void, and enjoined the city from enforcing the ordinances against the property owners.


OVERVIEW: After the property owners purchased their land and made improvements, the city passed ordinances which changed the use of the land from retail business to multi-family. The trial court found the ordinances unconstitutional, and the Court of Appeals agreed. On appeal, the court reversed, holding that there was no authority for theory that one who acquired and improved property had a right to rely on the zoning regulations effective at the time of improvement, even to the point that such regulations would not be repealed or materially changed in the absence of compelling necessity. Rather, there could be no vested or contract rights against rezoning or an extension of a district, since zoning constituted a governmental, legislative, and discretionary power. The property owners' reliance on the original zoning ordinance in purchasing and improving their land was not sufficient to prevent rezoning. Where the rights of the property owners to continue the use indefinitely were preserved and provision made for administrative appeal for relief in individual cases, the ordinances could not be considered arbitrary or confiscatory.


OUTCOME: The judgment finding the amended zoning ordinances to be unconstitutional was reversed and remanded.

 

232 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Teegardin v. Foley


No. 35037


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 449; 143 N.E.2d 824; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 432; 2 Ohio Op. 2d 462



June 26, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Plaintiff, an automobile dealer and the appellant herein, instituted this action in the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County, naming the members of the Motor Vehicle Dealers' and Salesmen's Licensing Board, the Director of Highways and the Attorney General as parties defendant.

Plaintiff alleges that Section 1317.08, Revised Code, is unconstitutional in that it operates to deprive him of property without due process of law, and that under its provisions he is denied equal protection of the law. He prays for a declaratory judgment, an injunction and incidental relief. *


* We note here that this action was brought while the General Code was still in effect and is governed by the terms thereof. In view, however, of the fact that the Revised Code created no changes in the substance of all the statutes herein considered, we will confine our frame of reference to the Revised Code in order to avoid unnecessary length and confusion.

After a protracted pleading [***2] skirmish, the cause was heard on its merits, and a judgment was rendered for the defendants.

Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, a trial de novo was had, and judgment was again rendered for defendants.

The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff car dealer appealed a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which ruled in favor of defendants, the motor vehicle dealers' and salesmen's licensing board, the highway director, and the attorney general, in an action brought by the car dealer for declaratory relief prohibiting defendants from limiting his premiums for assignment of installment contracts to financial institutions under Ohio Rev. Code § 1317.08.


OVERVIEW: The car dealer brought a declaratory action against defendants, alleging that § 1317.08 was unconstitutional and deprived him of property without due process of law and to equal protection of the law by limiting his right to contract. He sought an injunction to prohibit defendants from enforcing § 1317.08 against him, which limited the amount of premium that he could receive for the assignment of retail installment contracts to financial institutions. The trial court ruled n favor of defendants and the car dealer appealed. The appellate court held a trial de novo and again found in favor of defendants. The car dealer sought review On review, the court affirmed and ruled that § 1317.08 restriction on the amount of premium that the car dealer could receive was not unconstitutional because its function was substantially related to the valid legislative goal of curbing the dealings between retail dealers and financial institutions that resulted in hidden charges and general fraud on the public. Moreover, § 1317.08 was neither unreasonable nor discriminatory because it did not interfere with the car dealer's business and it affected all retail dealers in the same manner.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed judgment in favor of defendants.

 

233 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Geo. F. Alger Co. v. Bowers


Nos. 35066, 35067


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 427; 143 N.E.2d 835; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 427; 2 Ohio Op. 2d 430



June 19, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

These cases arose from the imposition of the Ohio highway use tax upon appellant, a Michigan corporation engaged in the business of trucking in interstate commerce with trucks licensed in Ohio, Michigan and Indiana.

The orders of the Tax Commissioner assessing the tax were appealed from to the Board of Tax Appeals, which found the assessments reasonable and lawful, and the decisions of the board are now before this court for consideration.



DISPOSITION: Decisions affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a decision from the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed appellee tax commissioner's orders assessing an Ohio highway use tax upon the taxpayer. The board found that the assessments were reasonable and lawful. The tax was imposed upon the taxpayer, a foreign state corporation engaged in a business of trucking in interstate commerce with trucks licensed in three states.


OVERVIEW: The Ohio Highway Use Tax Act, also known as an "axle-mile tax," levied a graduated tax upon trucks, ranging from certain sums per mile for trucks having three or more axles. The taxpayer argued that the tax was unconstitutional. The court stated that the taxpayer's argument should have been directed to the Ohio General Assembly. The court determined that the tax imposed bore a reasonable relationship to a purpose for which it was created, did not impair interstate commerce, and was not discriminatory. The tax was a valid exercise of a taxing power. The court considered a reciprocity board's power, under Ohio Rev. Code § 4503.37, to cancel a reciprocity agreement entered into by the board between Ohio and a foreign state. The board, created by § 4503.37, had the power to cancel the reciprocity agreement entered into with the foreign state. There was no mandatory duty on the board created by Ohio Rev. Code § 5728.15 to require the board to enter into reciprocity agreements. Although the court could have instructed the board that it was required to enter into reciprocity agreements, the agreements required an acquiescence of another state over which the court had no control.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the board's decision and the commissioner's orders.

 

234 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


East Fairfield Coal Co. v. Booth


No. 34929


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 379; 143 N.E.2d 309; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 415; 2 Ohio Op. 2d 289



May 15, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County.

This litigation originated in the form of two actions in the Court of Common Pleas of Mahoning County.

By stipulation of counsel, the two actions were consolidated.

The present plaintiffs are and have been respectively the lessee and the owner of a tract of approximately 135 acres of farm land located on the western edge of Canfield Township in Mahoning County.

One of the defendants is the zoning inspector for the township and the remaining three are the trustees for the township.

The relief sought by the plaintiffs is that the defendants be enjoined from interfering with the removal of minerals underlying the plaintiffs' farm land, and that the court declare unconstitutional a subsequently adopted township zoning ordinance prohibiting strip mining in an agricultural district.

The Court of Common Pleas rendered a decree in favor of the plaintiffs by holding the subsequently adopted township zoning ordinance unconstitutional so far as its operation prohibits the plaintiffs from removing coal from their land by the strip-mining method, and the defendants were enjoined from interfering with such removal of coal by the plaintiffs.

 [***2] The defendants and also the plaintiffs perfected appeals to the Court of Appeals on questions of law and fact. The unanimous decree of that court was similar to the decree of the Court of Common Pleas.

The case is in this court for a review by reason of an appeal by the defendants. The plaintiffs have filed cross-assignments of error.



DISPOSITION: Decree affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated cases defendants, a township zoning inspector and township trustees, appealed a decree of the Court of Appeals (Ohio) in favor of plaintiffs, a lessee and an owner of a tract of farm land, in an action to enjoin defendants from interfering with the removal of minerals underlying their land and that the trial court declare unconstitutional a township zoning ordinance prohibiting strip mining in an agricultural district.


OVERVIEW: Both lower courts held that the subsequently adopted township zoning ordinance insofar as it prohibited plaintiffs from removing coal from their land by strip mining was arbitrary and unreasonable, and deprived plaintiffs of their property without due process of law, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment and Ohio Const. Art. I, §§ 1, 16, and 19. Defendants contended that the decisions of the lowed courts were adverse on the ground that the zoning ordinance was invalid so far as it affected the land of plaintiffs. The court found that minerals underlying plaintiffs' lands had a market value in excess of $ 1,000,000 and the residual value of the lands after removal of the minerals would be about $ 17,000. The minerals could only be removed through strip mining and such operation only constituted a temporary use of the lands. The court held the State of Ohio recognized strip mining as a legitimate business and no township could arbitrarily prohibit the conduct of that business. Accordingly, the court concluded that the ordinance to the extent to which it applied to plaintiffs' land was unreasonable and arbitrary.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decree.

 

235 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Yorkavitz v. Board of Township Trustees


No. 34936


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 349; 142 N.E.2d 655; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 445; 2 Ohio Op. 2d 255



May 8, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lorain County.

Plaintiffs instituted this action in the Court of Common Pleas of Lorain County, praying for a declaratory judgment as to their rights, and that the township trustees of Columbia Township be enjoined from enforcing a certain provision of a zoning resolution adopted by the trustees pursuant to the authorization thereof found in Chapter 519, Revised Code.

The provision of the zoning resolution in question (subdivision 14, section five) is as follows:

"The following uses shall be deemed to constitute a nuisance and shall not be permitted in any 'R,' 'B,' or 'I' districts [the unincorporated territory of the entire township is divided into "R" (residential), "B" (business), or "I" (industrial) districts for the purposes of the zoning resolution]:

"* * *

"14. Aviation fields, landing fields, either for private or public use, runways, airplane hangars, proving or instruction grounds."

Plaintiffs allege that this provision of the resolution is invalid, and that they have the right to establish a commercial aviation field within the township.

Defendants answer that such aviation field will constitute a nuisance and will be a violation [***2] of the zoning resolution.

The Court of Common Pleas found this provision to be unconstitutional and enjoined the township trustees from enforcing it.

On appeal on questions of law and fact, the Court of Appeals for Lorain County found the provision in question to be constitutional and prohibited the plaintiffs from "in any wise conducting an airport of any kind within the limits of Columbia Township."

The cause is before this court on an appeal as of right and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff airport owners appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lorain County (Ohio), which found defendant township trustee's zoning resolution barring the operation of airports to be constitutional, and which prohibited the airport owners from conducting an airport within township limits.


OVERVIEW: The airport owners instituted an action for a declaratory judgment as to their rights, and to enjoin the township trustees from enforcing a certain provision of a zoning resolution adopted by the trustees.
