The trial court found the provision to be unconstitutional and enjoined the township trustees from enforcing it. On appeal. the Court of Appeals for Lorain County found the provision to be constitutional and prohibited the airport owners from conducting an airport of any kind within the township limits. The owners appealed. The court reversed because the General Assembly had indicated that airports were beneficial to the public and were to be promoted and encouraged. In addition, in delegating to township trustees the power to zone it did not include the power to circumvent the general law by completely prohibiting airports, throughout the unincorporated territory of a township, as being nuisances per se. Therefore, the zoning resolution was invalid and unenforceable because it was an unlawful extension of the power delegated to township trustees.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remanded the cause to the trial court.

 

236 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Neff v. Board of County Comm'rs


No. 35116


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 360; 142 N.E.2d 658; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 455; 2 Ohio Op. 2d 261



May 8, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Belmont County.

Plaintiff, a duly elected, qualified and acting justice of the peace of Mead Township, Belmont County, filed his petition in the Common Pleas Court of that county, alleging that the defendant Board of County Commissioners of Belmont County, purporting to act under the provisions of Section 1907.47, Revised Code, fixed the annual salary and expenses of the office held by plaintiff at a total sum of $ 150; that such section is unconstitutional and void in that neither it nor any other section of the Code prescribes any standards or rules governing the exercise of authority stated therein to be delegated to the board; and that the provisions of the statute purport to be of a general nature but cannot have uniform operation throughout the state.

The prayer of the petition is that the section be declared unconstitutional and void, or that so much of the resolution of the board as pertains to plaintiff's salary be set aside and the board be ordered to enter as the annual salary of plaintiff the sum of either $ 3,600 or $ 1,000.

The cause was submitted on an agreed statement of facts. The court held Section 1907.47, Revised Code, to [***2] be unconstitutional and void and entered judgment for plaintiff.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment.

The cause is now before this court on an appeal as of right and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Board of County Commissioners of Belmont County appealed a decision from the Court of Appeals of Belmont County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment of a trial court, which had found in favor of plaintiff justice of the peace. The justice of the peace had brought an action to challenge the validity of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1907.47.


OVERVIEW: The Board fixed the annual salary of the justice of the peace pursuant to § 1907.47. The justice of the peace claimed that § 1907.47 was unconstitutional in that it did not prescribe any standards or rules governing the Board's exercise of authority. The trial court held that § 1907.47 was unconstitutional and entered a judgment in favor of the justice of the peace. The appellate court affirmed the judgment of the trial court. The Board appealed, and the court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court. The court held that justices of the peace were not constitutional courts per Ohio Const. art. IV, § 1 but were created by legislative authority and could have been abolished or their compensation changed at the will of the general assembly per Ohio Const. art. II, § 20 so long as it acted in conformity with constitutional limitations. Justices of the peace were county elective officers and any act of fixing their salaries had to be uniform. The general assembly's act of conferring authority on the Board to fix the justice of the peace's salary was in conflict with Ohio Const. art. II, § 26 because there was no uniform rule for determining compensation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court.

 

237 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Richter Concrete Corp. v. Reading


No. 34933


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 279; 142 N.E.2d 525; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 395; 2 Ohio Op. 2d 169



April 17, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The facts in this case are not in dispute.

On April 21, 1954, the Council of the City of Reading, Ohio, passed an ordinance (No. 918-1954), the pertinent portions of which are as follows:

"Be it ordained by Council of the City of Reading, Ohio, two-thirds of all members elected thereto concurring;

"Section I: That it shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, firm or corporation to operate any vehicle or vehicles on any of the public streets within the boundaries of the city of Reading, Ohio, containing a gross weight, including load, in excess of 20,000 pounds, excepting for the purpose of loading or unloading said vehicles at a residence, place of business or industry within the boundaries of the city of Reading, Ohio, which shall include ordinary deliveries to any of such places, and excepting also for the purpose of traveling to or from a residence, place of business or industry where said vehicle or vehicles are registered or hired and excepting also for the operation of vehicles over Reading Road, a state highway.

"Provided further, that the gross weight, including load of any vehicle or vehicles, shall include the [***2] gross weight of any trailer or trailers attached to any vehicle or vehicles, together with load.

"* * *

"Section III: That this ordinance be, and the same is hereby declared an emergency measure necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health and safety, the reason for the emergency being that vehicles of the type restricted herein are damaging streets and endangering the safe movement of persons and other vehicles. Therefore, this ordinance shall take effect and be in force immediately from and after its passage."

The following October three employees of Richter Concrete Corporation, having its principal place of business in Cincinnati, were arrested while driving concrete mixer trucks on Galbraith Road in the city of Reading and were charged with violating said ordinance. After these arrests, Richter Concrete Corporation, hereinafter called plaintiff, brought an action in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County to enjoin the city of Reading and its mayor from enforcing the provisions of the ordinance against it or its drivers and to have such ordinance declared invalid and unconstitutional. The trucks admittedly weighed in excess of the limit specified.

 [***3] The trial court after final hearing found the ordinance to be valid and accordingly dissolved the temporary restraining order previously allowed and dismissed plaintiff's petition.

On appeal to the Court of Appeals, the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was reversed and final judgment rendered in favor of plaintiff.

The cause is now before this court on an appeal as of right and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant City appealed a decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) that reversed a trial court and ruled that Reading, Ohio, Ordinance 918-1954 (April 21, 1954), violated the Equal Protection Clauses of the U.S. and Ohio Constitutions. After its truckers were arrested for violating the ordinance, plaintiff company obtained a temporary injunction against enforcement by the City. The trial court dissolved the injunction.


OVERVIEW: Under the ordinance, it was unlawful to operate, on any of the City's public streets, a vehicle with a gross weight, in excess of 20,000 pounds, except for the purpose of loading or unloading at a residence or place of business within the City or for travelling to or from a place in the City where the vehicle was registered or hired. There was also an exception for travel over one state highway. The company, which had its principal place of business outside the City, challenged the ordinance after its truckers were arrested while driving concrete mixers, which weighed in excess of the limits, within the City. The court found that the ordinance in effect discriminated between residents and nonresidents engaged in the operation of trucks weighing in excess of 20,000 pounds. The ordinance illegally imposed restrictions on those engaged in through traffic and imposed no such regulations upon those using the streets for other than through traffic, notwithstanding that such traffic imposed the same stress upon the streets and created the same hazards. The ordinance created an arbitrary and discriminate classification in violation of U.S. Const. amend. XIV and Ohio Const. art. I, § 2.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower appellate court that the ordinance was unconstitutional.

 

238 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Clinger v. Duncan


No. 34855


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 216; 141 N.E.2d 156; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 379; 2 Ohio Op. 2d 31



March 13, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

Inez M. Clinger was injured by an automobile owned by Emma G. Lemen. She instituted the present action in the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County against Lemen, hereinafter referred to as defendant, and Ada E. Duncan to recover damages for such injuries upon the claim that their joint negligence was directly responsible therefor. Plaintiff was awarded a verdict and judgment in the trial court against defendant alone, and on appeal on questions of law to the Court of Appeals that judgment was affirmed.

The allowance of a motion to require the Court of Appeals to certify the record brings the cause here for decision on the merits. Additional facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant car owner sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which entered judgment in favor of appellee injured in an action brought by the injured to recover damages for injuries sustained by the owner's automobile.


OVERVIEW: The injured was hurt by the owner's automobile. She instituted an action against the owner and a passenger to recover damages for such injuries upon the claim that their joint negligence was directly responsible therefor. The injured was awarded a verdict and judgment in the trial court against the owner alone. The trial court found that the injured was not a guest at the time of her injuries within the meaning of Ohio Rev. Code § 4515.02, commonly known as the "guest statute." The judgment was affirmed by the court of appeals. Upon review, the court affirmed the judgment. The court found that when the injured left the automobile to summon help, she temporarily, at least, removed herself from the category of one being transported in or upon a motor vehicle and would not have resumed a guest status until she again entered the car. The court stated that the trial court properly applied the rule of ordinary negligence because the injured was not a guest at and immediately before the time she was injured. The court rejected the owner's argument that when the owner got out of her car shortly before the injuries, she placed it under the control and in charge of the passenger.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the injured.

 

239 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Grandle v. Rhodes


No. 35003


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 197; 140 N.E.2d 897; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 450; 2 Ohio Op. 2d 4



March 6, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

ON REHEARING.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff brought a motion for a rehearing of the court's prior opinion, which affirmed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed a trial court judgment in favor of defendant auditor in an action concerning the auditor's use of a highway improvement fund for a parking garage.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff brought a motion for a rehearing of the court's prior opinion in an appeal of an action concerning the auditor's use of a highway improvement fund for a parking garage. The court noted that in its original opinion the majority of the court decided that the use of the contested funds was not for statutory highway purposes. However, the court reversed its former judgment and rendered final judgment for plaintiff because the sole question arose over the defraying of certain preliminary costs of the construction with funds the use of which was restricted by a section of the Ohio Const., art. XII, § 5a. Obviously, the parking garage could be constructed without the use of these funds. The holding of the majority was not a holding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5538.01 et seq. was unconstitutional, but rather it was a holding that the use of the funds was not, within the meaning of Ohio Const., art. XII, § 5a for statutory highway purposes. Therefore, the highway improvement fund was not described by the statutory words any funds available for the purpose.


OUTCOME: The court rescinded its former judgment, reversed the judgment of the appellate court, and rendered final judgment for plaintiff.

 

240 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Reiss v. Columbus Municipal Court


No. 34942


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 178; 140 N.E.2d 787; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 372; 1 Ohio Op. 2d 463



February 27, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The appellants who live in the city of Columbus instituted in the Court of Appeals an action in prohibition against the Columbus Municipal Court and the city attorney. They allege in their petition that affidavits were filed against them in the Columbus Municipal Court charging them with violating a Columbus pedestrian-traffic regulation; that warrants for their arrest were issued in bad faith; that the traffic regulation which they were charged with violating is illegal and in violation of the state Uniform Traffic Act and the ordinances of the city of Columbus; that their cases are pending in the Columbus Municpal Court; that such court has no jurisdiction of the cases; that the Municipal Court Act, as amended, giving the Columbus Municipal Court county-wide jurisdiction, created an illegal and unconstitutional court; that the city attorney seeks to usurp the duties of prosecuting attorney; and that his acts in the prosecution of criminal cases are unlawful and illegal. The prayer is that the Municipal Court and the city attorney be prohibited from proceeding any further with appellants' cases or from entering final judgments [***2] therein.

Appellees demurred to the petition for the reason that the petition does not state facts which show a cause of action.

The Court of Appeals sustained the demurrers.

An appeal as of right brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

241 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Allied Stores of Ohio, Inc. v. Bowers


No. 34926


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 116; 140 N.E.2d 411; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 454; 1 Ohio Op. 2d 342



January 30, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Allied Stores of Ohio, Inc., herein referred to as the taxpayer, is an Ohio corporation. In an appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals from a final order of the Tax Commissioner, the taxpayer contended that the Tax Commissioner had erroneously assessed for taxation for the year 1954 certain "merchandise * * * held in a storage warehouse for storage only" within the meaning of those words as used in Section 5701.08, Revised Code, in effect prior to September 30, 1955, and that the statutes of Ohio were unconstitutional to the extent that they purported to levy a tax on such property not "belonging to a nonresident of" Ohio, in that they denied a resident such as the taxpayer the protection of the laws equal to that enjoyed by a nonresident. See Little v. Smith, Atty. Genl., 124 Kan., 237, 257 P., 959, 57 A. L. R., 100; Colgate v. Harvey, 296 U.S., 404, 102 A. L. R., 54.

Section 5709.01, Revised Code, reads so far as pertinent:

"* * * All personal property located and used in business in this state * * * are subject to taxation, regardless of the residence of the owners thereof."

Section 5701.08, Revised Code, prior [***2] to September 30, 1955, read so far as pertinent:

"(A) Personal property is 'used' within the meaning of 'used in business' * * * when acquired or held as means or instruments for carrying on the business * * * or when stored or kept on hand as material, parts, products, or merchandise; but merchandise or agricultural products belonging to a nonresident of this state is [are] not used in business in this state if held in a storage warehouse for storage only."

In its final entry, the Board of Tax Appeals stated in part:

"The only real point of difference between the present case and that of the Goodrich case * * * [161 Ohio St., 202, 118 N. E. (2d), 525] lies in that appellant is a domestic, or an Ohio corporation, engaged exclusively in merchandising, while the Goodrich company is a nonresident manufacturing corporation. * * *

"Since appellant's principal query concerns a matter of discrimination and the constitutionality of Revised Code Section 5701.08 * * *, matters over which this board is without jurisdiction to consider, this board can do nothing else but to affirm the Tax Commissioner's order as made * * *."

In affirming the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals,  [***3] the Court of Appeals stated in part:

"The positive statement in Section 5701.08, Revised Code, that 'products belonging to a nonresident of this state is not used in business in this state if held in a storage warehouse for storage only' is not an arbitrary or artificial classification and is within the right and power of the Legislature to declare. See City of Xenia v. Schmidt, 101 Ohio St., 437 [130 N. E., 24]; Travelers' Ins. Co. v. Connecticut, 185 U.S., 364. Goodrich Co. v. Peck, 161 Ohio St., 202 [118 N. E. (2d), 525], in effect so holds."

The cause is now before this court on appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals as a case involving a debatable constitutional question and pursuant to allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) affirmed a decision of the Ohio Board of Tax Appeals, which affirmed a final order of appellee tax commissioner imposing a tax upon certain merchandise held by appellant corporation in a storage warehouse. The corporation filed a motion for certification of the record, and the appellate court granted the motion.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner assessed the merchandise pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5709.01, which provided that all personal property located and used in business in Ohio was subject to taxation, regardless of the residence of the owner of the property. The corporation objected to the assessment of the tax on equal protection grounds, claiming that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5701.08, which provided, in part, that merchandise owned by a nonresident was not "used in business" in Ohio if was being held in a warehouse for storage only, discriminated against residents in favor of nonresidents. The Board affirmed the commissioner's order, and the appellate court affirmed the Board's decision. The court affirmed, concluding that even if the allegedly discriminatory language was deemed to be unconstitutional, the corporation would not be entitled to relief because the court could not simply strike the offending language therefrom, but would be required to strike the provision in its entirety, and if the provision were stricken in its entirety, the property in question would remain subject to taxation under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5709.01.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

242 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Bowers


Nos. 34868, 34872


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 122; 140 N.E.2d 313; 1957 Ohio LEXIS 359; 1 Ohio Op. 2d 345



January 30, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The Youngstown Sheet & Tube Company, herein referred to as the taxpayer, is an Ohio corporation. In its 1954 return, it eliminated from the average value of its reported manufacturing inventories certain inventories of property owned by it and held in various storage places in Ohio. The Tax Commissioner in his final order found these withheld inventories to be taxable. Furthermore, the Tax Commissioner in that order made no deduction from the tax base of any amount on account of "drawings" which the taxpayer claimed to be exempt from taxation.

On appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals, that board affirmed the order of the Tax Commissioner so far as it related to the "drawings." With respect to the property held in storage, the taxpayer had contended that that provision of Section 5701.08, Revised Code, which, prior to September 30, 1955, read, "but merchandise * * * belonging to a nonresident of this state is not used in business in this state if held in a storage warehouse for storage only," should have stricken therefrom the words "belonging to a nonresident of this state" for the reason that those words made such provision unconstitutional [***2] and that such provision when so revised excepted such property from taxation. The Board of Tax Appeals determined that it had no power to determine that any part of Section 5701.08, Revised Code, was unconstitutional and that it was therefore bound to render its decision in accordance with the provisions of that statute as it found them.

The taxpayer further contended that certain iron ores imported by it from foreign countries were exempt from taxation by reason of the provisions of Clause 2 of Section 10 of Article I of the Constitution of the United States. This contention was sustained by the Board of Tax Appeals.

The cause is now before this court on appeals by the Tax Commissioner and by the taxpayer from the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgments accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed the order of the Ohio Tax Commissioner as it made no deduction from the tax base of any amount on account of "drawings" which the taxpayer claimed to be exempt from taxation.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer further contended that certain iron ores imported by it from foreign countries were exempt from taxation by reason of the provisions of U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, cl. 2. That contention was sustained by the Ohio Board of Tax Appeals. The court ruled that the drawings were exempt under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5701.03. The taxpayer's evidence as to the value of "drawings" was largely evidence as to the cost of drawings and specifications. The evidence in the record did not require the conclusion as a matter of law that the specifications referred to in the evidence of cost were part of the drawings. The court found that the evidence did show conclusively that there were a very substantial number of drawings. Also, there was evidence disclosing that both the cost of such things as some of the "tracings, blueprints and supplies" and also the charges for some of the "detail draftsmen and tracers" amounted to several thousands of dollars.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the case except to the extent that it related to the claimed deduction from the tax base on account of "drawings," and the cause was remanded to the Board for further proceedings.

 

243 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Grandle v. Rhodes


No. 35003


Supreme Court of Ohio


166 Ohio St. 108; 139 N.E.2d 328; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 435; 1 Ohio Op. 2d 225



December 26, 1956, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] For opinion on rehearing see post, 197.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Plaintiff seeks to enjoin the expenditure of money from the Highway Improvement Fund for defraying the cost of certain preliminary studies relative to the construction of a parking lot under the Statehouse grounds in Columbus.

Plaintiff alleges in his petition that Section 5538.17, Revised Code, provides in part that, with the approval of the Underground Parking Commission, the Director of Highways shall expend out of any funds available for the purpose such moneys as are necessary for the study of any underground parking lot; that pursuant thereto the commission, acting through the director, has contracted for certain engineering studies and surveys in connection with the proposed underground parking lot and has authorized the director to expend from the Highway Improvement Fund $ 64,500 for paying the cost of studies and surveys; that the Highway Improvement Fund is made up of revenues derived from taxes collected on the sale of gasoline used for propelling motor vehicles on the highways of the state; that such use of the fund does not constitute expenditure for the costs of administration [***2] of laws concerning the registration, operation and use of vehicles on public highways, statutory refunds and adjustments provided in such laws, payment of highway obligations, costs of construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of public highways and other statutory highway purposes, etc.; and that unless restrained the auditor will expend portions of the Highway Improvement Fund to pay vouchers relative to engineering studies and surveys in connection with the proposed underground parking lot.

The prayer is that the auditor be enjoined from expending any sums from the Highway Improvement Fund or from spending any money, derived from fees, excises and license taxes relating to registration, operation and use of vehicles on public highways and to fuels used for propelling such vehicles, for the purpose of paying any part of the cost of engineering studies or surveys in connection with the underground parking lot.

Defendant filed a demurrer to the petition on the ground that it does not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.

The trial court sustained the demurrer, and, plaintiff not desiring to plead further, rendered judgment for defendant.

The Court of [***3] Appeals affirmed the judgment.

The allowance of a motion to certify the record brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment of the trial court, which sustained a demurrer brought by defendant auditor and rendered judgment in the auditor's favor in an action brought by plaintiff to enjoin the auditor from using money from a highway improvement fund for constructing a parking lot under statehouse grounds.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff sought to enjoin the expenditure of money from the highway improvement fund for defraying the cost of certain preliminary studies relative to the construction of a parking lot under the statehouse grounds. The prayer was that the auditor be enjoined from expending any sums from the fund or taxes in connection with the underground parking lot. The auditor filed a demurrer to the petition on the ground that it did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action. The trial court sustained the demurrer and rendered judgment for the auditor. The appellate court affirmed, and plaintiff appealed. The court affirmed because Ohio Const. art. XII, § 5a did not forbid the expenditure from revenues derived from the motor vehicle fuel excise tax for studies and surveys for the underground parking lot, for which provision was made in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5538.17. The court reasoned that a purpose of providing parking space on a highway would appear to be no more a highway purpose than a purpose of providing necessary parking space off the highway.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

244 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Michaels v. Morse


No. 34765


Supreme Court of Ohio


165 Ohio St. 599; 138 N.E.2d 660; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 571; 60 Ohio Op. 531; 60 Ohio Op. 2d 531



December 5, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator appealed from a decision by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which denied relator's writ of mandamus to compel respondent Industrial Commission to hear and determine relator's claim for compensation.


OVERVIEW: Relator had brought an action in mandamus for an order to compel the Commission to proceed to hear and determine relator's claim for compensation pursuant to the statutory provisions that were in effect prior to October 5, 1955. On that date, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4123.512 to 4123.519, were to become effective, and no provision was made that required the Commission to complete the rehearing proceedings. The court found that relator's claim had been filed on August 10, 1954, and disallowed on January 4, 1955. On September 8, 1955, the Commission found that it had authority under the existing law to grant relator's request for a hearing but that there was insufficient time to permit relator to complete the case, and for the Commission to hear and determine it, prior to October 5, 1955. The Commission ordered that relator's claim would, on and after October 5, 1955, be deemed to be pending before the Commission on appeal as provided for by the new sections. The court found that the new statute was constitutional because the new statute still applied to certain pending proceedings before the Commission, which included relator's claim.


OUTCOME: The judgment that denied relator's writ of mandamus was affirmed.

 

245 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Ethell v. Hendricks


No. 34422


Supreme Court of Ohio


165 Ohio St. 217; 135 N.E.2d 362; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 478; 59 Ohio Op. 298



May 9, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hancock County.

This cause originated in the Court of Appeals for Hancock County with the filing by relator of a petition in quo warranto praying that respondent "be required to show by what warrant he claims to have, use, exercise and enjoy" the office of chief of police of the city of Findlay.

The cause was submitted to that court for decision upon an agreed statement of facts which disclosed that in 1953 the civil service commission of Findlay adopted a rule that examinations in the civil service in that city should consist of a written examination and an oral examination with a 75 per cent weight being given to the written examination and a 25 per cent weight given to the oral examination; that on or about November 2, 1954, a vacancy arose in the office of the chief of police of that city; that thereafter the civil service commission of the city "posted * * * a notice of examination" to fill that vacancy which stated that "75 per cent of said examination would be written and 25 per cent of the examination would be oral and interview"; that on December 1, 1954, said commission "gave a written, competitive examination to fill the vacancy" in [***2] said office; that on December 3, 1954, the civil service commission "did give, to relator and respondent, along with three other participants in said written examination, an oral examination"; that in grading the examination a 75 per cent weight was given to the written part of the examination and a 25 per cent weight was given to the oral part of the examination and the resulting grades were then, pursuant to the rules and regulations of the commission, multiplied by 0.9, and there was then added thereto by reason of Section 143.16, Revised Code, a seniority credit of 10 for relator and of 6.4 for respondent; that, upon completion of these examinations and the computation of grades, the commission certified to the mayor that respondent had received the highest rating and the mayor promoted respondent to the office of chief of police of the city; and that relator's grade on the written portion of said examination, including his credit for service in the police department, was the highest grade obtained by any person on that part of the examination but the grade of respondent which was the basis of his certification by the commission to the mayor was higher than that of relator solely [***3] because of the greater percentage received by respondent on the oral part of the examination.

Neither party has contended that any charter or ordinance provision should be considered in the determination of this cause. The applicable statutes so far as pertinent read:

 Section 143.16, Revised Code (formerly Section 486-10, General Code).

"All applicants for positions and places in the classified service shall be subject to examination which shall be public, and open to all, within certain limitations to be determined by the commission, as to citizenship, residence, age, sex, experience, health, habit, and moral character; provided any soldier * * * who has been honorably discharged * * * and is a resident of Ohio, may file with the commission a certificate of service and honorable discharge, whereupon he shall receive additional credit of 20 per cent of his total grade given in the regular examination in which he receives a passing grade. Such examination shall be practical in character, shall be written, or written and oral, as the commission determines, and shall relate directly to those matters which will fairly test the relative capacity of the person examined to discharge [***4] the particular duties of the position for which appointment is sought. When appropriate, such examination may include physical examinations by a licensed physician, and where the examination is for a position requiring unusual and particular skill, it may include a test of manual skill.

"Applicants taking promotion examinations, which shall be in writing, shall receive credit for seniority, which shall be determined as follows: One per cent of the total grade attainabe in such examination for each of the first four years of service, and six-tenths per cent of such total grade for each of the next ten years of service. The state Civil Service Commission shall have control of all examinations, except as otherwise provided in Sections 143.01 to 143.48, inclusive, of the Revised Code. No questions in any examination shall relate to political or religious opinions or affiliations.

"Reasonable notice of the time, place, and general scope of every competitive examination for appointment to a position in the civil service, except as otherwise provided in such sections, shall be given by the commission. Written or printed notices of every examination of the state classified [***5] service shall be sent * * *." (Emphasis added.)

 Section 143.24, Revised Code (formerly Section 486-15, General Code).

"Vacancies in positions in the classified service shall be filled in so far as practicable by promotions. The commission shall provide in its rules for keeping a record of efficiency for each employee in the classified service, and for making promotions in the classified service on the basis of merit, to be ascertained as far as practicable by promotional examinations, by conduct and capacity in office, and by seniority in service, and shall provide that vacancies shall be filled by promotion in all cases where, in the judgment of the commission, it is for the best interest of the service. All examinations for promotions shall be competitive. In promotional examinations, efficiency and seniority in service shall form a part of the maximum mark attainable in such examination. In all cases where vacancies are to be filled by promotion, the commission shall certify to the appointing authority only the name of the person having the highest rating. The method of examination for promotions, the manner of giving notice thereof, and the rules governing [***6] the same shall be in general the same as those provided for original examinations, except as otherwise provided in Sections 143.01 to 143.48, inclusive, of the Revised Code." (Emphasis added.)

 Section 143.30, Revised Code (formerly Section 486-19, General Code).

"* * * all authority granted to the state Civil Service Commission with respect to the service under its jurisdiction shall, except as otherwise provided by Sections 143.01 to 143.48, inclusive, of the Revised Code, be held to grant the same authority to the municipal civil service commission with respect to the service under its jurisdiction. * * *"

 Section 143.34, Revised Code (formerly Section 486-15a, General Code).

"* * * No position above the rank of patrolman or regular fireman in a police or fire department shall be filled by any person unless he has first passed a competitive promotional examination. * * * Whenever a vacancy occurs in a position above the rank of patrolman or fireman in a police or fire department, and there is no eligible list for such rank, the municipal civil service commission shall, within 60 days of such vacancy, hold a competitive promotional examination. After such [***7] examination has been held and an eligible list established, the commission shall forthwith certify to the appointing officer the name of the person receiving the highest rating. Upon such certification, the appointing officer shall appoint the person so certified within 30 days from the date of such certification. * * *" (Emphasis added.)

The Court of Appeals held that the civil service commission of the city "was without authority to adopt a rule to provide for an oral examination in addition to the written examination," and that, since the relator's grade on the written portion of the examination, including his credit for service, was the highest grade obtained by any person taking that portion of the examination, the relator was entitled to certification for appointment to fill the vacancy in the office of chief of police and the respondent was unlawfully holding that office. The judgment of the court thereupon ordered the ouster of respondent from that office and ordered that relator be certified and appointed to fill that vacancy.

The cause is now before this court on appeal from that judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed  [***8] in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant individual sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hancock County (Ohio), which ordered his ouster from the office of chief of police and ordered that appellee relator be certified and appointed to fill that vacancy.


OVERVIEW: The civil service commission (Commission) of the city adopted a rule that examinations in the civil service should consist of a written examination and an oral examination with a 75 percent weight being given to the written examination and a 25 percent weight given to the oral examination. A vacancy later arose in the office of the chief of police. Subsequently, the Commission gave a written, competitive examination to fill the vacancy in said office to the individual, the relator, and three other participants. The individual received the highest rating and the mayor promoted him to the office. The relator's grade on the written portion of the examination was the highest obtained by any person on the written portion of the examination. He filed an action against the individual, and the lower court ordered his ouster from the office of chief of police and ordered that the relator be certified and appointed to fill that vacancy. The court affirmed in part the judgment, by holding that the certification of the individual was unlawful because it was based upon the result of a promotional examination that was not authorized by law, as it was not an exclusively written examination.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part and reversed in part the judgment, which ordered the individual's ouster from the office of chief of police and ordered that the relator be certified and appointed to fill that vacancy.

 

246 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Bouse v. Cickelli


No. 34757


Supreme Court of Ohio


165 Ohio St. 191; 134 N.E.2d 834; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 473; 59 Ohio Op. 261



April 25, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Relator voted the Republican ballot in the May 1952 primary election but did not vote in the general election of that year. In February 1954, relator filed a declaration of candidacy and nominating petition as a Democrat for Representative to Congress for the primary election to be held in May 1954; such declaration and petition was rejected by the Board of Elections of Trumbull County for the reason that he registered and voted as a Republican in 1952; and the Court of Appeals, in a mandamus action brought by relator, held that he was ineligible to be a Democratic candidate for the office in the May 1954 primary election. He voted the Democratic ballot in the May 1954 primary.

On February 8, 1956, relator filed with the board of elections his declaration of candidacy and petition for nomination as a candidate of the Democratic Party for the office of Representative to Congress from the Eleventh Congressional District, containing the requisite number of signatures and duly verified. The board refused to have relator's name placed on the Democratic Party ballot for the May 1956 primary election for the reason that relator had voted as a member of a different political [***2] party at a primary election held within the next preceding four calendar years.

By the instant action in mandamus, originating in this court, relator seeks a writ requiring the board to certify to the board of elections of each county within the district that relator is entitled to have his name appear on the Democratic primary ballot.

The case is submitted on the petition and the answer filed thereto.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator candidate sought mandamus relief to compel respondent county board of elections to place his name on a Democratic primary ballot for a Congressional seat.


OVERVIEW: The candidate voted in the Republican primary. Before the next election, he filed a declaration of candidacy and nominating petition as a Democrat to run for a congressional seat. The county board of elections rejected his declaration and petition. In a prior mandamus action, it was held that he could not run as a Democrat in that election. He voted as a Democrat in that primary. Then for the following election, he again presented a petition for nomination and declaration of candidacy. The board of elections again rejected his petition and declaration and again he sought mandamus relief. Again his petition for mandamus relief was denied. The court held that under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3513.191 as amended, he could not be a candidate for nomination for one party if he had voted as a member of another party in any primary election within the preceding four calendar years. It did not matter that under the pre-amendment § 3513.191, he would have qualified to be a candidate. The amended statute was a valid exercise of police power and was not invalid retroactive legislation. Further, as the candidate had no vested right in an existing statute, amending it took away no rights from him.


OUTCOME: The court denied mandamus relief to the candidate.

 

247 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Humphrys v. Winous Co.


No. 34485


Supreme Court of Ohio


165 Ohio St. 45; 133 N.E.2d 780; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 446; 59 Ohio Op. 65



March 14, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellants Putnam and Andrews are directors and majority shareholders of The Winous Company and own between them approximately 59 per cent of the stock of the corporation. Appellee Humphrys controls approximately 40 per cent of the stock and for several years prior to the annual meeting of the shareholders of the corporation on January 18, 1954, had been a director of the corporation.

Having failed to give notice of his election to vote cumulatively at the annual meeting on January 18, 1954, as required by Section 1701.58, Revised Code, Humphrys was not re-elected to the board of directors and was replaced on the board by one Anthony.

Following this election of directors, the annual meeting of the corporation was adjourned, at about noon on January 18, until certain financial statements requested by Humphrys could be typed for presentation. Upon reconvening at about 2:30 p. m. on January 18, the shareholders adopted a resolution amending the code of regulations and providing that each director, after the election at that meeting, shall hold office for three years, and that the three directorships shall be designated by classes [***2] as follows: Class A director shall hold office for one year and thereafter for three years; class B director for two years and thereafter for three years; and class C director for three years and thereafter for three years. The shareholders then adopted a resolution which "designated and appointed" Anthony as the first class A director, appellant Andrews as the first class B director and appellant Putnam as the first class C director.

Appellees filed a petition for declaratory judgment and equitable relief in the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County praying for a declaration of the invalidity of the amendment to the code of regulations of the company and the consequent election of directors by classes. The Court of Common Pleas held that, although under Section 1701.64, Revised Code, it was within the power of the majority of the shareholders to classify their three directors in the manner undertaken, the notice of the annual meeting was insufficient to permit such classification at that meeting. It, therefore, held that the three directors, having been duly elected for terms of one year, should continue in office during the remainder of such period.

Humphrys perfected an appeal [***3] to the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County on questions of law, which court held as follows:

"That the Court of Common Pleas should have rendered final judgment for the plaintiffs appellants for the reason that where three directors are provided for with three-year terms of office, one to be elected each year, the right to cumulative voting is, in such case, completely nullified, and such amendment to the code of regulations for the classification of directors is null and void, being a violation of the terms of Section 1701.58, R. C.; that the resolution seeking to designate each of the directors already duly elected on the morning of January 18, 1954, to different respective classes was consequently also invalid; that the provisions of Section 1701.58, R. C., prohibiting the restriction or qualification of cumulative voting is specific in character and constitutes a limitation upon the applicability of Section 1701.64, R. C.; and this court coming now to render the judgment which the Court of Common Pleas ought to have rendered, it is therefore considered, ordered and adjudged by this court that the attempted classification of directors by the purported amendment of the code of [***4] regulations of The Winous Company is null and void, and that the resolution seeking to designate each of the directors already duly elected on the morning of January 18, 1954, to different respective classes is invalid."

The cause is before this court upon the allowance of appellants' motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the directors and the majority shareholders, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which reversed a lower court ruling against appellee minority shareholders by finding that classification of directors by an amendment of the corporate code of regulations was null and void and that the resolution seeking reclassify each of the directors already elected was invalid.


OVERVIEW: Minority shareholder was not re-elected to the board of directors after he failed to give notice of his election to vote cumulatively at an annual meeting. At the meeting, the shareholders adopted a resolution amending the code of regulations and providing that each director, after election at that meeting, would hold office for three years and that three classes of directorships were designated so as to stagger the classes' terms. The shareholder then designated the newly elected directors into classes. Minority shareholders filed a petition for declaratory judgment and equitable relief that was granted on grounds that the notice of the annual meeting was insufficient to permit such classification at that meeting. The appellate court found that such action by the shareholders nullified the right to cumulative voting. On appeal, the court held that Ohio Rev. Code § 1701.58 guaranteed to minority shareholders the right of cumulative voting and that the notice of the meeting was proper.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appeals court, modified the lower court's decision with regard to sufficiency of the annual meeting notice, and affirmed the lower court as modified.

 

248 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Church v. Brown


No. 34624


Supreme Court of Ohio


165 Ohio St. 31; 133 N.E.2d 333; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 444; 59 Ohio Op. 45



March 7, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

ON DEMURRER to petition.

The relators have invoked the original jurisdiction of this court for the purpose of obtaining a writ of mandamus to require the respondent Secretary of State to accept for filing and recording articles of incorporation of a proposed nonprofit corporation to be known as "National Nudist Council, Inc."

Relators allege in their amended petition that they "all are adults of legal age and under no disability"; that they have devoted many years of work to the furtherance of the nudist movement in this country, motivated by a desire to serve this cause; that to relators and other sincere adherents nudism is a religion; that all nudist groups maintain strict and high moral standards and seek constantly to improve physical and mental health; that it is relators' desire and they believe their inherent right to practice nudism within the state of Ohio, to conduct a program of general education and information in explanation of the movement, to attempt to convert the public to their point of view and to form nudist clubs; and that relators believe a nonprofit corporation to be the most effective organization for their purposes.

Relators allege further [***2] that they have tendered to respondent articles of incorporation for the proposed nonprofit corporation, with the necessary filing fee and with the request that they be accepted for filing and recording, and that respondent refuses to comply with the request.

The prayer is for a writ requiring respondent to accept for filing and recording the articles of incorporation, and that he be required to perform all acts which it is his duty to do in connection with the incorporation of such proposed corporation.

To this petition respondent has filed a demurrer on the ground that the amended petition does not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.



DISPOSITION: Demurrer sustained and writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator nudists invoked the court's original jurisdiction for the purpose of obtaining a writ of mandamus to require respondent the Secretary of State to accept for filing and recording articles of incorporation for the proposed nonprofit corporation known as National Nudist Council, Inc.


OVERVIEW: The nudists sought to have their group incorporated. They submitted the required documents and the required fee, but their request for incorporation was denied by the secretary. The nudists filed an action before the court seeking a writ of mandamus to compel the secretary to accept their documents and incorporate their group. The court noted that the proposed corporate purpose of the nudists violated Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2905.31 in that it necessitated the exposure of private parts in the presence of two or more persons of the opposite sex. The court additionally noted that a corporation could not have been formed for an unlawful purpose. The nudists argued, however, that § 2905.31 was unconstitutional. The court held that § 2905.31 was a valid exercise of the state's police power to prevent the practice of nudism regardless of the belief of those desiring to practice it as a doctrine of life, cult, or sect. Therefore, the nudists failed to show by their petition a clear legal right to the relief prayed for, and the writ was denied.


OUTCOME: The secretary's demurrer was sustained, and the request for a writ of mandamus was denied.

 

249 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Morgan


Nos. 34311, 34361


Supreme Court of Ohio


164 Ohio St. 529; 133 N.E.2d 104; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 601; 58 Ohio Op. 411



February 23, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

In cause No. 34311, appellant Anna H. Morgan, hereinafter called appellant, pursuant to subpoena, appeared before the Ohio Un-American Activities Commission at a hearing held by it in Columbus, Ohio, on April 1, 1952.

After being sworn, appellant refused to answer substantially each and every question propounded to her, "under the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution, because to do so would give your committee an opportunity to incriminate me."

Subsequently, on May 21, 1952, appellant was indicted under Section 12845, General Code ( Section 2917.42, Revised Code), for her refusal to answer 37 of the questions so propounded.

Her demurrer to the indictment, filed October 25, 1952, having been overruled, appellant, in writing, waived her right to trial by jury, and the cause was tried before a judge of the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County on November 16, 1953.

At the trial the state called as witnesses Gordon Renner, Samuel L. Devine and Edwin H. Hammock.

The first two witnesses are attorneys at law who were members of the 99th General Assembly and the Ohio Un-American [***2] Activities Commission, Renner being the elected chairman and Devine the elected secretary thereof, and both were present at the hearing at which appellant appeared.

Hammock is a court stenographer who was employed by the commission and who recorded the hearing out of which the indictment and trial here under consideration arose.

These witnesses were, of course, subjected to cross-examination. Other than this, however, there was neither testimony nor evidence offered by appellant, she apparently being content to rely upon the validity of either her earlier attack upon jurisdiction by demurrer or her motion for a directed verdict of acquittal duly made at the close of the trial.

The only item of physical evidence in the record is a copy of a subpoena which purports to be a copy of the subpoena duly served upon appellant and by virtue of which she appeared before the commission. It was introduced by the state and its validity is not questioned.

The trial court sustained appellant's motion for a directed verdict of acquittal upon five counts of the indictment, finding that the questions therein included were either not pertinent to the matter under inquiry by the commission or were [***3] repetitious of other questions as to the indictment, overruled said motion with respect to the remaining counts, found appellant guilty thereon and imposed sentence.

The Court of Appeals for Franklin County affirmed the judgment of the trial court, and the cause is before this court both as an appeal of right and by the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.

In cause No. 34361, appellants Raley, Stern and Brown, hereinafter called defendants, pursuant to subpoena, appeared before the Ohio Un-American Activities Commission at a hearing held by it in Cincinnati, Ohio, on October 20, 1952.

Upon the refusal of each to answer certain questions propounded to him, on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate him, the commission, in compliance with the provisions of Section 76-32, General Code ( Section 103.35, Revised Code), caused proceedings in contempt to be prosecuted in the Common Pleas Court of Hamilton County.

Separate indictments were returned by the Grand Jury of Hamilton County, charging defendants with specified violations of Section 12137, General Code ( Section 2705.02, Revised Code).

By agreement defendants were tried together before a judge of the [***4] Court of Common Pleas, after having individually waived in writing the right to trial by jury.

The trial court found each defendant guilty of contempt as charged in all counts of each indictment, and proceeded to impose sentence.

On appeal to the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, the causes were consolidated, and that court affirmed in part and reversed in part the judgments of the trial court; and the cause is before this court both as an appeal of right and by the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated cases, defendants appealed judgments of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County and the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgments that found them guilty of contempt for refusing to answer certain questions propounded at the Ohio Un-American Activities Commission.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were called before the Ohio Un-American Activities Commission to give testimony. They refused to answer certain questions under the protection afforded by the Fifth Amendment. Defendants were indicted under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2917.42 and 2705.02 and held in contempt under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 103.35. Defendants were found guilty of contempt. The court affirmed defendants' convictions, determining that the general assembly had the power to create the Ohio Un-American Activities Commission under Ohio Const. art. II, § 8 for investigative purposes. One defendant invoked a privilege under the protection against self-incrimination afforded her by Ohio Const. art. I, §10. The immunity from prosecution granted defendants by the state concerning any of the matters to which they might have testified afforded them as much protection from self-incrimination as the Ohio Constitution, and a refusal to answer on the attempted invocation of the privilege against self-incrimination was unavailable by virtue of the immunity granted. A direction by the Commission to answer after the refusal was unnecessary because the immunity precluded the possibility of justifying a refusal.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments of the trial court.

 

250 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Sloan


No. 34417


Supreme Court of Ohio


164 Ohio St. 579; 132 N.E.2d 460; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 605; 58 Ohio Op. 438



February 23, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Scioto County.

This is an appeal from a judgment of the Court of Appeals reversing a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas and entering final judgment against the appellant defendants. The action is one wherein the state of Ohio is attempting to enforce a personal liability of the sellers and purchasers of a business for sales taxes accrued during the operation of the business by the sellers.

The pertinent facts are as follows.

For some time prior to March 1946, M. L. Sloan and Kelsie Goodman operated a business known as the Corner Lunch. In March 1946 such business was sold to appellants, Leonard and Clara Lowe, and the record reveals that no discussion was had or any provision made for the payment of sales taxes which had accrued during the operation of the business by the sellers. On June 18, 1946, a sales tax assessment was made against Sloan and Goodman by the Department of Taxation.

On June 24, 1949, the state instituted an action to recover such taxes and joined M. L. Sloan, Kelsie Goodman, Leonard Lowe and Clara Lowe as defendants.

The defendants Sloan and Goodman filed no answer and made no appearance and judgment by default was [***2] entered against them. The appellants filed an answer. In the trial of the case the state proved the prior ownership of the business, the sale thereof to appellants and the failure to provide for the payment of the accrued sales taxes at the time of the sale; and, to prove the amount due, the state introduced into evidence the certificate of assessment of the taxes made against Sloan and Goodman. The appellants introduced no evidence but contended that the certified copy of the findings of the Department of Taxation was insufficient to establish the correct amount of the taxes, and if it was sufficient then Section 5546-9b, General Code ( Section 5739.14, Revised Code), was unconstitutional.

The trial court, upon the motion of appellants on the ground that the state had failed to prove facts sufficient to make a case, dismissed the petition as to appellants.

On appeal to the Court of Appeals, the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was reversed and final judgment was entered against the appellants.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the purchasers of a business, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Scioto County (Ohio), which reversed the judgment of the trial court and found in favor of appellee State of Ohio in the State's action to enforce personal liability of the purchasers for sales taxes accrued during the operation of the business by the sellers.


OVERVIEW: When the sellers sold the business to the purchasers, no discussion was had or any provision made for the payment of sales taxes which had accrued during the operation of the business by the sellers. The Ohio Department of Taxation subsequently assessed sales tax against the sellers. The trial court found that the State had failed to prove facts sufficient to make a case. The court of appeals reversed and final judgment was entered against the purchasers. On further appeal, the purchasers contended, inter alia, that even if a certificate of assessment was prima facie evidence of the amount of taxes due, they were denied due process because they had no notice, were not parties, and had no opportunity to be heard in the proceeding in which assessment was made. In affirming the judgment of the trial court, the court found that the purchasers were liable for the sales taxes because of their lack of due diligence under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5739.14. The certificate of assessment was prima facie evidence of the amount due in taxes from the purchasers. Due process requirements were met because the purchasers had complete notice and an adequate opportunity to be heard in the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

251 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Heine v. Busher


No. 34501


Supreme Court of Ohio


164 Ohio St. 519; 132 N.E.2d 459; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 596; 58 Ohio Op. 386



February 15, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The appellant, Gladies B. Heine, instituted in the Court of Appeals an action in prohibition against the Chief Justice of the Cleveland Municipal Court. She alleges in her petition that she is a licensed minister of the New Thought Temple in Cleveland; that two affidavits were filed against her in the Cleveland Municipal Court, based on Section 4731.34, Revised Code, charging her with the illegal practice of medicine; that Section 4731.34 is unconstitutional; that its constitutionality was attacked by appellant in the Municipal Court; that the unconstitutionality of the statute deprives the Municipal Court of jurisdiction; and that the Court of Appeals should immediately take jurisdiction and determine whether the statute is constitutional without exposing appellant to the hardship of a long and expensive trial. The prayer is that an order be issued prohibiting the judges of the Cleveland Municipal Court from proceeding to hear and determine the action therein pending against appellant.

The answer alleges that appellant appeared generally in the Municipal Court and, by counsel, requested a bill of particulars and demurred to [***2] the affidavits without reservation; that the offenses complained of were misdemeanors occurring in the city of Cleveland; that the Municipal Court has jurisdiction; and that appellant has a full and adequate remedy at law by appeal.

The Court of Appeals found that appellant "has a plain, adequate, existing remedy at law," and denied the writ.

An appeal as of right brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

252 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Giordano


No. 34604


Supreme Court of Ohio


164 Ohio St. 509; 132 N.E.2d 211; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 594; 58 Ohio Op. 353



February 8, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN HABEAS CORPUS.

The petitioner herein, Joseph Giordano, instituted in this court a proceeding in habeas corpus, seeking discharge from the custody of the Warden of the Ohio Penitentiary.

It appears from the petition that in 1934, in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, petitioner was convicted of burglary after a plea of guilty; that in 1939, in the same court, he was convicted of assault with intent to rob; that in 1947, in the Court of Common Pleas of Columbiana County, after a plea of guilty, he was convicted of robbery; and that thereafter he was charged with being an habitual criminal, tried, convicted and sentenced to the penitentiary. It is from confinement under this last sentence that he now seeks to be released.



DISPOSITION: Petitioner remanded to custody.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate sought habeas corpus relief to challenge his imprisonment under the habitual criminal act, Ohio Gen. Code § 13744-1 (Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2961.11). The inmate had previous convictions for burglary and assault with intent to rob; after his third conviction, for robbery, the inmate was charged with and convicted of being an habitual criminal.


OVERVIEW: The inmate was convicted of burglary when he was 17 years old. Five years later, he was convicted of assault with intent to rob. Eight years after that, he was convicted of robbery, then charged with and convicted of being an habitual criminal. He sought habeas relief, which was denied. The court held that the first conviction was not void for lack of jurisdiction. The common pleas court which convicted him had concurrent jurisdiction with the juvenile court over 17 year old offenders pursuant to Ohio Gen. Code §§ 1639 and 1683-20. The inmate's complaint that his robbery conviction was the result of a conspiracy by the prosecutor, to avoid convicting him of a crime (armed robbery) which would not sustain an habitual criminal conviction, was without merit. He could not raise alleged defects in the indictment in a habeas proceeding. Finally, the inmate could not raise the constitutionality of the habitual criminal statute, Ohio Gen. Code § 13744-1 (Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2961.11), because the court that convicted him had jurisdiction to determine the statute's constitutionality.


OUTCOME: The court denied habeas corpus relief to the inmate.

 

253 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Pratt v. Weygandt


No. 34159


Supreme Court of Ohio


164 Ohio St. 463; 132 N.E.2d 191; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 585; 58 Ohio Op. 315



February 1, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action in mandamus originating in this court, wherein the relator, Arno Pratt, seeks a writ to require the respondent, the Chief Justice of this court, to remove Warren S. Earhart, Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Lawrence County, from hearing and determining a divorce action pending in that court and in which relator and his wife are the opposing parties.

The present action was instituted after the respondent heard and overruled an affidavit of prejudice filed against Judge Earhart by the relator, in connection with the above-mentioned divorce case.

In the present action, following the overruling of a demurrer to the amended petition, an answer amounting to a general denial was interposed, and the cause is now before the court for determination on the pleadings and the transcript of the evidence presented before the respondent at the hearing on the affidavit of prejudice.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After respondent, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Ohio, denied an affidavit of prejudice against the trial judge hearing relator's divorce, relator sought a writ of mandamus to compel respondent to remove the trial judge under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2701.03.


OVERVIEW: Relator alleged the trial judge in his divorce was a former partner of his wife's law firm, a political opponent, and that there were other entanglements. The trial judge testified he had no partiality and held no ill will against relator. Relator sought a new judge be assigned under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2701.03 and respondent, the Chief Justice of the Ohio Supreme Court refused, finding no bias. Relator then sought a writ of mandamus from the court, contending the statute required substitution once allegations of bias were made. Otherwise, relator contended respondent abused his discretion. The court held that the course of law over 30 years and practical considerations precluded relator's first contention. As to the second, the court could not say respondent had plainly abused his discretion. Noting it was best to recuse where there was even an issue of bias, the court denied the writ of mandamus.


OUTCOME: The writ of mandamus was denied because the respondent Chief Justice was to investigate and decide allegations of bias in a trial judge, not accept them automatically.

 

254 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. McNamara v. Brown


No. 34657


Supreme Court of Ohio


164 Ohio St. 457; 132 N.E.2d 208; 1956 Ohio LEXIS 581; 58 Ohio Op. 298



January 25, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN PROHIBITION.

This action in prohibition, instituted originally in this court, was brought to test the constitutionality of Section 3513.256, Revised Code, as amended effective January 1, 1956 (126 Ohio Laws, S. 220). That section, relating to nominating petitions of independent candidates for county offices, provides in part as follows:

"The nominating petition of independent candidates for the office of representative to the General Assembly, county commissioner, county auditor, prosecuting attorney, clerk of the Court of Common Pleas, sheriff, county recorder, county treasurer, county engineer, coroner, shall be signed by not less than 25 qualified electors of the county, or not less than seven per cent of the number of electors who voted for Governor at the next preceding regular state election in the county, whichever is the greater. The nominating petition of independent candidates for the office of judge of Probate Court, judge of the Court of Common Pleas, and such other courts as are established by statute, shall be signed by qualified electors not less in number than seven per cent of the number of electors who voted for Governor at the next preceding regular state [***2] election in the territory over which such court has jurisdiction, or 2,500 electors, whichever is the lesser number." (Emphasis supplied.)

It is alleged by relator that the section is unconstitutional in that it violates Section 26, Article II of the Constitution of Ohio, which provides that "all laws, of a general nature, shall have a uniform operation throughout the state."

Relator contends that the statute is a law of a general nature within the meaning of the above-quoted constitutional provision; that by arbitrary classification it sets up conditions which in application make it impossible for citizens to become independent candidates for ten elective county offices in the large counties and then arbitrarily places judicial candidates in a class where the requirements to become independent candidates are substantially different; and that it arbitrarily and fictitiously creates a class or classification to such extent that it is unconstitutional.

The prayer of the petition is for an order commanding the respondent Secretary of State to withdraw or nullify all petition forms heretofore printed and circulated, based on Section 3513.256, Revised Code, as amended, and to notify [***3] each county board of elections to refuse to certify the nomination of any judicial candidate who files an independent-candidate nominating petition containing signatures less in number than seven per cent of the electors who voted for Governor at the next preceding regular election in the territory in which the judicial candidate seeks office.

The cause has been presented on demurrer to the petition, on the ground that it does not state facts which show a cause of action. Counsel concede that the court's ruling thereon will dispose of the case.



DISPOSITION: Demurrer sustained and writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer brought an action in prohibition against respondent, the Illinois Secretary of State, to test the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3513.256, as amended effective January 1, 1956, 126 Ohio Laws, S. 220. The Secretary demurred to the taxpayer's petition on the ground that it did not state facts that showed a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: Section 3513.256 related to nominating petitions of independent candidates for county offices. The taxpayer argued that § 3513.256 violated Ohio Const. art. II, § 26, because, inter alia, it arbitrarily placed judicial candidates in a class where the requirements to become independent candidates were substantially different, and that it arbitrarily and fictitiously created a class or classification to such extent that it was unconstitutional. The court found that the classification in § 3513.256 was reasonable and valid. The only classification made by § 3513.256 in prescribing requirements for nominating petitions was a distinction between candidates for nonjudicial office and candidates for judicial office. Section 3513.256 operated equally on all members of a designated class. There was a substantial difference between the duties of judicial officers and the officers in the other departments of the government, and those differences made the classification a reasonable one.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the demurrer to the petition and denied the writ.

 

255 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Masterson v. Ohio State Racing Com.


No. 34433


Supreme Court of Ohio


164 Ohio St. 312; 130 N.E.2d 829; 1955 Ohio LEXIS 484; 58 Ohio Op. 98



December 7, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN PROHIBITION.

This is an action originating in this court to prohibit the respondent Ohio State Racing Commission from authorizing, permitting, or issuing any permits for conducting horse racing for a stake, purse, or award, with pari-mutuel or certificate type of wagering, within the state of Ohio, and especially to prohibit the issuing of any such permits to tracks within 30 miles of each other, on the same date or dates.

The relators are Charles P. Masterson and Sophie Borek, citizens of the state of Ohio, and Georgeann Borek, Gerald Borek and Patrick Borek, citizens of Ohio and minors of tender years, by their mother and next friend, Sophie Borek, for and on behalf of the state of Ohio and all its citizens.

The relators allege that they are interested in the execution of the laws of the state of Ohio, in the upholding and enforcing of constitutional prohibitions and in the enforcing of public duties affecting themselves and citizens of Ohio generally; that Sophie Borek is the former wife and Georgeann, Gerald and Patrick Borek are children of John Eugene Borek, who had lost money by wagering at one of the race tracks for which a permit had been given by the respondent commission;  [***2] that the commission was established pursuant to Section 3769.01 et seq., Revised Code, with power to prescribe rules and conditions under which horse racing for a stake or purse, with pari-mutuel or certificate type of wagering, shall be conducted in the state of Ohio, and, as authorized and restricted by the Horse Racing Act of Ohio, to determine to whom, for what date or dates, and for what track or tracks permits to conduct such horse racing shall be issued.

Relators allege further that at all times herein concerned Section 6 of Article XV of the Constitution of Ohio provided that "lotteries, and the sale of lottery tickets, for any purpose whatever, shall forever be prohibited in this state"; that to conduct either pari-mutuel or certificate type of wagering is to conduct a lottery contrary to the Constitution of Ohio; that both the winners of the lottery and the amounts won are determined by chance; and that any attempted statutory authorization thereof is unconstitutional and void.

Relators allege further that they have no ordinary remedy at law to prohibit the operation of this illegal lottery and abuse of the power by the commission, and, therefore, pray the court for [***3] a writ of prohibition.

The issues are submitted on a demurrer to the petition.



DISPOSITION: Demurrer sustained and writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relators, two adults and three children of one of the adults on their own behalf and for all the citizens of Ohio, filed an original action for a writ of prohibition to prevent respondent Ohio State Racing Commission from permitting horse races that involved pari-mutuel or certificate-type wagering. Relators alleged that they had no ordinary remedy at law. The Commission filed a demurrer.


OVERVIEW: Relators alleged that they were interested in the execution of the laws of Ohio, in the upholding and enforcing of constitutional prohibitions, and in the enforcing of public duties affecting themselves and citizens of Ohio generally. The wife alleged that her former husband had lost money by wagering at one of the race tracks for which a permit had been given by the Commission. Relators argued that Ohio Const. art. XV, § 6 prohibited lotteries and that pari-mutuel or certificate-type wagering was a lottery, so that the Commission's authorization of horse racing with such wagering violated the Ohio constitution. The court held that: (1) relators had an appropriate and adequate remedy in equity, so they could not pursue the remedy of prohibition; (2) the remedy of injunction was available; and (3) relators' petition did not state a cause of action.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the Commission's demurrer and denied relators' application for a writ.

 

256 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Sun Oil Co. v. Euclid


No. 34385


Supreme Court of Ohio


164 Ohio St. 265; 130 N.E.2d 336; 1955 Ohio LEXIS 468; 58 Ohio Op. 25



November 16, 1955, Decided
