Code §§ 9660-1, 9660-2, plaintiff stockholders brought an action challenging the conversion. After the court of appeals found in favor of defendant, plaintiffs sought review, and the court affirmed. The court held that even though defendant was incorporated prior to § 9660-2's enactment, § 9660-2 was applicable because defendant had since merged, and thus, the merger agreement was an amended articles of incorporation subject to § 9660-2. The court also held the conversion had not constituted a dissolution in violation of defendant's constitution because Ohio Gen. Code § 9665's dissolution power had not limited §§ 9660-1, 9660-2's conversion power. Furthermore, the court held plaintiffs, as dissenting stockholders, were not entitled the fair cash of value for plaintiffs' shares because § 9660-2 had not provided such a right. Finally, the court held the exchange of shares for withdrawable share accounts had not been inequitable even though the shares' book value had been greater than the accounts because book value had not represented actual value and book value was unrealizable.


OUTCOME: Court affirmed a judgment in favor of defendant corporation in plaintiff stockholders' action that challenged defendant's conversion into a federal savings and loan association because defendant obtained the power to convert following a merger, the conversion had not violated defendant's constitution, plaintiffs were not entitled to fair cash value for shares, and the exchange of shares for withdrawable share accounts was not inequitable.

 

286 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


McDougall v. Central Nat'l Bank


No. 32675


Supreme Court of Ohio


157 Ohio St. 45; 104 N.E.2d 441; 1952 Ohio LEXIS 504; 47 Ohio Op. 60



March 5, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga county.

Plaintiff is the administrator of the estate of Dorothy B. McDougall who died intestate in 1945 and who is herein referred to as decedent. Plaintiff is also the surviving spouse of decedent, having been married to her in 1936. In 1930, the decedent had created an irrevocable trust. In 1935, by supplemental agreement, she added to the assets of the trust. By the terms of this trust, she reserved the income to herself for life and reserved the right to designate the donee of the corpus of the trust by will. The trust provided that, in default of such designation, the corpus was to be distributed to the decedent's children but, if she had no children, to her mother and sister or the survivor. No provision was made in the trust agreement or the supplemental agreement of 1935 regarding taxes or their payment.

The decedent left no issue, and she was predeceased by her mother. Since she executed no will, the corpus of the trust was distributable to decedent's sister.

For estate tax purposes, the gross taxable estate of the decedent amounted to $ 612,541.57. This figure represented the sum of the net assets before estate tax [***2] in the decedent's probate estate, amounting to $ 462,993.91, and of the assets in the trust, amounting to $ 149,547.66. The federal estate tax amounted to $ 149,587.89. This was paid by the administrator out of the probate assets.

The administrator brought an action requesting the court to determine what amount was a fair and equitable portion of the estate tax that should be borne by and paid from the trust estate and prayed for judgment against the trustee for that amount.

The Common Pleas Court held that the estate tax was payable entirely from the probate assets and that the administrator had no rights against the trust estate.

That judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.

The cause is now before this court on appeal, pursuant to allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the administrator of decedent's estate, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's holding that the estate tax was payable entirely from the probate assets and that the administrator had no rights against the trust estate. The administrator had initiated the action to recover from appellee trustee a portion of the estate tax he had paid.


OVERVIEW: The corpus of decedent's trust was transferred to her sister. The administrator and decedent's husband paid the estate taxes due and brought an action against the trustee for determination of what portion of the taxes should have been paid out of the trust estate. The trust agreement did not have a provision for the payment of taxes. The lower courts found that the trust estate was not liable to any portion of the federal estate tax. On appeal, the court reversed. The taxable estate of decedent for estate tax purposes was divided into two separate parts, the probate estate and the trust estate. Congress intended that the federal estate tax had to be paid out of the estate as a whole, and that the applicable state law as to the devolution of property at death governed the distribution of the remainder. The estate tax was a burden on "the estate as a whole," including the trust assets and represented an obligation on all of the assets included in decedent's gross estate. The court had previously approved equitable apportionment of the federal estate tax. Thus, an apportionment of the federal estate tax burden between the probate assets and the trust assets was required.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and held that the trust estate had to pay a relative portion of the total tax paid.

 

287 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


W. E. Anderson Sons Co. v. International Brotherhood of Teamsters, etc.


No. 32436


Supreme Court of Ohio


156 Ohio St. 541; 104 N.E.2d 22; 1952 Ohio LEXIS 601; 46 Ohio Op. 460; 29 L.R.R.M. 2457; 21 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P66,787



February 13, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin county.

This is an action brought in the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County to enjoin certain alleged conduct on the part of the defendants tending to interfere with and prevent the plaintiff from carrying out its contractual and usual business activities.

The plaintiff, W. E. Anderson Sons Company, hereinafter designated Anderson, is a corporation having its place of business in the city of Columbus where it is engaged in the business of transporting and delivering by motor truck building materials and other commodities. For that purpose it owns and operates about 60 trucks and employs drivers to operate them.

The defendant Local Union No. 311, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen & Helpers of America, hereinafter designated local union, is an association the members of which are employed as operators of motor trucks and motor vehicles. A number of such members own and operate their own trucks. The defendant Don Pfeiffer is the president and business agent of the local union. The defendant Columbus Building Trades Council is an association of local unions operating in the Columbus area, created by authority [***2] of the Building Trades of the American Federation of Labor, and is composed of delegates or affiliates of various local unions connected with the building trades, including the local unions named as defendants in this action. The defendant Phil O'Day is an officer of such building trades council.

In February 1949, the James I. Barnes Construction Company, hereinafter designated Barnes, was the general contractor engaged in the construction of one of the buildings constituting University Health Center on the campus of Ohio State University at Columbus, Ohio, and in such construction work employed a number of subcontractors. In such construction work Barnes and all its subcontractors employed only union building trade workers.

One of such subcontractors was H. W. Holt & Son Company, hereinafter designated Holt, which had a subcontract to do the filling and grading work on the construction premises. Holt, in turn, engaged Anderson as its subcontractor to haul bank-run gravel from a borrow pit located outside the city of Columbus and dump it at the construction site. The truck operators doing the hauling for Anderson were not members of any union. Their employment comprehended the [***3] dumping of the gravel at the construction site as a delivery operation and was not in any way implemented with the employment of other workmen on the construction project.

The local union had previously sought to obtain this trucking work from Holt for its members who owned and operated their own trucks but the effort was unsuccessful. The local union, both before and after Anderson had secured the contract from Holt to do the hauling work, sought to persuade Anderson's employees to become members of the union but likewise without success.

On the afternoon of February 9, 1949, Anderson's men began delivering by truck dirt and gravel to the construction site. Later the same day, Pfeiffer informed Holt that since it was not employing union men to do this hauling he decided to banner the job. The next day Pfeiffer stationed a picket at the entrance of the construction project where Anderson's truckers entered and left the premises, which picket carried a large body-size banner bearing in display lettering: "Anderson does not employ members of Teamsters Local 311 affiliated with the Building Trades Council, A. F. of L."

Immediately following the placing of the picket and banner,  [***4] most of the union employees working directly for Barnes and for its various subcontractors quit work. As a result of such work stoppage Barnes ordered Holt, its subcontractor, to stop Anderson and its nonunion truck drivers from delivering further materials to the construction site. The order was given by Holt and Anderson ceased hauling on February 16, 1949. The union employees of Barnes and of his subcontractors then resumed work on the job.

After the hauling was suspended, a meeting attended by Holt, Barnes, Pfeiffer and O'Day was held, at which it was agreed that Holt should employ union truck drivers to do the hauling of the dirt and gravel. Two or three such operators were secured but after an hour or two of work they were stopped by representatives of the Public Utilities Commission on the ground that the union operators did not have permits from such commission and were not qualified to operate the trucks.

On February 21, 1949, after Holt had been unsuccessful in securing union operators, Anderson's nonunion truck drivers resumed the work of hauling and continued work for two days without incident. No hauling was done on February 23, 24 or 25 on account of unfavorable [***5] weather. Hauling was resumed, however, on February 28, 1949, and on March 1, 1949, a picket and banner were again placed at the entrance to the construction site, and again most of the union men on the job employed by Barnes and his subcontractors quit work.

After a second conference between Pfeiffer, O'Day and Barnes, Pfeiffer and O'Day requested that an order in writing be sent to Holt to stop Anderson's men from further work, whereupon, under date of March 3, 1949, a telegram was sent to Holt by one Stahl, a representative of Barnes, which was as follows:

"Columbus, Ohio, March 3, 1949


"H. W. Holt & Son

"998 West Mound Street

"Columbus, Ohio

"You are hereby notified to cease work on the TB hospital job in accordance with your contract within 48 hours and we also request that you cease work as soon as possible. You shall not start work without our written consent that all employees are satisfactory to this company. Further changes in arrangements after starting work shall be only made by advising us and with our consent.

"James I. Barnes Construction Co.

"By Ray Stahl."


Again Anderson and his men ceased hauling and the union men employed by Barnes and its [***6] subcontractors resumed work.

A few days later, Anderson instituted this action. After setting up in his petition the facts substantially as above stated, he prayed that the defendants be enjoined from "picketing or bannering the site of any building, job or work whereat plaintiff has or shall have delivered building materials * * * for the purpose of preventing plaintiff from making delivery of materials or other commodities to such site."

Four of the defendants filed answers admitting certain of the allegations of plaintiff's petition with general denials as to the remainder of such allegations, and variously alleging that the granting of an order or orders as prayed for by the plaintiff against the defendants would constitute a deprivation of rights as guaranteed in Articles I, XIII and XIV, Amendments, U.S. Constitution, and Sections 6 and 11, Article I, Ohio Constitution.

At the trial, Arthur Stray, superintendent of construction for Barnes, testified that on the day before the banner was posted O'Day called him by telephone and asked him if Anderson was hauling. Stray answered, "yes," whereupon O'Day said there "would be a banner up in the morning" and "well, if they want [***7] a showdown we will give it to them." O'Day admitted that he had the telephone conversation with Stray but denied the statement as to showdown and denied that he said the banner would be posted, because "I cannot banner the job, that is up to the locals."

Holt testified that on the day Anderson's men began working Pfeiffer informed Holt that he decided to have the job bannered because Anderson was making deliveries of gravel and was not employing members of the local union to do the work. Pfeiffer admitted that he posted the picket with the banner.

O'Day, when asked whether there are any principles of the unions, other than specific rules and regulations, against crossing a picket line or working behind a banner, replied, "I think the principle lies within the man himself that is working on the job." Pfeiffer testified that Anderson had other jobs it was hauling to at the same time but that he did not put banners up at any of those places.

Two union men who testified at the hearing, in response to questions involving reasons for quitting work, said that they quit work because they did not want to work behind a banner.

On hearing, the Common Pleas Court found that the defendants,  [***8] local union, Pfeiffer, Columbus Building Trades Council, and O'Day, individually and as an officer of the Building Trades Council, had instituted an illegal secondary boycott and that the action of the defendants was in restraint of trade. The court granted an injunction restraining the defendants generally from acts, the purpose of which was to prevent plaintiff from making delivery of materials to the construction site.

The Court of Appeals for Franklin county on stipulation that the cause be submitted to that court solely upon the evidence presented in the Common Pleas Court denied an injunction.

The cause is in this court for review upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant subcontractor, a gravel hauling company, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed the order of the trial court granting an injunction, and denied the subcontractor's request for an injunction against appellee union members to prevent them from picketing or bannering to prevent the subcontractor from making delivery of materials to the construction site.


OVERVIEW: The subcontractor, who was hired to make delivery of gravel and building materials to a construction site, employed drivers who were not union members. When the union members who worked on the site began picketing and bannering, all the other workers walked off the job, causing repeated work stoppages. The subcontractor brought an action to enjoin the conduct of the union members tending to interfere with and prevent the subcontractor from carrying out its contractual and usual business activities. The trial court granted an injunction restraining the union members from acts that prevented the subcontractor's drivers from making delivery of material. The appeals court reversed, and denied the injunction, and certified the cause to the court for review. The court reversed the appeals court's judgment, finding that the union members were engaged in a secondary boycott, which was illegal in the state when employed in a labor dispute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appeal court and rendered final judgment for the subcontractor on its complaint for an injunction preventing the union workers' bannering and picketing.

 

288 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Healy


No. 32371


Supreme Court of Ohio


156 Ohio St. 229; 102 N.E.2d 233; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 481; 46 Ohio Op. 110



November 21, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga county.

In the September 1948 term of the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, the grand jury returned an indictment, containing 12 counts, charging the defendant, Leslie T. Healy, with the violation of Section 12447-1, General Code, commonly referred to as the "larceny by trick statute." Upon application therefor a bill of particulars was furnished the defendant on June 6, 1949, which was prior to the trial. The state entered a nolle prosequi as to five counts in the indictment and the trial proceeded on the remaining seven. The validity of both the indictment and the bill of particulars was challenged by the defendant on the ground that they were vague, indefinite and uncertain in their terms, and for the further reason that Section 12447-1, General Code, under which the indictment was purported to have been drawn, is unconstitutional and void because of being vague, indefinite and uncertain. The challenge was rejected.

Trial was had to a jury which returned a verdict of guilty on each of the seven counts. A motion for a new trial and a motion in arrest of judgment were filed in due course and overruled. Judgment was entered [***2] on the verdict and the defendant sentenced to the penitentiary.

The Court of Appeals (one judge dissenting) reversed the judgment of the trial court for error of law "(1) in failing to instruct the jury that 'an intent to deprive owners of their property' as an element of the crimes charged, and (2) for error of law in exclusion of evidence proffered by defendant-appellant."

The cause is before this court following the allowance of a motion by the state for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of seven counts of larceny by trick. The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga (Ohio) reversed defendant's convictions. The state appealed.


OVERVIEW: The intermediate court found that the trial court erred in its jury instructions regarding the intent required for larceny by trick, and that the trial court erred in excluding certain evidence proffered by defendant. The court disagreed, reversed the intermediate court's order, and affirmed defendant's convictions. The court held that the trial court properly applied the language of the larceny by trick statute, Ohio Gen. Code § 12447-1, in its instructions to the jury. The court noted that the trial court charged generally on intent. The court said that it would have been error had the trial court attempted to establish by fiat some definition of specific intent, which was not required by the statute to constitute the offense. Regarding the exclusion of evidence, the court held that the trial court did not err in rejecting defendant's proffered bank records. The court said that defendant was allowed to testify fully that he did not make false representations, and that he honestly intended to build houses in accordance with the contracts. The court concluded that defendant was not prejudiced in any way by the rejection of the photostatic copies of the bank statements.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the intermediate court's order that reversed defendant's convictions for larceny by trick. The court affirmed defendant's convictions.

 

289 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Gill v. Volz


No. 32456


Supreme Court of Ohio


156 Ohio St. 60; 100 N.E.2d 203; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 451; 45 Ohio Op. 63



July 5, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Franklin county.

On June 28, 1946, a bastardy proceeding was instituted in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, Division of Domestic Relations, upon the complaint of Joan R. Gill charging the accused, Robert Volz, to be the father of her unborn child. The child was born prior to the trial of the case and was then living.

In September 1947, the case was tried in the Common Pleas Court, wherein a jury returned a verdict of guilty, nine jurors concurring. A motion for new trial was overruled, but the trial judge failed to enter a judgment that the accused was the reputed father of a bastard child.

On application to the Common Pleas Court, Division of Domestic Relations, to fix the money support for the mother during pregnancy and the expenses in connection with the birth of the child, the same were fixed at $ 819.46, and an order was made for the support of the child.

An appeal was taken to the Court of Appeals which reversed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court because it had failed to enter any judgment after the return of the verdict of guilty by the jury, and ordered the cause remanded to the Court of Common Pleas for further [***2] proceedings.

Thereafter, in February 1949, without further hearing, the Common Pleas Court entered a judgment adjudging the accused to be the reputed father of the bastard child and ordering that such judgment be entered nunc pro tunc as of November 8, 1947. Following this entry, the Common Pleas Court, without taking any further testimony, re-entered its identical former judgment nunc pro tunc.

A second appeal was taken to the Court of Appeals which again reversed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court on the ground that the latter court was in error in entering such judgment nunc pro tunc and again remanded the cause.

On June 7, 1950, the Common Pleas Court, without further hearing, entered a judgment as of that date adjudging the accused to be the reputed father of a bastard child, whereupon the Division of Domestic Relations of such court re-entered its judgment for expenses of the child's birth, support of the mother during pregnancy and the child's support and maintenance from its birth and ordered that the accused be committed to jail if he neglected to comply with the order of the court.

On appeal on questions of law, that third judgment was affirmed by the [***3] Court of Appeals, and, on motion, the judges of that court certified the record to this court for review and final determination on the ground that its judgment was in conflict with that of the Court of Appeals for Hardin county in State, ex rel. Griffin, v. Zimmerman, 67 Ohio App., 272, 36 N. E. (2d), 808.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) certified the record of its judgment that appellant father was the reputed father of a bastard child born to appellee mother. A jury had returned a verdict that the father was the father of the child. On appeal, the judgment was reversed because the trial court had failed to enter the judgment. The case had been appealed and remanded twice before it was certified to the court.


OVERVIEW: The mother instituted a bastardy proceeding against the father and charged that he was the father of her unborn child. A jury returned a guilty verdict with nine jurors concurring. After two appeals and two remands, the appellate court affirmed the judgment and certified the record to the court due to a split between the appellate courts as to whether a bastardy proceeding was a civil or a criminal action. The court concluded that a bastardy proceeding was essentially a civil action and affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which had affirmed the judgment of the trial court. The court noted that while bastardy proceedings had often been referred to or classified as "quasi-criminal" proceedings, as such, they were not the same as purely criminal proceedings. The court found that past legislation authorizing a civil jury to enter a verdict upon the concurrence of three-fourths or more of their number encompassed all types of cases that were not purely criminal. The court concluded that the trial court committed no error in accepting the verdict of guilty concurred in by nine members of the jury.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which affirmed the judgment of the trial court that the father was the reputed father of the mother's child.

 

290 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Green v. Acacia Mut. Life Ins. Co.


No. 32339


Supreme Court of Ohio


156 Ohio St. 1; 100 N.E.2d 211; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 447; 45 Ohio Op. 32



June 27, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton county.

On March 18, 1948, Consetta P. Green, hereinafter designated plaintiff, brought an action in the Common Pleas Court of Hamilton County against Acacia Mutual Life Insurance Company, hereinafter designated defendant, upon a policy of insurance on the life of her husband, George C. Green, in which policy plaintiff was named beneficiary. The policy had been delivered to George C. Green upon payment of a premium on October 17, 1947.

George C. Green died October 31, 1947, while such policy was in effect.

Defendant filed an answer in which it alleged that decedent in his application for the policy claimed to be in good health, whereas he was not, in giving false answers with reference to his physical condition; and that defendant relied on such answers.

Defendant tendered to plaintiff the amount of the premium paid for the policy, with interest.

After trial, plaintiff filed a reply to defendant's answer nunc pro tunc.

The jury returned a verdict in favor of plaintiff for the full amount of the policy, with interest, whereupon defendant filed a motion for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict. The motion was overruled and [***2] judgment was entered by the trial court upon the verdict.

Within ten days thereafter defendant filed a motion for a new trial, which was granted by the trial court by an order reading as follows:

"This cause being heard on defendant's motion to set aside the verdict and judgment herein and to grant a new trial, was argued by counsel and submitted to the court; on consideration whereof the court, having been requested by plaintiff to state the grounds of the finding, finds said motion well taken on the grounds that there is newly discovered evidence material for the defendant and because the verdict and judgment are manifestly against the weight of the evidence, and that the motion should be sustained.

"It is, therefore, ordered that the verdict and the judgment entered herein be, and the same are hereby set aside and vacated and a new trial of the cause is granted.

"To all of which the plaintiff, by her counsel, excepts."

From that order the plaintiff appealed to the Court of Appeals of Hamilton County, and the defendant filed a cross-appeal from the order of the trial court overruling its motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.

The Court of Appeals dismissed both the [***3] appeal and cross-appeal and in reference to the former found "no abuse of discretion on the part of the Court of Common Pleas in vacating and setting aside the judgment and granting the motion for a new trial and that said appeal not being predicated upon a final order is not reviewable by this court and should be dismissed."

The judges of the Court of Appeals, finding its judgment in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals of the Eighth Appellate District, in the case of Haffner v. Schmeidl, 87 Ohio App., 143, 56 Ohio Law Abs., 77, 90 N. E. (2d), 700, certified the record to the Supreme Court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff beneficiary sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals of Hamilton County (Ohio), which dismissed her appeal in her action against defendant insurer to recover under a life insurance policy.


OVERVIEW: The beneficiary filed an action against the insurer to recover under her husband's life insurance policy to which the insurer answered that the husband's insurance application contained false information. The jury returned a verdict in the beneficiary's favor, which led the insurer to file a motion for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict, which was denied. The insurer then filed a timely motion to set aside the verdict and for a new trial, which the trial court granted. The beneficiary's appeal was dismissed by the appellate court on the ground that it was not predicated upon a final judgment, and then was certified to the court for a final determination. The court affirmed. The court held that an order that granted a motion for a new trial was not, in the absence of an abuse of discretion, a final judgment that was reviewable to an appellate court. The court ruled that once the judgment for a new trial had been entered, the former verdict was no longer in existence and no judgment existed that could have been appealed, absent an abuse of discretion. Because the court found that there was no abuse of discretion by the trial court, the beneficiary's appeal was properly dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court that dismissed the beneficiary's appeal in her action to recover under a life insurance policy against the insurer.

 

291 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Kurtz v. Shaffer


No. 32427


Supreme Court of Ohio


155 Ohio St. 491; 99 N.E.2d 479; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 599; 44 Ohio Op. 445



May 31, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action in mandamus originating in this court to compel the clerk of the City Commission of the City of Springfield and the Clark County Board of Elections to submit to the electors of the city of Springfield an ordinance proposed by initiative petition to amend and supplement an existing ordinance. The ordinance which was proposed to be amended had been passed by the city commission of Springfield on May 24, 1948, was known as ordinance No. 4741 and became effective July 1, 1948. It provided for a tax of one per cent on certain specified types of income. The amending ordinance proposed by initiative would reduce the rate of the tax to one-half of one per cent and make certain provisions for exemptions. The charter of the city of Springfield contains comprehensive provisions authorizing the initiative, including the following:

Section 53. "Any proposed ordinances, including ordinances for the repeal or amendment of an ordinance then in effect, may be submitted to the city commission by petition signed by at least five per cent of the total number of registered voters in the municipality. All petitions circulated with respect to any proposed ordinance [***2] shall be uniform in character, shall contain the proposed ordinance in full, and shall have printed or written thereon the names and addresses of at least five electors, who shall be officially regarded as filing the petition and shall constitute a committee of the petitioners for the purpose hereinafter named.

"Each signer of a petition shall sign his name in ink or indelible pencil and shall place on the petition, opposite his name, the date of his signature and his place of residence by voting precinct and by street and number. The signatures to any such petition need not all be appended to one paper, but to each such paper there shall be attached an affidavit by the circulator thereof, stating the number of signers to such part of the petition and that each signature appended to the paper is the genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be, and that it was made in the presence of the affiant and on the date indicated."

Section 54. "All papers comprising a petition shall be assembled and filed with the clerk of the city commission as one instrument, within one hundred and twenty days from the date of the first signature thereon, and when so filed, the clerk shall [***3] submit the same to the city commission at its next regular meeting and provision shall be made for public hearings upon the proposed ordinance."

Petitions were circulated between May 4, 1950, and August 21, 1950, on which latter date they were filed with the clerk of the city commission as one consolidated petition. On the evening of August 21, 1950, the petition was submitted to the city commission in regular session. The commission ordered its clerk to have the petition checked to determine its adequacy, sufficiency and validity and authorized the clerk to utilize the facilities of the Clark County Board of Elections and such other means as were necessary and proper for the accomplishment of that purpose.

At the time said petition was so filed there were in the city of Springfield 31,345 registered voters. Five per cent of the registered voters was 1,568. The initiative petition contained 1,810 names. The check of the petition made by the clerk of the city commission with the assistance of the board of elections and certain others indicated that many signatures on the petition were invalid or irregular and that the number of valid signatures thereon was less than the required [***4] number of 1,568. The city commission accepted the report of the check of the petition and on September 20, 1950, formally rejected the petition by ordinance declaring it to be insufficient, inadequate and invalid for the reasons therein set forth.

Section 55 of the charter provides in substance that if the city commission rejects a proposed ordinance the petitioners by written demand filed within 20 days after such final action may require that the proposed ordinance be submitted to a vote of the electors in its original form "if, with or prior to such demand, a petition for such election, signed after the final action or inaction of the city commission, is filed with such clerk bearing additional signatures of five per cent of the electors of the city, none of whom were signers of the first petition." That section then continues: "Such clerk shall forthwith cause notice of the filing of such demand and petition to be published in some newspaper of general circulation in the city, and shall also within five days certify to the officers having control of elections the proposed ordinance, stating whether or not a special election is demanded in the petitions, the percentage of registered [***5] voters who signed the two petitions in the aggregate, and the date on which he published the notice last mentioned."

On October 3, 1950, the petitioners did file with the city commission a second petition purporting to contain 2,574 additional signatures. Some check was made of the names appearing upon the second petition but notice of the filing of such demand and petition was not published in any newspaper and no certificate was issued to the board of elections with respect to placing the petition upon the ballot at any election.

This action in mandamus was instituted on October 17, 1950. The prayer of the petition is:

"Relator prays that a peremptory writ of mandamus be issued directing the defendant herein, Mrs. M. Lucille Shaffer, clerk of the City Commission of Springfield, Ohio, to comply with her mandatory obligation to cause notice of filing of this demand to be published in some newspaper of general circulation in the said city and also to certify to the officers having control of elections the proposed ordinance, that a special election is demanded, the percentage of registered voters who signed the two petitions in the aggregate and the date on which she published [***6] the notice last mentioned."

The petition also prays for an alternative writ requiring the board of elections to place the initiated ordinance on the ballot for the election of November 7, 1950.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator filed a petition for a writ of mandamus to compel respondents, city clerk and city commissioner, to submit to the electors an ordinance proposed by initiative petition to amend an ordinance providing for a tax on certain income. The city commissioner had refused to submit the ordinance upon a determination that it contained an insufficient number of valid signatures, as required by Springfield, Ohio, Ordinance § 53.


OVERVIEW: While relator's petition contained signatures equaling at least five percent of the voters registered on the date the petition was submitted, as required by Springfield, Ohio, Ordinance § 53, the city commissioner determined that many of the signatures were invalid. The court denied the petition for a writ. At the outset, the court ruled that the initiative sections of the city charter were not unconstitutional simply because they required a certain number of signatures. Moreover, the court ruled that relator had no standing to challenge the constitutionality of the initiative provision while at the same time attempt to compel the city officials to effectuate those provisions. The court also ruled that the city commissioner had both a right and a duty to ensure that the signatures were valid. The court explained that the right of citizens to vote on legislation proposed by initiative petition had to be exercised in conformity with the provisions of the city charter. Finally, the city commissioner properly determined that there were insufficient valid signatures because either the signators were not residents or registered voters, or because the signatures were not signed in ink.


OUTCOME: The court denied relator's petition for a writ of mandamus.

 

292 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Iddings v. Board of Education


No. 32365


Supreme Court of Ohio


155 Ohio St. 287; 98 N.E.2d 827; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 567; 44 Ohio Op. 294



April 25, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Jefferson county.

On May 12, 1948, the Jefferson County Board of Education adopted a resolution to create a new local school district from the territory theretofore comprising the Port Homer Local School District and the Saline Local School District. On June 10, 1948, there was duly filed with the county board a written remonstrance against the creation of the new school district. The remonstrance contained the signatures of 705 qualified electors residing in the combined districts.

Thereafter the county board of education found and determined that the remonstrance was insufficient in that it did not contain the signatures of at least 330 qualified electors who voted in the territory constituting the newly created school district at the 1947 general election. It is agreed that 659 qualified electors residing in the territory included in the newly created school district voted in the 1947 general election. The county board named the new district "Saline Local School District," appointed a five-member board and directed an audit of the books of the former districts.

Suit was instituted in the Court of Common Pleas of Jefferson County to enjoin [***2] further proceedings in the creation and establishment of the new local school district. Issue was made by petition, amended answer and reply.

Following hearing thereof the court found the plaintiffs were not entitled to the relief prayed for.

Appeal to the Court of Appeals on questions of law and fact resulted in a like finding and judgment.

The cause was thereupon duly appealed to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant electors challenged a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Jefferson County (Ohio), which denied the electors' request for injunctive relief. The electors had filed an action against appellees, a county board of education and others, seeking an injunction to enjoin appellees from further proceeding in the creation and establishment of a new local school district.


OVERVIEW: A written remonstrance, which contained the signatures of 705 qualified electors residing in the combined districts, was filed against the board's decision to create a new local school district. The board found that the remonstrance was insufficient in that it did not contain the signatures of at least 330 qualified electors who voted at the last general election in the territory constituting the newly created school district. The electors then sought to enjoin further proceedings in the creation and establishment of the new local school district. On appeal from a judgment for the board, the court held that: (1) the board had authority under Ohio Gen. Code § 4831-1 (1947) to create a new local school district; (2) the language of the general assembly in § 4831-1 was susceptible of only one meaning, that to qualify and to be counted as a remonstrator against the action of the board, one had to have voted at the last general election; and (3) § 4831-1 did not violate the constitution because it did not deprive any right conferred by any constitutional provision, it had uniform operation throughout the state, it did not abridge the privileges or immunities of any citizen.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

293 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Jelm v. Jelm


No. 32196


Supreme Court of Ohio


155 Ohio St. 226; 98 N.E.2d 401; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 560; 44 Ohio Op. 246; 22 A.L.R.2d 1300



April 18, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga county.

This is an appeal from a judgment of the Court of Appeals which affirmed a judgment of the Common Pleas Court vacating and setting aside a decree of divorce, which decree had been granted at a previous term of court and without contest, no answer having been filed and no appearance having been made by the defendant. Further facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wife sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which ruled that the trial court had the power to vacate a divorce decree entered in the trial court by a prior term. The wife argued that the trial court did not have jurisdiction to determine appellee husband's motion to vacate the divorce decree.


OVERVIEW: The wife filed for and obtained an uncontested divorce. The wife, however, did not inform the trial court that she continued to live with the husband. The couple also conceived a fourth child. When asked about the divorce by the husband, the wife was evasive and did not tell him that she had obtained a judgment of divorce. The wife then remarried to the husband's surprise. The husband filed a motion to vacate the divorce decree on the grounds of the wife's fraud. The trial court granted the husband's motion. On appeal from the appellate court's decision affirming, the court ruled that the trial court, as a court of general jurisdiction, had the inherent power to vacate its own judgment on the basis of fraud. The court ruled that where the husband filed his motion to vacate the judgment as soon as he learned of the wife's fraud, the circumstances permitted the trial court's exercise of its power to vacate the judgment. The court also ruled that the trial court's power to vacate a judgment entered by a prior term complied with the requirements of Ohio Gen. Code § 11635. The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court, which affirmed and the trial court decision.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which upheld the trial court's allowance of the husband's motion to vacate the divorce decree on the grounds of the wife's fraud.

 

294 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of McWilson


No. 32379


Supreme Court of Ohio


155 Ohio St. 261; 98 N.E.2d 289; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 562; 44 Ohio Op. 262



April 18, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga county.

On January 3, 1949, Thomas McWilson, hereinafter designated petitioner, filed a petition in the Probate Court of Cuyahoga County, under Section 10509-25, General Code, in which petition he alleged that one James Hawkins McWilson, hereinafter designated decedent, last resided in St. Louis, Missouri; that he disappeared from his home and domicile in St. Louis on or about September 25, 1936, and has not been heard from or seen since; and that on account of his absence from the place of his last domicile for a period of more than seven years he is presumed to be dead.

Petitioner in his petition applied to be appointed administrator of the estate of decedent and prayed that proceedings be had by the court so that the legal presumption of the death of decedent may be established and an administrator of his estate appointed.

On January 3, 1949, the Probate Court found that petitioner is the father and only next of kin of decedent and entitled to administer decedent's estate, ordered the advertisement provided for in Section 10509-25, General Code, and set a further hearing on February 14, 1949.

On this latter date the court entered [***2] an order finding that the statements contained in the petitioner's petition were true; that decedent was a resident of St. Louis, Missouri; that he disappeared from his home and domicile in St. Louis on or about September 25, 1936; that he has not been heard from or seen since; and that he has been absent for a period of more than seven years and is believed to be dead.

The court found further that the presumptive death had been made out and it so decreed, ordered that the date of the death of decedent be fixed as of September 25, 1943, ordered the publication as provided in Section 10509-28, General Code, and continued the case until July 1, 1949.

On this latter date the court made absolute the decree rendered on February 14, 1949, and fixed the date of the presumptive death of decedent as September 25, 1943.

The court likewise found that petitioner is the father and only next of kin of decedent and appointed petitioner administrator of decedent's estate.

On October 17, 1949, petitioner filed a motion in the Probate Court to correct the journal entry of February 14, 1949, by striking out the words, "September 25, 1943," and inserting in lieu thereof, "February 14, 1949," nunc  [***3] pro tunc, upon the grounds, inter alia, that the former date was inserted in the entry by mistake and inadvertence constituting irregularity within the purview of the statute, and that the words complained of were put in the entry in violation of the requirements of the Code under which such entry was made, which Code required the date of the presumed death of the decedent to be fixed as of the date of the decree.

This motion was denied.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Probate Court, with one judge dissenting.

The cause is before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner father, appointed administrator of his deceased son's estate, sought review of the judgment from the Court of Appeals of Cuyahoga County (Ohio) that denied his motion to correct the journal entry regarding the presumed date of death of the decedent.


OVERVIEW: The father had filed an action, alleging that the decedent, his son, had disappeared from their home and had not been from or seen since for a period of more than seven years and was presumed to be dead. The trial court admitted the matter to probate, appointed the father as administrator of the decedent's estate, and fixed the date of the presumptive death of the decedent as seven years from the date of disappearance. The father filed a motion to correct the journal entry, by changing the date of death to the date of the decree. The trial court denied that motion, and the appellate court affirmed. In reversing, the court held that the common law, requiring the presumption of death at the end of seven years, had been modified by Ohio Gen. Code §10509-28, causing the presumption to arise at the date of a decree by the trial court. Thus, the trial court did not have the authority to fix the date of death as the date seven years after the decedent's disappearance, and it committed error in denying the father's motion to change the date as to the presumption of the decedent's death.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment from the trial court.

 

295 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Standard Oil Co. v. Glander


No. 32060


Supreme Court of Ohio


155 Ohio St. 61; 98 N.E.2d 8; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 536; 44 Ohio Op. 86



March 14, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The appellant is The Standard Oil Company, an Ohio corporation, and the appellees are C. Emory Glander, Tax Commissioner of Ohio, and John A. Zangerle, auditor of Cuyahoga county.

This appeal from the Board of Tax Appeals involves the final orders and tax assessments made by the Tax Commissioner with respect to and on certain tangible personal property of the appellant for the tax years 1943, 1944, 1945 and 1946, respectively. Three separate appeals to the Board of Tax Appeals were prosecuted by the appellant which were consolidated in the hearing by that board. One of the appeals, involving the validity of a final assessment by the Tax Commissioner for the year 1945, was decided in favor of the appellant and no appeal was prosecuted to this court. The appeal to this court is limited to the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals in regard to Tax Commissioner's case No. 12488, which involves a final assessment certificate and an amendment thereof assessing taxes for the tax years 1943 and 1944 on a Houdry catalytic cracking unit which was in the process of construction on January 1, 1943, and on January 1, 1944, but which was not completed and [***2] not in operation on either of those tax-listing dates, and Tax Commissioner's case No. 14381, which is an appeal from final orders of the Tax Commissioner assessing taxes for the tax years 1945 and 1946, respectively, on certain towboats and barges of the appellant, the then finished and operating Houdry catalytic cracking unit above referred to and certain machinery and equipment in process of construction which were unfinished and not in operation on January 1, 1945, and January 1, 1946.

The decision of the Board of Tax Appeals affirmed in most respects the orders and assessments in each of these causes, and the appellant, by appeal to this court, presents the question whether the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals is unreasonable or unlawful.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer disagreed with appellees, the tax commissioner and the county auditor, concerning the state's right to tax taxpayer's barges and towboats under Ohio Gen. Code § 5328 as well as the valuations of a refinery and equipment and machinery in the process of construction. After the Board of Tax Appeals (BTA) substantially rejected the taxpayer's consolidated appeals and upheld the commissioner's rulings, the taxpayer appealed.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer claimed that its barges and towboats were not subject to state tax. It also challenged the valuation of a plant and certain equipment and machinery in the process of construction. When the BTA substantially upheld the commissioner's determinations, the taxpayer appealed. The court affirmed in part and reversed in part. The court upheld the taxation of the barges and towboats despite a Fourteenth Amendment challenge because the law did not require apportionment based on the percentage of actual use in the state's waters and apportionment, as a legislative function, was not properly undertaken by a court. The court also upheld the BTA's ruling that machinery under construction nonetheless was "used in business" for the purposes of Ohio Gen. Code § 5325-1 because the ruling was neither unreasonable nor unlawful. However, the court reversed the BTA's plant valuation. While the commissioner had properly eliminated certain "overrun" costs from the plant's assessed value, the court agreed with the taxpayer that further reduction was needed to reflect the plant's functional obsolescence and the holding was reversed and remanded for redetermination of the plant's true value.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the imposition of state property tax on the taxpayer's barges and towboats, upheld the imposition of tax on certain machinery and equipment under construction, and upheld the commissioner's determination of certain "overrun" costs. However, the court found that the BTA had inadequately reflected the impact on taxable value of the plant's functional obsolescence. It reversed the ruling and remanded the issue for redetermination.

 

296 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Allen v. Ferguson


No. 32432


Supreme Court of Ohio


155 Ohio St. 26; 97 N.E.2d 660; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 532; 44 Ohio Op. 63



March 7, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

On June 14, 1950, relators, a firm of consulting engineers, entered into a written agreement with the Director of Highways which provided for their performing certain services necessary for the study of a proposed turnpike project. This contract provided for payment of the relators' fees in installments. At the time of the filing of their petition, relators had performed all the services required by the agreement to be performed in order to entitle them to certain payments under the agreement, and the Director of Highways had transmitted to the Auditor of State vouchers for the issuance of warrants to relators for such payments. The auditor refused to issue the warrants. Thereupon, relators brought this original action against the Auditor of State, seeking a writ of mandamus compelling the auditor to issue the vouchers for such payments. The case is now before this court for hearing upon the demurrer of relators to the amended answer of the auditor.



DISPOSITION: Demurrer to amended answer sustained and writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relators, a firm of consulting engineers, demurred to the amended answer of the Ohio Auditor of State in the engineers' action for a writ of mandamus compelling the auditor to issue vouchers for payments regarding the study of a proposed turnpike project for the Ohio Director of Highways.


OVERVIEW: The engineers sought payment for work they did on a study for a proposed turnpike project. The auditor claimed that the Ohio Director of Highways did not have authority to make the contract involved for numerous reasons: Ohio Gen. Code § 1220 required that the director use employees of the highway department; the project had not even been located; a turnpike commission did not exist; and the turnpike act was unconstitutional. The court sustained the engineers' demurrer. The court held that § 1220 impliedly permitted the director of highways to enter into a contract with a firm of consulting engineers. It also allowed the turnpike commission to secure necessary information before locating a turnpike. The turnpike commission appointees had power and authority to act as a turnpike commission while awaiting confirmation by the state senate. Ohio Const. art. I, § 19 permitted the taking of private property for toll roads as long as the owner was first compensated. Even if sections of the turnpike act not pertinent to this case were unconstitutional, the remainder of the act was independently valid.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the engineers' demurrer to the auditor's answer. The court allowed the writ of mandamus to compel the auditor to issue vouchers for payments due to the engineers.

 

297 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Lieux v. Westlake


No. 32222


Supreme Court of Ohio


154 Ohio St. 412; 96 N.E.2d 414; 1951 Ohio LEXIS 626; 43 Ohio Op. 343



January 10, 1951, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga county.

Ruth Lieux, herein referred to as relator, instituted a mandamus action in the Court of Appeals to compel the village of Westlake and its building commissioner to issue to her a building permit for the construction of a commercial greenhouse on her property in the village. The commissioner refused to issue the permit on the ground that the issuance would violate the zoning ordinance of the village. The Court of Appeals issued a writ of mandamus ordering the commissioner to issue the permit.

The case is here on appeal as a matter of right from the judgment of the Court of Appeals, the case being one originating in the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the village and its building commissioner, challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which issued a writ of mandamus, holding that a village ordinance was unconstitutional and ordering the commissioner to grant appellee landowner a permit for a commercial greenhouse. The commissioner argued that the landowner had failed to exhaust her administrative remedies.


OVERVIEW: Village of Westlake, Ohio, Zoning Ordinance prohibited the erection of commercial greenhouses in residential districts without a special permit. The ordinance provided that any applicant had a right notice and a public hearing to determine whether its greenhouse would be detrimental to the character of the district. The village building commissioner denied a landowner's application for a special permit. Instead of requesting a hearing, she filed an action for a writ of mandamus in the court of appeals on the ground that the ordinance as applied was unconstitutional. The court of appeals granted the writ and ordered the commissioner to issue the permit. The village and the commissioner appealed. The court quoted the ordinance's provisions for administrative appeal and observed that the landowner had not exercised her rights under the ordinance to appeal. Constitutional questions were not to be addressed unless they could not be avoided. Moreover, the constitutional issues would not be properly preserved unless the landowner exhausted her administrative remedies. The court reversed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's writ of mandamus and held that the landowner was required to exhaust the administrative remedies set forth in the village ordinance before she could challenge the constitutionality of the ordinance itself.

 

298 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Melvin v. Sweeney


No. 32428


Supreme Court of Ohio


154 Ohio St. 223; 94 N.E.2d 785; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 414; 43 Ohio Op. 36



October 27, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action in mandamus, originating in this court, to require the respondent to issue an order to the members of the various boards of elections in the state directing them not to assist illiterate voters in marking their ballots and to disregard former instructions to the contrary.

The relator alleges that on July 25, 1950, the respondent, purporting to act under the authority conferred on him by the statutes of Ohio, circulated a release to all boards of elections in the state of Ohio, wherein it was stated that the same assistance should be given to an illiterate voter as is given to a voter suffering from physical infirmity as provided in Section 4785-132, General Code.

Relator alleges further that the information and instructions contained in such release are erroneous and in violation of law in that the opinion expressed therein places an interpretation upon the aforesaid statute, which is not supported by and is directly contrary to the positive provisions of the statute; that if such instructions are carried out by the precinct election officials countless votes will be illegally cast in the state at the forthcoming election. Relator alleges further [***2] that as a result of the office held by the respondent the duty is specially enjoined upon him by law to advise with and instruct members of the various boards of elections in the state as to the proper methods of conducting elections and to provide rules, regulations and instructions for the conduct thereof; that by reason of the foregoing it is the mandatory duty of the respondent to advise the various boards of elections in the state that the information contained in his release and the opinion expressed therein are contrary to law and should be disregarded; and that the respondent has expressed his intention not to further advise the members of the boards of elections on the question of assisting illiterate voters to vote or directing the manner of such assistance.

The prayer of the petition is as above stated.

To this petition the respondent filed a general demurrer, and it was agreed by the parties that the ruling on such demurrer will be dispositive of the issues in this case.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator attorney general sought a writ in mandamus to compel respondent secretary of state to issue an order to the various state boards of elections directing them not to assist illiterate voters in marking their ballots and to disregard former instructions to the contrary. The attorney general challenged the interpretation of Ohio Gen. Code § 4785-132. The secretary of state filed a general demurrer to the attorney general's petition.


OVERVIEW: The state attorney general sought a writ in mandamus to compel the secretary of state to issue an order to the various state boards of elections directing them not to assist illiterate voters in marking their ballots and to disregard former instructions to the contrary. The attorney general challenged the secretary of state's interpretation of Ohio Gen. Code § 4785-132, a statute that allowed assistance to voters who were physically unable to mark their ballots at an election. The attorney general maintained that this statute could not be extended to voters who were illiterate. The secretary of state demurred to the attorney general's petition, and the attorney general sought review of the demurrer. The court found that the statute did provide for assistance to voters with physical infirmities only. The court concluded that the statute was not unconstitutional because it did not deprive voters such as illiterates of the right to vote. The court recognized that a statute requiring each voter to mark and prepare his ballot in secret without declaring its content to other persons was valid.


OUTCOME: The court allowed the writ of mandamus sought by the attorney general to compel the secretary of state to issue an order to the members of the various boards of elections in the state directing them not to assist illiterate voters in marking their ballots.

 

299 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 31891


Supreme Court of Ohio


154 Ohio St. 107; 93 N.E.2d 693; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 394; 42 Ohio Op. 186



July 12, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission.

This is an appeal by six cities of this state, Columbus, Cleveland, Akron, Toledo, Dayton and Canton, from an order of the Public Utilities Commission made March 28, 1949, approving a schedule of service rates to be charged by The Ohio Bell Telephone Company pursuant to its application therefor filed February 2, 1948. The rates so approved went into effect April 1, 1949, and have been charged by the company since that date.

In this opinion, the Public Utilities Commission will be referred to as the commission, The Ohio Bell Telephone Company as the company, the appellants as the cities, the American Telephone & Telegraph Company as American, and the Western Electric Company as Western.

Hearings on the company's application were commenced on November 29, 1948, and the evidence was concluded on January 5, 1949. As required by Section 614-20, General Code, a report of the secretary of the commission was filed on September 17, 1948, prior to the hearings and became available to all parties concerned. This report and the schedules attached thereto disclosed the results of the commission's investigation of matters set forth in the application [***2] of the company.

The company's evidence covered the essential elements of proof in a public utility rate hearing case, including reproduction cost new, existing depreciation, revenues and expenses, separation of property used in interstate and intrastate commerce, and fair rate of return. The evidence fully disclosed the company's and Western's intercorporate relationships with American as its subsidiaries.

To replace the schedule of rates fixed in 1927, the application sought the approval of a new schedule estimated to produce additional revenue of about $ 8,500,000 annually, or an increase of gross revenues of approximately nine per cent per annum. The company claimed and offered evidence to show that the increase sought was necessary because of increased operating expenses due to increase in cost of equipment and largely to increase in wages and salaries.

The only witness called by the cities was an engineer assigned to the law department of the city of Cleveland who testified only on the cost of money as related to a fair rate of return.

Other facts will be stated in the course of the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Order modified and, as modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant cities sought review of the decision of appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio (commission), which approved a schedule of service rates to be charged by the telephone company.


OVERVIEW: The telephone company had sought to increase service rates by application to the commission. The commission held a hearing, reviewed the evidence, and approved the increase. On appeal, the court ordered a modification of the commission's determination of a proper rate base, and as modified, affirmed. The court found that a modification of the proper base rate was necessary because part of the depreciation reserve was inappropriately included in the rate base, which was used to justify the rate increase. The court determined that the depreciation reserve, to the extent that it exceeded the present or accrued depreciation of the utility property, could not be invested in new or additional property and its value included and treated as a part of the rate base. The court also found that the straight line basis of computation of depreciation reserve was more realistic, and a proper depreciation reserve should contemplate something more than an equivalent to present or accrued depreciation because the rate of depreciation should be equally distributed over the life of the plant, rather than unequally where in the later years of the plant the rates would be significantly higher.


OUTCOME: The court ordered a modification of the commission's determination of a proper rate base, and as modified, affirmed, in the action by the cities that sought review of the commission's decision that approved a schedule of service rates to be charged by the telephone company.

 

300 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Calhoun v. Russell


No. 32142


Supreme Court of Ohio


154 Ohio St. 81; 93 N.E.2d 561; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 386; 42 Ohio Op. 150



June 28, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN HABEAS CORPUS.

The petitioner has invoked the original jurisdiction of this court for the purpose of obtaining a writ of habeas corpus ordering his release from the workhouse of the city of Dayton, Ohio, to which he was sentenced by the Municipal Court in two cases on December 21, 1948, after his conviction of the offenses of assault and assault and battery under a municipal ordinance.



DISPOSITION: Petitioner remanded to custody.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner prisoner invoked the original jurisdiction of the court for a second attempt at obtaining a writ of habeas corpus ordering his release after his sentence and conviction by a municipal court had been affirmed by a court of appeals (Ohio) for assault and assault and battery offenses under a municipal ordinance.


OVERVIEW: The prisoner contended that the municipal ordinance under which he was convicted, sentenced, and imprisoned was unconstitutional. He based that assertion on the single fact that the maximum penalty provided by the ordinance was greater than that of Ohio Gen. Code § 12423. He thus claimed that was illegally restrained. The court remanded the prisoner to custody. A writ of habeas corpus could not have been substituted for the remedy of a direct appeal or used to test the constitutionality of a statute or ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court remanded the prisoner to custody after denying his second application for habeas corpus relief from his sentence and conviction for assault and battery.

 

301 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Commercial Motor Freight, Inc. v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 31878


Supreme Court of Ohio


153 Ohio St. 390; 91 N.E.2d 886; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 487; 41 Ohio Op. 407



April 19, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission.

On January 21, 1949, the Andrews Cartage Company, which will hereinafter be designated applicant, a motor transportation company certificated as a common carrier, applied to appellee, the Public Utilities Commission, hereinafter designated the commission, for a private motor carrier permit under which, pursuant to a private contract, applicant proposed to serve the United States Steel Supply Company, hereinafter designated shipper, a large shipper of steel operating in Cleveland.

The appellants, hereinafter designated protestants, protested the issuance of the proposed private motor carrier permit. The hearing on the application was held before an attorney examiner of the commission before whom evidence was adduced that the applicant has been in business in Cleveland for 37 years, and that it holds common carrier authority from the commission, but as a common carrier has never served the shipper.

The applicant and its affiliated companies own more than 300 pieces of motor vehicle equipment which will be needed by the shipper for its business under the proposed contract, which contract provides for the exclusive use by the shipper of [***2] specialized equipment. The contract provides that the applicant is to acquire trucks specially designed for transporting fabricated steel of irregular shapes and varying lengths, with devices to facilitate unloading from the sides at places where there are no unloading cranes. The shipper's business is that of warehousing, fabricating and supplying the smaller users of steel as well as the larger users who do not buy large quantities of particular types of steel. The shipper also operates a warehouse in Cleveland where it has just completed a new plant which will handle about 5,000 tons of steel per month. The steel which the shipper manufactures is made to fit particular jobs in reinforcing concrete and may be of most any shape or size. The applicant is to move the steel to building job sites which will be in various parts of the state.

The contract provides that the shipper will make exclusive use of the equipment furnished by applicant and that added equipment will be furnished on call when needed. Under the contract the shipper is to pay applicant weekly for the regular equipment and daily for the extra equipment, the compensation being based on the size of the vehicle,  [***3] and additional payments for trucks depending upon the mileage traveled.

Applicant's trucks are to be built to the shipper's specifications, painted in the shipper's colors and with its name on them. There is evidence that the shipper is using the protestants' service and expects to continue to do so; and that about 40 per cent of its total tonnage will move by common carrier and 40 per cent by contract carrier. There is evidence that the service of the applicant under the contract permit will cost the shipper more than the use of the trucks of the applicant as a common carrier if it were possible to do so.

The shipper will be using the services of contract carriers at other warehouses in the United States, since it has disposed of its own trucks and uses services such as proposed in the contract.

The business contemplated by the contract is entirely new and has never been served by any common carrier. The contract provides that the shipper will keep the time of the truck drivers' work day, will do the dispatching of the drivers and trucks; and that the service furnished will be identical with private carriage except that it will be given to a contract carrier.

The evidence shows [***4] that the contract will not take business from any existing facility either rail or motor. There is evidence that the type of business contemplated by the contract is a specialized service; a common carrier is not sufficient for the type of business or service proposed and it is neither feasible nor practicable to attempt to devise a common carrier tariff which will apply to the business. The shipper has never used the applicant as a common carrier under its certificate granted by the commission.

The attorney examiner found that the application and formal requirements were in proper order; that applicant was a proper party to whom the commission may grant contract carrier authority; that the shipper has a need for the services proposed by applicant; and that the granting of the application is consistent with the public interest. He found further that certificate No. 1141 now held by applicant should be restricted by prohibiting the transportation of property by applicant under such certificate for any shipper now or hereafter listed under applicant's contract carrier authority. The examiner recommended that the application be granted.

The commission adopted the findings of the [***5] attorney examiner, granted the application and on June 21, 1949, overruled the application of protestants for a rehearing.

An appeal was taken to this court.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant protestants sought review of a decision of appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which granted an application for a private motor carrier permit submitted by a carrier who proposed to serve a large shipper of steel.


OVERVIEW: The carrier applied to the Commission for a private motor carrier permit to service a large steel shipper. The protestants objected to the issuance of the permit. The Commission found that the carrier was a proper party to whom to grant contract carrier authority. The Commission overruled protestants' application for a rehearing. Protestants contended that a Commission rule prohibiting a common carrier from securing a private motor carrier permit unless approved by the Commission was illegal. The court held that: (1) there was ample evidence to demonstrate that the service to be performed by the carrier for the shipper was of such a special nature that it justified a contract with a private carrier in order to have it performed in a businesslike and sensible manner and in order to reduce the number of large trucks on the highways; and (2) while Ohio statutes defined common carrier by motor vehicles as something entirely different from a private carrier, there was no prohibition against one person being both, and thus, it was not unlawful for the Commission to vest a dual character upon a transportation company if consistent with the public interest.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's decision.

 

302 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Kauer v. Defenbacher


No. 32007


Supreme Court of Ohio


153 Ohio St. 268; 91 N.E.2d 512; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 471; 41 Ohio Op. 278



March 22, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action in mandamus originating in this court and brought by the Director of Highways, herein referred to as relator or the highway director, against the Director of Finance, herein referred to as the Director of Finance, and Auditor of State, herein referred to as the auditor. The case was submitted for decision on the amended petition of relator, the answers of the Director of Finance and of the auditor, and the reply of relator.

From these pleadings it appears, without dispute, that, pursuant to Section 1201 et seq., General Code, the Governor appointed the four members of the Ohio Turnpike Commission, to be appointed by him; that, by virtue of his office, relator is the other member of the commission; that the commission requested relator to apply to the controlling board, created by Amended House Bill No. 654 enacted by the 98th General Assembly, for its consent and approval for the expenditure of $ 600,000 out of funds available to relator, for the study of a turnpike project and for authority to use engineering and other forces, including consulting engineers and traffic engineers, in effecting such study; that relator did make application in due [***2] form to the controlling board for its approval and consent to the expenditure by relator of $ 600,000 for such purposes from moneys appropriated by the 98th General Assembly to the "highway improvement fund"; that the controlling board approved that application by the number of favorable votes required under such Amended House Bill No. 654; that, pursuant to such approval and consent, relator submitted to the Director of Finance an encumbrance estimate or certificate for the purpose of encumbering $ 600,000 of the moneys appropriated by Amended House Bill No. 654 to the "highway improvement fund"; and that the Director of Finance refused to issue such encumbrance certificate on the ground that he had neither the legal duty nor the legal authority to do so.

Relator prays that an order of mandamus issue compelling the Director of Finance to issue such certificate of encumbrance and the auditor to receive and recognize it.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator Director of Department of Highways brought an action in mandamus against respondents, Director of Department of Finance and Auditor of State, to compel the finance director to issue a certificate for the purpose of encumbering $ 600,000 of moneys appropriated for a highway improvement fund.


OVERVIEW: The highway director sought to compel the finance director to issue a certificate for the purpose of encumbering $ 600,000 of moneys appropriated by an amended house bill to the highway improvement fund for the study of a turnpike project and for authority to use engineering and other forces, including consulting engineers, in effecting such study. The court held that the amended house bill made a specific appropriation of money which was available for the study of a turnpike project, that the general assembly had the power to appropriate moneys for such purpose, that the turnpike act was not unconstitutional, and that mandamus would lie. The writ was allowed.


OUTCOME: The court allowed a writ of mandamus to issue compelling the finance director to issue a certificate of encumbrance as requested by the highway director and compelling the auditor to receive and recognize it.

 

303 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Angell v. Toledo


No. 31896


Supreme Court of Ohio


153 Ohio St. 179; 91 N.E.2d 250; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 460; 41 Ohio Op. 217



March 8, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas county.
