On August 6, 1948, plaintiff, appellant herein, filed his petition (later amended) in the Common Pleas Court of Lucas County attacking the validity of the ordinance adopted by the council of the city of Toledo on January 28, 1946, known as Ordinance No. 18-46.

In addition to the officers of the municipal corporation, the E. B. Badger Company, plaintiff's employer, was made a party. The petition sought to have Ordinance No. 18-46 declared invalid and plaintiff's employer restrained from deducting the tax from plaintiff's wages.

A demurrer to such petition was sustained. Plaintiff, refusing to further amend his petition and to further plead, the petition was dismissed. Motion for new trial was overruled. Appeal was taken to the Court of Appeals of Lucas county which affirmed the Court of Common Pleas.

The case is in this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city employee sought review from the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's holding dismissing the city employee's complaint against defendant city, which sought to have declared invalid a city ordinance that allowed income tax deductions to be taken from his paycheck.


OVERVIEW: The city employee argued that the city did not have the power to enact an ordinance that provided for the assessment and collection of an income tax. The General Assembly could not enact an income tax unless it was in accordance with the Ohio Constitution. Under Ohio Const. art. XII, §§ 8, 9 it was permissible to pass an income tax, which could be either uniform or graduated and not less than 50 percent of the income and inheritance taxes collected by the state was to be returned to the locale in which the tax originated. Because the General Assembly had pre-empted the income tax field, the city, subject to the limitation as may be imposed by the General Assembly under Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 13 or Ohio Const. art. XIII, § 6, could levy and collect a tax. Therefore, the court held that in the absence of legislation by the General Assembly providing for a uniform or graduated income tax, the city had the power to levy and collect an income tax. Because the city afforded to the city employee a place to work protected by the city government against fire, and theft, the city employee was subject to the tax, even though he was not a resident of the city.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment dismissing the city employee's petition to declare a city ordinance invalid.

 

304 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Applications of University of Cincinnati


Nos. 31779, 31780


Supreme Court of Ohio


153 Ohio St. 142; 91 N.E.2d 502; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 456; 41 Ohio Op. 197



March 1, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The facts are stated in the per curiam opinion.



DISPOSITION: Decisions reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a consolidated case, appellant taxpayers, a university and a board of education, challenged judgments from appellee, the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which held that property belonging to the university that was rented out commercially was not exempt from taxation, and which held that the board of education's property allocated for a future junior high school was also not exempt from taxation.


OVERVIEW: Initially, the university asked for an exemption of its property under Ohio Gen. Code § 4003-15 (120 Ohio Laws 475, 500). Similarly, the board of education asked for an exemption of its property under Ohio Gen. Code § 4834-16. Thereafter, the Board held that both of the properties at issue were not exempt from taxes under the respective provisions. On appeal, however, the court reversed the Board's decisions. Specifically, the court held that although a majority of the members of the court were of the opinion that Ohio Gen. Code §§ 4003-15 and 4834-16 were unconstitutional, more than one member of the court did not concur in that viewpoint. As a result, the court declared that both sections were constitutional and that the real properties at issue were entitled to exemption from taxation, except for two vacant lots involved in the university case. As to those vacant lots, the court emphasized that there was nothing to have been used for the endowment or support of the university. Thus, the court concluded that the words of Ohio Gen. Code § 4003-15 did not provide for tax exemption of those lots. Otherwise, the court reversed the Board's decisions.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decisions of the Board, except as provided in the court's opinion regarding two lots in the university's case.

 

305 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Grieb v. Department of Liquor Control


No. 31846


Supreme Court of Ohio


153 Ohio St. 77; 90 N.E.2d 691; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 553; 41 Ohio Op. 148



February 23, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin county.

Louis W. Grieb operated an establishment in the city of Springfield in which he sold beer, wine and spirituous liquors to the public at retail and by the drink under a permit issued by the Department of Liquor Control of the state of Ohio.

On March 1, 1946, the state Board of Liquor Control issued an order revoking Grieb's permit. Prior to the receipt of the notice of such revocation, agents of the Department of Liquor Control entered Grieb's establishment and seized quantities of wine, whiskey, gin and rum, of the approximate value of $ 5,000, and retained the same as directed and authorized by Sections 6064-28 and 6064-40, General Code.

Thereafter, Grieb brought an action for a declaratory judgment in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin county against the Department of Liquor Control, the Board of Liquor Control and the then Director of Liquor Control. In his petition Grieb alleged the facts narrated above and asked for a determination as to the constitutionality of:

"* * * (1) that part of Section 6064-40 of the General Code of Ohio which provides for the deduction of 25% of the gross proceeds of the sale of seized intoxicating [***2] beverages, legally manufactured and legally acquired by the permit holder, having an alcoholic content of 3.2% by weight to 21% by volume plus the deduction of other costs and expenses as set forth in said section, before refunding the proceeds of said sale to the former permit holder, and (2) that part of Section 6064-40 of the General Code of Ohio which provides for the payment of no amount to the former permit holder for spirituous liquors legally manufactured and legally acquired by the permit holder, seized pursuant to the Liquor Control Act."

The petition was met by a denial of certain allegations thereof.

Findings of fact and conclusions of law were made by the Court of Common Pleas. The conclusions of law are as follows:

"1. Section 6064-40, General Code, provides for the confiscation of private property which is legally acquired and which is not declared a public nuisance therein, without compensation to the owner thereof and with no provision for hearing or judicial process or judicial determination, in violation of Sections 16 and 19 of Article I of the Constitution of Ohio and the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States.

"2. Section 6064-40, General [***3] Code, provides for the taking of spirituous liquor legally acquired and not declared a public nuisance therein for the use of public institutions without compensation in violation of Sections 16 and 19 of Article I of the Constitution of Ohio, and the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States.

"3. Sections 6064-28 and 6064-40, General Code, are unconstitutional in that they authorize the taking of and confiscation of private property without due process of law and without compensation in violation of Sections 16 and 19 of Article I of the Constitution of Ohio and the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States.

"4. The seizure of said liquor and the confiscation thereof by the defendants were illegal.

"5. The plaintiff is entitled to have said liquor described in the petition returned to him by defendants or recover the fair value thereof from the defendants.

"It is therefore declared, adjudged and decreed that the seizure and confiscation of plaintiff's liquor described in the petition was illegal and the plaintiff is entitled to have said liquor returned to him by the defendants or recover the fair value thereof from the defendants, at defendants'  [***4] costs, to all of which findings, conclusions of law and judgment the defendants except."

An appeal on questions of law was perfected by the defendants, the appellants herein, to the Court of Appeals, where the judgment below was affirmed.

The cause is now before this court for disposal upon an appeal as of right and upon the allowance of the motion for certification.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Department of Liquor Control challenged a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) that affirmed a trial court judgment that Ohio Gen. Code § 6064-28 and Ohio Gen. Code § 6064-40, the seizure of appellee owner's liquor were unconstitutional. It also affirmed the judgment that the owner was entitled to have the liquor returned or to recover its fair value.


OVERVIEW: The Department seized and destroyed the owner's liquor under Ohio Gen. Code § 6064-28 and Ohio Gen. Code § 6064-40 because the owner's liquor license had been revoked. The court held that the trial and appellate courts were correct in their judgment. Although the license was revoked because he was found to have violated certain statutes, that fact did not alter the fact that the liquor he owned at the time of the revocation of his permit were legally manufactured and acquired. Thus the liquor was not a nuisance per se. He had a property right in the liquor that could not have been taken away without judicial inquiry and determination.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals that determined that the statutes allowing the seizure of the owner's liquor and the seizure itself were unconstitutional.

 

306 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Frecker v. Dayton


No. 31765


Supreme Court of Ohio


153 Ohio St. 14; 90 N.E.2d 851; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 449; 41 Ohio Op. 109



February 15, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery county.

Plaintiff's business is the manufacture and sale of ice cream and frozen desserts. Sales are made by plaintiff's employee-salesmen who operate refrigerated vending tricycles through the streets of the residence sections of Dayton. The sales take place at the curb, on the sidewalk or on private property.

On June 5, 1946, the commission of the city of Dayton passed the following emergency ordinance No. 16059:

"Prohibiting in the interest of public safety, the sale in the parks, and on or from the streets, sidewalks and alleys of the city of Dayton, Ohio, of certain commodities herein enumerated.

"Whereas, the commission of the city of Dayton, Ohio, deems it necessary and in the public interest to reduce the hazards of injury to young children and to avoid traffic congestion in the parks, and on the streets, sidewalks and alleys of the city of Dayton, to prohibit the sale of certain commodities hereinafter enumerated; and

"Whereas, it is necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, property, health and safety, that this ordinance take effect at an early date; therefore.

"Be it ordained by the commission [***2] of the city of Dayton:

"Section 1. That the Code of General Ordinances of the city of Dayton, Ohio, be supplemented by the enactment of Sections 228-1 [sic] and 288-2 to provide as follows:

"Sec. 288-1. Excepting in any market stands, which now or may hereafter be licensed under the provisions of sections 156 to 196, Code of General Ordinances both inclusive, and park concessions, now or hereafter granted by the city of Dayton, no person, firm or corporation, shall sell or offer to sell, in the parks, and on or from the streets, sidewalks and alleys of the city of Dayton, Ohio, any ice cream in any form, popsicles, ice sherberts or frozen desserts of any kind, any and all kinds of soft drinks, such as pop cola drinks or others, candies of any kind, hot dog or other sandwiches, and peanuts, popcorn, or other similar products.

"Sec. 288-2. Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation, found guilty of the violation of this ordinance, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($ 25) and the costs of prosecution, or more than fifty dollars ($ 50) and the costs of prosecution, and each violation hereof shall [***3] constitute a separate offense.

"Section 2. For the reasons stated in the preamble hereof, this ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure and shall take effect immediately upon its passage."

On June 7, 1946, plaintiff filed its petition in the Common Pleas Court of Montgomery County alleging, inter alia, that the city officials would "unless restrained and enjoined by this court, enforce the aforesaid ordinance against plaintiff, his agents and employees, and arrest or cause the arrest of plaintiff, his agents and employees."

Plaintiff alleged further that the enforcement of the aforesaid ordinance would prohibit it from operating its business in the city of Dayton, Ohio, and would have the effect of stifling competition and would unfairly and unlawfully discriminate against plaintiff.

The Common Pleas Court on June 7, 1946, allowed a temporary restraining order which on September 23, 1948, after hearing upon the petition, the answer, the evidence and the stipulation of parties, was made permanent upon the ground that such ordinance was unwarranted, unreasonable and discriminatory and that the provisions of such ordinance had no real and substantial relationship to public [***4] safety, public health or public welfare, and that accordingly such ordinance was null and void and in violation of the Constitution of the state of Ohio and the Constitution of the United States.

The cause was appealed to the Court of Appeals for Montgomery county and was there heard under the following stipulation:

"The parties do hereby stipulate and agree that the transcript of the evidence in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County, filed herein by the appellant as a bill of exceptions, together with the exhibits, shall constitute all of the facts of this case for submission, together with briefs and arguments of counsel, to the Court of Appeals for its determination of this appeal."

The Court of Appeals, after such hearing, entered a like decree.

The cause is in this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Decree affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of the decision from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which affirmed a decision that granted judgment in favor of appellee ice cream vending company in its action to permanently enjoin the enforcement of a city ordinance that prohibited the vending of ice cream on city streets.


OVERVIEW: The city enacted an ordinance that prohibited the vendor from selling its ice cream on the city streets. The vendor filed an action against the city to enjoin enforcement of the ordinance. The trial court granted judgment in favor of the vendor and issued a permanent injunction against enforcement of the ordinance on the basis that it had no real or substantial relation to public safety, health, or welfare, and that it was null and void and violative of the Constitutions of Ohio and the United States. The appellate court affirmed the judgment, and the city challenged the decision. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that the ordinance discriminated against persons of the same occupation or business. Various city ordinances licensed sellers of different goods and commodities. The ordinance was unwarranted, unreasonable, and discriminatory.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment restraining the city from enforcing an ordinance that prevented the vendor from selling ice cream on the streets.

 

307 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Baltimore & O. R. Co. v. Board of Revision


No. 31897


Supreme Court of Ohio


152 Ohio St. 521; 90 N.E.2d 574; 1950 Ohio LEXIS 557; 41 Ohio Op. 78



February 8, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The appellant, Scioto-Sandusky Conservancy District, made an assessment (92 Ohio St., 215) under Section 6828-43, General Code, on the property (Section 6828-1, General Code) of appellee, The Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Company. Appellee company filed its complaint (Section 5609, General Code) with the board of revision of Fayette county, claiming that the auditor had included the value of personal property in his valuation of the company's real property. The board of revision having acted adversely, the appellee company filed its appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals (Section 5610, General Code). The Board of Tax Appeals vacated the finding of the board of revision and made a finding purporting to ascertain and determine the true value in money of the property (Section 5611-1, General Code).

Appellant was permitted to intervene by the county board of revision. No question was raised as to the propriety thereof.

The case is in this court under Section 5611-2, General Code, which provides in part:

"If upon hearing and consideration of such record and evidence the Supreme Court is of the opinion that the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals appealed [***2] from is reasonable and lawful it shall affirm the same, but if the Supreme Court is of the opinion that such decision of the Board of Tax Appeals is unreasonable or unlawful, it shall reverse and vacate same or it may modify same and enter final judgment in accordance with such modification."



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant conservancy district challenged the finding of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) that vacated the finding of appellee board of revision and purported to ascertain the value of appellee railroad company's property. The conservancy district voted an assessment against the railroad's property under the Conservancy Act of Ohio. The railroad company challenged the constitutionality of Ohio Gen. Code § 6828-1, which defined property.


OVERVIEW: The railroad company filed a complaint with the board of revision, alleging that the conservancy district had improperly assessed taxes for the value of its personal property, rather than real property alone. The board of revision upheld the assessment, but was overruled by the board of tax appeals. The power of assessment was conferred by Ohio Gen. Code § 6828-43 on the board of directors of the conservancy district and the property assessed was limited to property as defined in Ohio Gen. Code § 6828-1. On appeal, the court ruled, upon hearing and consideration of the record and evidence, that the decision of the board of tax appeals was both unreasonable and unlawful and reversed the order. The Conservancy Act of Ohio defined and controlled exactly what property was properly assessed. Although it was proper for the county board to classify property as between that described in Ohio Gen. Code § 6828-1, within the Conservancy Act of Ohio, and property not described in that section, the court disagreed with the board of tax appeals' holding that the power of assessment was conferred on the Tax Commissioner by Ohio Gen. Code §§ 5419, 5423.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the board of tax appeals and remanded the case to the board with instructions to determine the true value in money of the "property" of the railroad, to be assessed according to law under the resolution of the board of directors of the conservancy district.

 

308 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Farrand v. State Medical Bd.


No. 31979


Supreme Court of Ohio


152 Ohio St. 429; 89 N.E.2d 571; 1949 Ohio LEXIS 384; 40 Ohio Op. 481



December 21, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin county.



DISPOSITION: Appeal dismissed.

 

309 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


O'Black v. Ohio Steel Foundry Co.


No. 31850


Supreme Court of Ohio


152 Ohio St. 367; 89 N.E.2d 301; 1949 Ohio LEXIS 365; 40 Ohio Op. 388



October 19, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [**1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Allen county.



DISPOSITION: Appeal dismissed.

 

310 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Wuebker v. Bockrath


No. 31551


Supreme Court of Ohio


152 Ohio St. 77; 87 N.E.2d 462; 1949 Ohio LEXIS 329; 39 Ohio Op. 389



June 29, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Auglaize county.

This action (which is a consolidation of two taxpayer actions) was instituted in the Court of Common Pleas of Auglaize county, seeking to enjoin the issuance of bonds by the joint township hospital district comprised of German, Jackson, Noble and St. Marys townships, Auglaize county. The trial court issued an injunction.

Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals the case was tried de novo and, upon the record there made, that court decreed that the restraining orders and injunctions theretofore allowed by the Court of Common Pleas be dissolved and that plaintiff's petitions be dismissed.

The case is in this court pursuant to an appeal as of right, a debatable constitutional question being claimed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sought review of a decree of the Court of Appeals for Auglaize County (Ohio), in a consolidation of two taxpayer actions, which dissolved the restraining orders and injunctions allowed by the Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) and dismissed the taxpayer's petition against appellee state. The taxpayers sought to enjoin the issuance of bonds by a joint township hospital district.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers' contentions were based largely upon the claim that neither exhibit "7" nor exhibit "8" should have been admitted in evidence and that without such exhibits there was nothing upon which to base the judgment of the court of appeals. The court carefully examined the various claimed defects in respect of these exhibits and found no prejudicial error in the action of the court of appeals. The taxpayers also claimed the following errors: that the corrected minutes showed that all three of the initial and interdependent resolutions were passed at the same meeting contrary to the provisions of the Uniform Bond Act; the notice of election remained ambiguous and uncertain in a material matter; the resolutions, upon which the county officials acted and upon which the election was actually held, remain uncorrected and admittedly defective in a material matter. The court ruled that all necessary resolutions were adopted and all necessary steps were taken prior to the sale of the bonds, and thereby determined and certified that substantial justice was done to the party complaining as shown by the record.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment, which dissolved the restraining orders and injunctions allowed by the trial court and which dismissed the taxpayer's petition.

 

311 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Squire v. Cleveland


Nos. 31135, 31136, 31143


Supreme Court of Ohio


150 Ohio St. 303; 82 N.E.2d 709; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 375; 38 Ohio Op. 161



November 10, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga county.

S. H. Squire, Superintendent of Banks of the State of Ohio, instituted an action in the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga county, as liquidator of The Union Trust Company and as such the holder and owner of a mortgage on certain lake-front property in the city of Cleveland. Subsequently, Union Properties, Inc., having purchased the property at foreclosure sale, was substituted as plaintiff.

The defendants which filed answers and crosspetitions in the Common Pleas Court were the city of Cleveland, The Union Salt Company (name later changed to The Lake Erie Salt Company) and Union Salt Company.

Union Properties, Inc., is the owner of a tract of land situated within the city limits of Cleveland, fronting on Lake Erie and bounded on the west by East 55th street, on the south by property owned by the New York Central Railroad Company and on the east by land owned prior to May 31, 1944, by The Union Salt Company (later The Lake Erie Salt Company) and subsequent to that date by Union Salt Company.

Union Salt Company is the owner of a tract of land also situated within the city limits of Cleveland, fronting on Lake Erie and bounded [***2] on the west by the land owned by Union Properties, Inc., on the south by property owned by the New York Central Railroad Company, and on the east by land owned by the American Steel & Wire Company.

The Lake Erie Salt Company (formerly The Union Salt Company) is an interested party in this case by reason of the fact that when it sold its property to Union Salt Company it reserved to itself any cause of action for damages or other monetary recovery which had accrued to it prior to May 31, 1944, as the result of actions of the city of Cleveland.

The original petition for injunction was filed in the Common Pleas Court on October 26, 1937. In an amended and supplemental petition, in addition to the declaratory judgment prayed for, it was sought to enjoin the city of Cleveland and others from proceeding to construct a highway from west to east across and over ground artificially created by filling into the shallow waters of Lake Erie immediately in front of the property of Union Properties, Inc., which highway, it was alleged, would permanently destroy the right of Union Properties to wharf out to navigable waters. Not only was the city of Cleveland one of the original defendants but [***3] also The Wilson Realty Company which had formerly owned the property now belonging to Union Properties.

Demurrers were filed, also amended and supplemental petitions and amendments thereto, and the case went to trial upon a second amended and supplemental petition filed April 17, 1943, and the pleadings directed thereto.

The second amended and supplemental petition alleges that Union Properties, Inc., is the owner of premises formerly owned by The Wilson Realty Company; that in 1914 its predecessor in title, The Wilson Realty Company, in order to protect and preserve the littoral rights appurtenant to its property, including the rights of navigation and to wharf out to the navigable waters of Lake Erie, commenced to fill into the shallow nonnavigable waters of the lake; and that at the time of the bringing of this action the filled land extended 700 feet from the 1914 shore line at the westerly end of its property and extended a distance of 200 feet from such shore line at the easterly end.

Union Properties, Inc., alleges further that it has the rights to use the filled land as a wharf, to wharf out beyond the filled land to the navigable waters of Lake Erie and to have access to [***4] such navigable waters to the exclusion of all persons, including the city of Cleveland; that such rights are and always have been appurtenant to its upland; that the westerly boundary of such rights is a line parallel to and 100 feet east of that found to be the westerly line of East 55th street, in a decision by the Court of Appeals of Cuyahoga county in the case of Lake Front East 55th Street Corporation v. City of Cleveland, in which decision the court found that the easterly boundary of the littoral rights appurtenant to the property owned by Lake Front East 55th Street Corporation was a line extending northerly and at right angles to the breakwater from the point where the west line of East 55th street intersected the shore line as it existed in 1925; and that the easterly boundary line of the land owned by Union Properties, Inc., is a line extending northerly from the intersection of the 1914 shore line with the easterly boundary of its upland to and at right angles to the breakwall.

The second amended and supplemental petition alleges further that the city of Cleveland asserts that Union Properties, Inc., has no right whatsoever in filled land or the waters beyond,  [***5] that there are no littoral rights appurtenant to this upland either to use the filled land as a wharf or to wharf out beyond the same, or of access to navigable waters, or of any other nature, and that therefore there are no boundaries of any such rights; that the city of Cleveland bases all such assertions upon certain statutes of the state of Ohio known as the Fleming Act (Sections 3699-a to 3699-9, General Code) and the Abele Act (Section 3699-10, General Code); that the Fleming and Abele Acts are unconstitutional and invalid, but, if valid, may not be construed to take away or deny any riparian or littoral rights otherwise than by due appropriation and compensation paid therefor; and that all the filling into the shallow waters in front of plaintiff's upland was done for the purpose of wharfing out to navigable waters of Lake Erie in aid of navigation and commerce and to preserve and protect the littoral rights appurtenant to such upland, including the right of navigation.

In the statement of its second cause of action, Union Properties, Inc., alleges that in the year 1936 the city of Cleveland, without the permission of either Union Properties, Inc., or its predecessor in [***6] title, The Wilson Realty Company, entered upon the filled land extending out from the upland of Union Properties and constructed thereon a sewer, a 100-foot wide highway, known as Cleveland East Shoreway, traversing the land in front of Union Properties' upland from the western to the eastern boundary for a distance of 1,250 feet, and a curved approach to such highway connecting it with East 55th street which extends southerly therefrom; and that in constructing and maintaining such highway the city of Cleveland interfered with, interrupted and cut off access from such upland to the navigable waters of the lake and thereby deprived Union Properties, the owner of the upland, of the use of the filled land as a wharf and cut off and interfered with the owner's use and enjoyment of the littoral right appurtenant to its upland property.

The prayer of the second amended and supplemental petition is for a declaration by the court establishing Union Properties' rights to use the filled land to wharf out and to have access to navigable waters, a declaration establishing the boundary of Union Properties' land, and an interpretation of Sections 3699-a through 3699-10, General Code (the Fleming [***7] and Abele Acts). The prayer is also for a perpetual injunction against the maintenance of the sewer and highway across the filled land in front of Union Properties' premises, and other equitable relief. In the prayer, The Union Salt Company (later The Lake Erie Salt Company) is sought to be joined as a necessary party to the establishment of Union Properties' easterly boundary line.

The city of Cleveland filed an answer and cross-petition in which it alleges that its council had under consideration for many years plans for increasing the water commerce of the port of Cleveland; that the execution of such plans had been hampered by the claimed rights of shore owners as asserted by Union Properties; that, proceeding under the city's general powers and powers granted it by Section 3699-1, General Code, and Section 19, Article I of the Ohio Constitution, its council enacted ordinance No. 103455 authorizing the construction and opening up of a waterside street on the lake side of the natural shore line of Lake Erie, across the submerged or filled lands of the state of Ohio, in the east basin of Cleveland's harbor, extending from East 9th street on the west to Gordon Park on the east;  [***8] and that the ordinance designated the purpose of the city in building the street to be to provide direct access to all piers, docks and wharves now or thereafter constructed along such harbor frontage.

The city's answer alleges further that no part of the public improvements was placed on or over any area filled in by Union Properties or its predecessor in title and denies that The Wilson Realty Company began filling in the waters of Lake Erie in front of its upland for the purpose of preserving or protecting its so-called littoral rights, but says that such filling in by that company, or which was permitted by it, was done for the purpose of making land which it hoped to add to its upland as owner thereof.

The cross-petition of the city alleges that the city plans eventually to take possession of all the filled land in front of Union Properties' upland for public uses in aid of navigation and seeks a declaration of rights, powers and liability, if any, to take or for having taken possession of part of such filled land and its right to take possession of other parts of such filled land, if it desires so to do, and a declaration of its rights and powers under the provisions of Sections [***9] 3699-1 and 3699-2, General Code.

An answer and cross-petition was filed by The Union Salt Company (later The Lake Erie Salt Company). Such answer admits most of the allegations of the petition and alleges that "the east and west line of its property extends at right angles from the upland boundary of said land to the breakwall, established by the United States government."

The cross-petition of The Union Salt Company (The Lake Erie Salt Company) alleges the construction of the shoreway by the city, the damage to the company's littoral rights as appurtenant to its upland, and that The Union Salt Company has "not caused any fill to be placed in the waters of Lake Erie nor has it in any artificial manner extended its shore line."

The prayer of The Union Salt Company (The Lake Erie Salt Company) is that the court require the city of Cleveland to institute proper appropriation proceedings, and that the littoral rights of The Union Salt Company be determined.

Union Salt Company, which, on May 31, 1944, during the pendency of this action, purchased the land formerly owned by The Union Salt Company (The Lake Erie Salt Company), filed an answer similar to the answer and cross-petition [***10] filed by The Union Salt Company.

The Wilson Realty Company was in default for answer.

There have been numerous replies and amendments to pleadings filed, none of which varies materially the issues presented by the second amended and supplemental petition and the original pleadings filed to it.

The case came on for trial in the Court of Common Pleas and the parties, in support of their claims, offered much evidence which is found in five volumes containing the printed record and numerous exhibits consisting of maps, official documents and ordinances.

The Common Pleas Court made separate findings of fact and conclusions of law. It found that a filling which made up the artificial land in front of the upland of Union Properties was done by or on account of The Wilson Realty Company, the predecessor in title of Union Properties; that the easterly and westerly boundaries of the littoral rights of Union Properties were located as set forth in the second amended and supplemental petition; that Union Properties is entitled to access to navigable waters in front of its upland; that it had and has a right to wharf out to such navigable waters for the purposes of navigation; that it has [***11] a right to use and occupy such filled land as a wharf for the purposes of navigation; and that the city of Cleveland has no right to cut off, impede or interfere with such access or use without compensation therefor.

The court found further that the sewer constructed by the city was located on filled land appurtenant to Union Properties' land; that the highway running from the west to east boundaries was constructed on filled land constituting a wharf appurtenant to Union Properties' upland; that the curved roadway connecting the highway with East 55th street was constructed upon filled land in front of Union Properties' upland; that in the construction of such highway the city had removed artificially made land of Union Properties, totaling 124,757 cubic yards; "that such works of the city of Cleveland in and upon said made land of plaintiff are not works in aid of navigation and commerce;" that the works were constructed without the permission or consent of Union Properties or its predecessor in title, and without compensating them in any amount whatsoever therefor; that these works impair, impede and interfere with access to navigable water from and to Union Properties' upland [***12] and deprive it of the use of the filled land; and that "the acts of said defendant, the city of Cleveland, in so constructing and maintaining said works without having acquired from the owner of said upland of the plaintiff the right to so construct and maintain the same, were and are unlawful."

The court held Sections 3699-a, 3699-1, 3699-2, 3699-3, 3699-4, 3699-5, 3699-6, 3699-7, 3699-8, 3699-9 and 3699-10, General Code, violative of Section 26, Article II, Section 1, Article XIII, and Section 20, Article I, Constitution of Ohio and, therefore, invalid.

The court determined that Union Properties was entitled to damages for the dirt removed and for the impairment of its littoral rights, and granted it certain rights of access over and under the highway.

The court found further that The Lake Erie Salt Company was the owner of premises formerly owned by The Union Salt Company; that the boundaries of its littoral rights were as set forth in the answer and cross-petition of The Union Salt Company (The Lake Erie Salt Company); that the land north of the 1914 shore line was artificial or filled land which resulted from filling in shallow, nonnavigable waters; that The Lake Erie Salt [***13] Company had at all times during its ownership the right to wharf out to navigable waters for purposes of navigation, the right of access to such waters and the right to take water from and to discharge water into the lake; that in constructing the highway the city of Cleveland filled in shallow nonnavigable waters in front of the upland owned by The Lake Erie Salt Company prior to May 31, 1944; that the highway constructed by the city extends from the westerly to the easterly boundaries of the littoral rights appurtenant to the upland; that such highway and fill in front of the upland are not works in aid of navigation or commerce; that they have been maintained by the city without permission or consent of The Lake Erie Salt Company; that such works impair, impede and interfere with the exercise of the littoral rights appurtenant to such upland; and that the construction thereof, without acquiring from the owner the right to construct and maintain, was unlawful.

The court determined also that The Lake Erie Salt Company was entitled to damages for such impairment and interference, accruing on or prior to May 31, 1944.

As to Union Salt Company, which purchased the land of The Lake [***14] Erie Salt Company on May 31, 1944, the court found that the easterly and westerly boundaries of its land are as found in the decision on the cross-petition of The Lake Erie Salt Company and determined that Union Salt Company was entitled to such damages as have accrued since May 31, 1944.

In its decision the Common Pleas Court located the 1914 shore line. Since the highway was completed and in general use, the court declined to enjoin its maintenance but ordered the assessment by a jury of damages accruing to Union Properties, The Lake Erie Salt Company and Union Salt Company.

An appeal was thereafter perfected on questions of law to the Court of Appeals, which made its own findings of fact and reversed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court in most material respects.

The Court of Appeals found that the 1914 shore line was the last natural shore line and determined its location to be as found by the Common Pleas Court; that the highway was constructed in front of the upland of Union Properties and Union Salt Company, on submerged or filled-in areas of the harbor; that such highway was a harbor improvement constructed by the city of Cleveland acting within its powers in aid of navigation [***15] and water commerce and in furtherance of the public trust under which the site thereof is held by the state of Ohio; that the provisions of Section 3699-2, General Code, did not apply to the fill in front of the property owned by Union Properties and Union Salt Company, because such fills must be made for and useable in furtherance of navigation or fisheries or other public uses to which the site thereof is adapted; that Union Properties and Union Salt Company, because of such fills and the construction of the roadway and other improvements in front of their respective uplands, have lost their advantage of access to the waters of Lake Erie; and that Section 3699-10, General Code, does not apply and does not add to or lessen public and private rights defined by Section 3699-a, General Code, and that, therefore, it was unnecessary to determine the constitutionality of Section 3699-10, General Code.

The Court of Appeals held further that so far as Union Properties and Union Salt Company may have any rights under Section 3699-a, General Code, the boundaries of such littoral rights are as found by the Common Pleas Court, and further granted them the right to cross, underpass or [***16] overpass the shoreway highway and to take water from and return water to Lake Erie.

From the judgment of the Court of Appeals three motions to certify the record were filed in this court. In case No. 31135 the appellant is Union Properties, Inc., and the appellees are the city of Cleveland, The Union Salt Company and The Lake Erie Salt Company. In case No. 31136 the appellant is Union Salt Company and the appellees are Union Properties, Inc., the city of Cleveland and The Lake Erie Salt Company. In case No. 31143 the appellant is The Lake Erie Salt Company and the appellees are the city of Cleveland, Union Properties, Inc., and Union Salt Company.

The case is before this court on the allowance of all three motions.

Further facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) that found that a road or shoreway was constructed by appellee city over the filled lands of appellants in aid of navigation and water commerce and that therefore pursuant to the Fleming Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 3699-1 to 3699-9, the city was not required to compensate appellants for any interference with its upland or littoral rights.


OVERVIEW: Appellant property owners challenged the court of appeals' reversal of an award of damages against appellee city for the impairment, impediment, and interference with their water access and the deprivation of a wharf and its use, as the result of the city's construction of a shoreway or road over filled land on appellants' property. The court of appeals held that the findings of the trial court were against the weight of the evidence and held that the Fleming Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 3699-1 to 3699-9, enabled the city to construct a road across the made land in front of appellants' land, whether or not such road was in aid of navigation and water commerce, without compensating appellants. On appeal, the court held that the court of appeals rendered a final judgment without the authority to do so because a remand to the trial court was necessary when the court of appeals reversed a judgment as against the weight of the evidence. The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment and remanded to the trial court for a retrial, which was what the court of appeals was required to do.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment and remanded to the trial court for retrial because the court of appeals was required to remand when it reversed a judgment as against the weight of the evidence. The court held there was conflicting evidence regarding whether appellant property owners had filled their land, whether the fill constituted a wharf, and whether appellee city constructed the road in aid of navigation.

 

312 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Kocsorak v. Cleveland Trust Co.


No. 31545


Supreme Court of Ohio


150 Ohio St. 437; 83 N.E.2d 70; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 394; 38 Ohio Op. 333



November 10, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [**1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lorain county.



DISPOSITION: Appeal dismissed.

 

313 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Hackley v. Edmonds


No. 31409


Supreme Court of Ohio


150 Ohio St. 203; 80 N.E.2d 769; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 365; 37 Ohio Op. 474



July 28, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action originating in this court, and the question arises by a general demurrer by the respondent to the petition of the relator, which demurrer tests the sufficiency of the petition to state a cause of action.

The petition recites that the relator is a duly qualified elector and taxpayer of the city of Hamilton, and that he brings the action for himself and other electors and taxpayers, on behalf of the city, the solicitor of the city having refused to institute an action upon the written demand of relator.

The petition recites further that in the year 1926 the city of Hamilton adopted a charter, pursuant to the Constitution of Ohio, and that such charter is now in full force and effect.

The charter provides, inter alia, that the council shall consist of seven members, who shall be elected by means of the proportional representation system; that the terms of the members of council shall be for two years; and that if a vacancy occurs in the council, except as the result of a recall election, such vacancy shall be filled by an eligible person named by the remaining members of council.

The petition recites further that the charter contains the following [***2] provisions:

"The Recall.

"Recall Petition Papers.

"Section 146. A member of the council may be removed from office by the electors of the city. The procedure for effecting such a removal shall be as follows:

"Any elector of the city may make and file with the city clerk an affidavit stating the name of the member whose removal is sought and the grounds alleged for such removal. The clerk shall thereupon deliver to the elector making the affidavit copies of petition papers for demanding such a removal, printed copies of which he shall keep on file for distribution as herein provided. In issuing any such petition paper the clerk shall enter in a record to be kept in his office the name of the elector to whom issued, the date of issuance, the number of papers issued, and shall certify upon each such paper the name of the elector to whom issued and the date of issuance. No petition paper shall be accepted as part of a petition unless it bears such certificate of the clerk and unless filed as hereinafter provided.

"Filing Recall Petition.

"Section 147. A petition demanding the removal of a member of the council shall be known as a recall petition. A recall petition to be effective [***3] must be returned and filed with the city clerk within 30 days after the filing of the affidavit as provided in the next preceding section, and to be sufficient must bear the signatures of electors of the city equal in number to at least fifteen per centum (15%) of those who voted at the last preceding regular municipal election. A recall petition, if insufficient as originally filed, may be amended as provided in this charter.

"Recall Election Ordered.

"Section 148. If a recall petition, or amended petition, shall be certified by the city clerk to be sufficient he shall at once submit it to the council with his certificate to that effect and shall notify the member whose removal is sought of such action. If the member of the council whose removal is sought does not resign within five days after such notice the council shall thereupon order and fix a day for holding a recall election. Any such election shall be held not less than forty nor more than sixty days after the petition has been presented to the council, and at the same time as any other general or special election held within such period; but, if no such election is to be held within such period, the council shall call [***4] a special recall election to be held within the time aforesaid.

"Candidates to Succeed Member Recalled.

"Section 149. The question of recalling any number of members of the council may be submitted at the same election, but as to each member whose removal is sought a separate petition shall be filed and provision shall be made for an entirely separate ballot. Candidates to succeed any member of the council whose removal is sought shall be placed in nomination by petition, signed, filed and verified as provided for nominating petitions for a regular municipal election; except that each petition paper shall specify that the candidate named therein is a candidate to succeed a particular member of the council whose removal is sought.

"Ballots in Recall Elections.

"Section 150. Ballots used at recall election shall conform to the following requirements:

"With respect to the member of the council whose removal is sought the question shall be submitted, 'Shall (name of person) be removed from the council by recall?' Immediately below such question there shall be printed on the ballots the two following propositions, one above the other, in the order here indicated:

"'For the recall [***5] of (name of person).

"'Against the recall of (name of person).'

"Immediately at the left of each proposition there shall be a square in which the elector by making a cross mark (X) may vote for either of such propositions. Under the proposition shall appear the words, 'Candidates to succeed (name of person) if recalled,' and beneath such words the directions to voters required to be printed on the ballots for a regular election of members of the council. Following the direction to voters the names of candidates shall be printed on the ballots in rotation as provided for a regular municipal election. The name of the member of the council whose removal is sought shall not appear on the ballot as a candidate to succeed himself.

"Result of Recall Election.

"Section 151. If a majority of the votes cast on the question of recalling a member of the council shall be against his recall he shall continue in office for the remainder of his unexpired term, but subject to recall as before. If a majority of such votes be for the recall of the member indicated on the ballots he shall, regardless of any defect in the recall petition, be deemed removed from office. When a member of the council [***6] is removed from office by recall the candidate to succeed such member, declared elected after counting the votes in the manner provided by this charter for a regular election, shall succeed the member so removed for the unexpired term.

"Election When Member Resigns.

"Section 152. If a member of the council in regard to whom a sufficient recall petition is submitted to the council shall resign within five days after notice thereof, the election shall be held as hereinbefore provided except that all propositions in regard to the recall shall be omitted from the ballots and that above the names of the candidates and before the direction to the voters, shall appear the words, 'Candidates to succeed (name of person) resigned.'

"Limitations on Recall Petitions.

"Section 153. No recall petition shall be filed against a member of the council within three months after he takes office, nor in case of a member subjected to a recall election and not removed thereby, until at least six months after that election."

The petition recites further that on March 8, 1948, the relator filed with the respondent, the clerk of the city of Hamilton, the following affidavit:

"State of Ohio, Butler County,  [***7] SS:

"K. Lewis Hackley, being first duly sworn, deposes and says that he is an elector of the city of Hamilton, Butler county, Ohio; that he makes and presents this affidavit pursuant to Sections 146 to 153, inclusive, of the charter of said city of Hamilton, Ohio, for the purpose of seeking and initiating a recall election of Edward Beckett as a member of council of the city of Hamilton, Ohio, and his possible removal from said office and the election of his successor in such office, all in accordance with the provisions of said charter.

"As grounds for such recall election or removal from office, affiant says that said Edward Beckett has violated the pledges which he made to the electorate of the city of Hamilton in the course of his campaign for election to said office; has departed from, and performed in office contrary to, the representations which he made to the electorate of said city whereby he sought election to said office; has circumvented the desires and purposes and betrayed the interests of the electors of said city by whose votes he was elected to said office; his conduct in said office has been inimical to the welfare and best interests of the city of Hamilton and [***8] of its citizens. Affiant believes, and therefore states, that the majority of the electors of said municipality desire the recall and removal of said Edward Beckett from said office.

"Therefore, the affiant hereby requests that the clerk of said city issue and deliver to him, forthwith, proper recall petition papers, in accordance with the provisions of said charter."

"K. Lewis Hackley."

(Oath omitted.)


The petition recites further that, on presentation of such affidavit to respondent, he refused, and has at all times since refused, to issue to relator any recall petitions or papers as provided for in the charter of the city of Hamilton.

Relator prays for a writ of mandamus directing respondent to issue to relator such recall petition forms or papers as provided for in such charter.

The respondent claims the recall provisions of the charter are in conflict with Section 38, Article II of the Constitution.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action by plaintiff relator against defendant city clerk the Supreme Court of Ohio considered the relator's request for a writ of mandamus issuing the clerk to deliver recall petition forms and papers so that a member of the city council might be recalled through popular vote.


OVERVIEW: The relator, a taxpayer, hoped to recall a certain city council member and requested recall petition forms from the city clerk accordingly. The city clerk failed to deliver such forms and claimed that the recall provisions of the city charter violated Ohio Const. art. II, § 38. Essentially, the city clerk was claiming that only for reasons specified under the Constitution were city council members to be recalled. The court analyzed the issue by looking to various constitutional provisions and held that the selection of municipal officers was a matter of purely local concern, and that the method of their selection and the tenure of their office could legally be limited or circumscribed by the provisions of a municipal charter adopted in pursuance of Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 7. Thus, the city's recall charter provision was simply a device which the people of the city saw fit to write into their charter, by which the councilman could be called to the test of a popular vote as to his right to continue in office. The court granted the requested writ accordingly.


OUTCOME: The court issued the relator's requested writ of mandamus directing the city clerk to deliver to relator the recall petition forms and papers, as prayed for.

 

314 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


New Orphans' Asylum of Colored Children v. Board of Tax Appeals


No. 31078


Supreme Court of Ohio


150 Ohio St. 219; 80 N.E.2d 761; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 366; 37 Ohio Op. 470



July 28, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

This is an appeal from a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals denying an application to exempt from taxation certain real property belonging to the New Orphans' Asylum of Colored Children of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, Ohio, appellant herein, hereinafter called the asylum, and an application for remission of taxes and penalties thereon.

The facts are not in dispute. The asylum is a corporation chartered by special act of the General Assembly in the year 1845. The asylum has rented the property in question to others and has used the rental income therefrom for the maintenance of the asylum.

The stipulation of facts reads as follows:

"(1) The net income of the property in question in these proceedings is and uniformly has been used solely for the support of the New Orphans' Asylum of Colored Children, an institution used exclusively for a children's home for poor children.

"(2) The New Orphans' Asylum of Colored Children has never at any time paid taxes on the property in question. Prior to the tax year 1933, the lessee of the property paid taxes thereon. In 1933, for the first time taxes on this property were assessed against the applicant [***2] [asylum]. That action led to the application whose denial resulted in this complaint. Neither before nor since 1933 has the New Orphans' Asylum of Colored Children paid any taxes on this property.

"(3) This stipulation may be made a part of the record in these proceedings."

In April 1946, the asylum filed with the county auditor of Hamilton county an application for exemption of this property from taxation for the year 1946 and an application for remission of taxes and penalties thereon, amounting to $ 5,821.23, both applications being based upon the provisions of Section 5353-1, General Code. On the hearing thereon, it was contended further by the asylum that the property in question was also exempt by reason of section 8 of its charter (hereinafter referred to as section 8). Section 8 recites "that all property belonging to said corporation shall be exempt from taxation by any law of this state."

The Board of Tax Appeals denied the applications, stating in its entry of denial that "the Board is more than doubtful of the constitutionality of * * * Section 5353-1, General Code, in view of the decision of the Supreme Court of Ohio in tax exemption matters," and held further [***3] that the board had no jurisdiction to hear the applications so far as they are predicated on section 8.

The asylum has appealed to this court pursuant to Section 5611-2, General Code, contending that the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals is unreasonable and unlawful.



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant asylum sought review of the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which denied the asylum's applications for tax exemptions on certain property, questioned the constitutionality of Ohio Gen. Code § 5353-1, and held that it had no jurisdiction to hear the applications.


OVERVIEW: The asylum applied for a tax exemption on certain property which it owned and rented, but used the net income therefrom for maintenance of the asylum. The asylum was denied an exemption. The court reversed. The court held that § 5353-1, which exempted the asylum's property, was unconstitutional because the general assembly's power to exempt real property was limited by Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2, and it had been established that when real estate was used for rental purposes, the right to exemption was forfeited even if the proceeds were used for charitable purposes. The court held, however, that the Board should have considered the appeal because pursuant to Ohio Gen. Code §§ 1464-1, 5570-1, and 5579, the Board necessarily had the authority to determine whether or not the asylum was not delinquent where it was allowed to determine who was delinquent. The court also held that the asylum was entitled to an exemption under § 8 of its charter because it obtained its charter by special act of the general assembly, and the charter was obtained prior to the enactment of Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2; therefore the contract rights of the asylum could not be affected by the later constitution.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the Board and remanded the case to the Board for further proceedings.

 

315 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Beck v. Hummel


Nos. 31496, 31498


Supreme Court of Ohio


150 Ohio St. 127; 80 N.E.2d 899; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 360; 37 Ohio Op. 435



July 22, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

APPEAL from the Secretary of State.

These two cases are so interrelated that they are considered together.

Case No. 31496 is an action in mandamus originating in this court, and case No. 31498 is an appeal from a finding of the Secretary of State, pursuant to Section 4785-100a, General Code.

On April 6, 1948, the Ohio Wallace-for-President Committee, an unincorporated, independent group of citizens of Ohio, filed with the Secretary of State an affidavit which stated, inter alia, that the group does not advocate, either directly or indirectly, the overthrow by force or violence of our local, state or national government; and that it does not carry on any program of sedition or treason by radio, speech or press.

The Secretary of State, pursuant to Section 4785-100a, General Code, certified that this group is not entitled to have a place on the presidential ballot in the election of 1948. There was an appeal from the finding of the Secretary of State to this court, in case No. 31498, and such case is here as a matter of right.

On June 10, 1948, the 25 relators, in case No. 31496, filed a petition for a writ of mandamus against respondent Edward J. Hummel [***2] as Secretary of State and chief election officer of the state.

The petition recites that respondent as chief election officer is the official with whom petitions are filed, which nominate candidates whose elections are to be determined by the electors of the state at large, and who is charged by law with the duty of supervising and processing such petitions and placing on the ballots the names of those duly nominated as candidates for state offices; that the relators are each possessed of the qualifications of an elector and are electors of the state; that a general election will be held in Ohio on November 2, 1948, when, together with other officers, 25 presidential electors of the state for 1948 will be elected by the voters of the state at large; and that the duties of the presidential electors who are elected are to meet in the state capitol at noon on a day designated by the Congress of the United States for the purpose of voting by ballot for president and vice-president of the United States for the term commencing in 1949, to make, sign and certify a list of all the persons voted for, the number of votes for each, and to transmit the list to the president of the United States [***3] Senate in Washington, D. C.

The petition recites further that petitions have been circulated among the electors of Ohio to nominate relators and each of them as independent candidates for election to the offices of presidential electors to vote for Henry A. Wallace for president and Glen H. Taylor for vice-president, each of whom resides in a state other than Ohio and who are constitutionally eligible to be elected to those offices.

The petition recites further that the aforesaid nominating petitions were tendered to respondent on June 10, 1948, accompanied by the written acceptance of the nominations by the relators and each of them as independent candidates for the offices of the 25 presidential electors of Ohio in 1948; and that such petitions indicate thereon that the relators and each of them were being nominated to vote for and as representatives of the candidacies of Wallace for president and Taylor for vice-president.

The petition recites further that the nominating petitions comply with all the provisions of Section 4785-91, General Code, and that respondent refused to accept and file such petitions and transmit separate petition papers to the proper county boards of elections [***4] in order that such boards might examine and determine the validity of the signatures on the petition papers.

The petition recites further that respondent refused to accept, file and process such nominating petitions because the statutes prohibit the placing on the presidential ballot or any other ballot at the general election to be held November 2, 1948, the names of candidates for president and vice-president or the candidates for presidential electors representing candidates, unless the candidates for president and vice-president were nominated as candidates for election to those offices by national conventions of political parties to which delegates or alternates were elected at the next preceding primary election, and unless the candidates for presidential electors in Ohio are nominated as candidates for such offices at a state convention of a political party (pursuant to Section 4785-74, General Code).

The petition recites further that independent candidates for presidential electors of Ohio may be nominated pursuant to Section 4785-91, General Code.

The petition recites further that if it be held that the election laws of Ohio do not permit the nomination of any candidates [***5] for election as presidential electors except those of the Democratic or Republican parties, such laws are unreasonable, arbitrary and violative of Section 2, Article I, Section 1, Article V, and Section 4, Article XV of the Constitution of Ohio, and the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.

The petition prays for a writ of mandamus commanding the respondent to accept and file the nominating petitions of the presidential electors of Ohio tendered to him and to promptly transmit separate petition papers to the proper county boards of elections for action in accordance with Section 4785-92, General Code, and, if the nominating petitions comply with the statutes, commanding the respondent to place the names of Henry A. Wallace and Glen H. Taylor as independent candidates for the offices of president and vice-president of the United States on the official presidential ballot of the state of Ohio; that a vote for such candidates be counted and considered as a vote for each of the relators herein as candidates for election as presidential electors of the state for 1948; and that the court grant such other and further or alternative relief as is necessary [***6] and proper to fully protect the rights of the relators herein and of all other citizens of the state of Ohio and the United States of America.

By leave of court the petition was amended by adding to the prayer thereof, the following:

"including a writ commanding the respondent to accept, file and process said nominating petitions and print on the proper ballot at the general election of November 2, 1948, the names of the relators as independent candidates for presidential electors."

The respondent filed an answer in which he admits every essential allegation in plaintiff's petition. However, he states that his refusal to accept and file the nominating petitions and transmit the same to the various boards of elections was for the reason that the relators are not entitled to be nominated to the offices of presidential electors of Ohio for 1948, and that Henry A. Wallace and Glen H. Taylor are not entitled to a place on the presidential ballot to be voted at the general election to be held in Ohio on November 2, 1948, because neither the relators nor the group of which they are or claim to be members has complied with the requirements of Section 4785-100a, General Code, and for [***7] the further reason that there are no provisions of law in Ohio under the authority of which the nomination of independent candidates for election to the offices of president and vice-president of the United States and presidential electors can be effectuated by nominating petitions.

The relators filed a reply in which they deny that they or the group of which they are members has not complied with the requirements of Section 4785-100a, General Code, and allege that such section was duly complied with by them, and that an appeal pursuant to such section was duly taken to this court from the finding of respondent that the group of which the relators are members is not entitled, pursuant to such section, to have a place on the November 2, 1948, election ballot.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed in case No. 31496. Finding reversed in case No. 31498.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant election committee sought review of a decision by appellee Secretary of State certifying that the committee was not entitled to have a place on the Ohio presidential ballot in the election of 1948. In a separate action, the committee, as relator, filed a petition for a writ of mandamus commanding the Secretary to place the names of independent candidates for the offices of president and vice-president on the presidential ballot.


OVERVIEW: An independent election committee filed suit challenging the findings of the Secretary of State (Secretary) certifying that the committee's group was not entitled to have a place on the presidential ballot because certain members were alleged to belong to the communist party. The committee filed a petition for a writ of mandamus commanding the Secretary to place the names of independent candidates for the offices of president and vice-president on the ballot. The court reversed and set aside the findings of the Secretary and concluded that the fact that three members of the group belonged to the communist party, if true, without any showing that they personally advocated the overthrow of the U.S. government by force, did not destroy or impair the effect of the committee's affidavit to get a place on the ballot. The court granted in part the committee's writ petition and commanded the Secretary to accept and file the committee's nominating petition for presidential electors. The court held that the signers of the nominating petition had prima facie placed the committee in nomination for presidential electors, irrespective of their ability to nominate independent candidates.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and set aside the findings of the Secretary of State excluding the independent election committee from having a place on the Ohio presidential ballot in the election of 1948. The court granted in part the committee's petition for a writ of mandamus and commanded the Secretary of State and chief election officer to accept and file the committee's nominating petition for presidential electors of the state of Ohio.

 

316 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Frohner


No. 31287


Supreme Court of Ohio


150 Ohio St. 53; 80 N.E.2d 868; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 357; 37 Ohio Op. 406



July 21, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning county.

In pursuance of their plan to steal an automobile to be used in the kidnaping of another boy, appellant Donald E. Frohner and Arthur N. Chapman, on Monday, January 13, 1947, went to a point outside the city of Youngstown, where they thumbed a ride from one William C. Spieth. Chapman entered the Spieth automobile and sat beside Spieth while appellant Frohner got in the back seat with a brief case in which he was carrying a 38-caliber revolver, loaded, and a blackjack, both to be used in the obtaining of the automobile, license plates to be substituted for the license plates on the automobile to be stolen, two pairs of pliers with which to change the license plates, and two ransom notes (one typewritten and one pencil block printed) to be sent to the father of the boy to be kidnaped that evening. A meeting with such boy had been arranged for that evening.

The decedent, Spieth, was 5 feet 8 inches in height and weighed 143 pounds, while appellant Frohner was 5 feet 11 inches in height and weighed 153 pounds. The record does not show the height of Chapman but does show "well built, fairly well nourished, white, male patient, 17 [***2] years of age, weight 135 pounds."

Spieth was asked to stop the car as the boys wanted to get out. As Spieth slowed down his automobile, Frohner ordered him to get out and upon his failure to obey the order, Frohner struck Spieth over the head with a blackjack and then shot him twice in the back with the revolver, killing him. Chapman tried but failed to start the automobile.

Observing the approach of a Greyhound bus from around a bend in the road, the boys became frightened, abandoned the automobile and started running across a field.

A deputy sheriff, assigned to investigate the homicide, apprehended Frohner and Chapman that same evening and took them to the Mahoning county jail where they were confined to that part of the jail set aside for juveniles.

That same evening, in the presence of Frederic T. O'Connor, a member of the Youngstown police force especially assigned to the juvenile department and working out of Juvenile Judge Beckenbach's court, the deputy sheriff, an assistant prosecuting attorney and others, Frohner and Chapman made and signed the following confessions written by O'Connor, to wit:$§$§$§

"Jan. 14, 1947

"County jail$§$§$§$§

"My name is Donald [***3] Edward Frohner 16 years of age born in Youngstown O. May 9, 1930 I live at 1005 Glenwood ave. with my father, Theodore, mother Lorena and brother Theodore, Jr. age 21. On Jan. 13, 1947 I got out of school South High at 2:45 p. m. and along with Arthur Ned Chapman decided to steal a car, we had made up our minds to this last Sunday Jan 12th I got a 38 special police revolver from my dad's bedroom of which was his gun, and took it to school with me, and had it in my locker, I told Art that I had the gun, and that we would use it to get a guy out of a car. We took the bus downtown and then went to the bus arcade and got a Canfield bus, paid 35c for a one way ticket, this bus went out to Austintown then south on Rt 46 to Canfield, arrived in Canfield about 4 o'clock, and started out of Canfield towards Austintown, hitched a ride to where Rt. 62 turns off of 46 in a 1941 Ford Cp. three of us in the one seat. Then we started walking along Rt 62 towards Youngstown, when another car 1940 Ford 2 door sedan came along, with only the driver in it, I got in the rear seat and Arthur in the front seat, after riding with this man along Rt 62 for about a mile, I told him we wanted to get out and [***4] for him to slow down, when he stopped I pulled the gun on him and ordered him out of the car, he wouldn't leave but put up a struggle, and I struck him on the head with the gun, and he continued to struggle so I shot him twice, we both got out of the car and started to run. There was a Greyhound bus approaching from Youngstown, we started thru the field and then in the woods until it was dark then we came out on the highway where we were picked up by the sheriff, I hid the gun in the woods near the Terrace Gardens.

"This statement was given of my own free will and without any threats or promises and may be used in court either for or against me.

"I have read the foregoing statement of 2 pages and is true to the best of my knowledge.$§$§$§

"[signed] Donald Edward Frohner$§$§$§$§

"Witnesses:

"John R. Hooker

"Sheriff Ralph E. Elser

"Det. Frederic T. O'Connor Juvenile Division Ys. Police Dept.

"Written by [Frederic T. O'Connor]"$§$§$§

"Jan. 13, 1947

"County jail

"Youngstown, Ohio$§$§$§$§

"My name is Arthur Ned Chapman I am 17 years of age born in New Castle, Pa. Sept. 23, 1929 I live at 565 Willis ave. Youngstown Ohio with my father 'Ned' and stepmother [***5] -- half brother age 8 months and half sister 4 years old.

"Today I got out of South High School at 2:45 p. m. and along with Don Frohner age 16 1005 Glenwood ave. decided to go out and steal a car -- Last Sunday Jan. 12th we had made up our minds to get a car and take it over to New Castle Pa. and hide it, then when things got quiet, we could go over and drive it around. Don said he had a gun and brought it to school today, we were going to use it to get a car.

"We rode the bus downtown and then out on Mahoning bus to the end of the line Meridian rd. We then hitched a ride in a 1946 Ford and rode to Austintown where it turned south on Rt. 46 towards Canfield, the reason we didn't get this car was because there were two men in it. When we got to the intersection of Rt. 62 and 46 we asked the men to leave us out, about 10 minutes after we got out another car came along and we hitched a ride with him, he drove east on Rt. 62 and after riding about 5 minutes, we told him we were going to get out so he would slow the car down, he started slowing the car down, and Don hit him on the head, and I grabbed the wheel and turned off the ignition and we coasted to a stop, while we were coasting [***6] to a stop this man started fighting with us, then Don shot him, the man was stunned before he got shot, after Don shot him the bus came along. I was trying to start the car, reaching my legs over his to get my foot on the starter, did not get the car started, we both got out of the car and started running thru the fields, I thot Don only shot him once but I guess it was twice, Don said come on hurry up let's get away, after we were in the woods quite a while afterwards Don threw the gun in the leaves and covered it up.

"This statement was given of my own free will without any threats or promises, and may be used in court as evidence either for or against me.

"I have read the foregoing statement and it is true to the best of my knowledge.$§$§$§

"[signed] Arthur N. Chapman.$§$§$§$§

"Witnesses

"Sheriff Ralph E. Elser

"John R. Hooker, Asst. Prosecuting Atty.

"Det. Frederic T. O'Connor Juvenile Dept. Ys. Police"

In compliance with Section 1639-32, General Code, the judge of the Juvenile Court made an investigation and received the following reports under date of January 16, 1947, from Dr. Eugene E. Elder, superintendent of Youngstown Receiving Hospital, and Corinne F.  [***7] Baker, psychologist:

"The following is a repo



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's conviction of defendant for first-degree murder.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and his accomplice, both minors, attempted to steal a car for use in a kidnapping. Defendant ultimately shot and killed the car's driver. The defendant initially pled not guilty but later changed his plea to guilty and waived his right to a jury trial. On appeal, defendant attacked his guilty plea and his waiver of a jury trial, among other things. The court held that no objections, either on policy grounds or constitutional grounds, could be found to Ohio Gen. Code §§, 13442-4, 13442-5, which gave defendants the right to waive jury trials. The court also held that the trial court properly explained defendant's rights to him, that defendant's decision to waive a jury trial was arrived at after much deliberation with his family and attorney, and that defendant had an intelligent understanding of the effect of the withdrawal of his plea of not guilty and his waiver of a jury trial.
