The court noted that the defendant could not plead guilty and waive his right to a jury in the hope that he would receive mercy in his sentencing and then later claim ignorance when his gamble failed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the appellate court, which affirmed defendant's conviction for murder.

 

317 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Parker


No. 31360


Supreme Court of Ohio


150 Ohio St. 22; 80 N.E.2d 490; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 352; 37 Ohio Op. 318



June 23, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit county.

An indictment was returned by the grand jury of Summit county against Murray S. Parker, the several counts whereof vary only as to the date of the claimed violation.

Without the formal parts and the date, each count charges "that Murray S. Parker * * * unlawfully and publicly did establish, open, set on foot, carry on and promote as the owners thereof, a certain scheme of chance, commonly called 'Keno,' contrary to the form of the statute in such case made and provided, and against the peace and dignity of the state of Ohio."

Issue was made by demurrer, the ground stated therefor being "for the reason that the facts stated in said indictment do not constitute an offense punishable by the laws of this state."

The Court of Common Pleas sustained the demurrer, overruled the motion of the state to amend the indictment and discharged the defendant.

Upon appeal on questions of law the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment.

The case is in this court following an allowance of the motion for certification of the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State appealed from the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgment, which sustained defendant's demurrer to an indictment charging defendant with unlawfully establishing and promoting a scheme of chance, overruled the motion of the State to amend the indictment, and discharged defendant.


OVERVIEW: Defendant demurred on the ground that the indictment did not constitute a punishable offense because did not allege that the scheme of chance was "for his own profit." The trial court sustained the demurrer, overruled the State's motion to amend the indictment, and discharged defendant. On appeal the court affirmed, holding that: (1) Ohio Rev. Stat. § 13064 did not violate any provision of the Ohio Constitution because it was in harmony with Ohio Const. art. XV, § 6 in that it did not authorize or give validity to any gambling transaction and it imposed a fine and imprisonment upon anyone who engaged in any of the enumerated transactions "for his own profit"; (2) use of the word "unlawfully" in the indictment did not cure the omission of the "for his own profit" language omitted from the indictment because the word "unlawfully" stated a mere conclusion and was not synonymous with the words "for his own profit"; and (3) leave to amend the indictment by inserting the words "for his own profit" was properly refused because the indictment could not be cured by amendment since a vital and material element identifying or characterizing the offense was omitted from the indictment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment affirming the trial court's judgment sustaining defendant's demurrer and overruling the State's motion to amend the indictment.

 

318 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland v. Terrill


No. 31109


Supreme Court of Ohio


149 Ohio St. 532; 80 N.E.2d 115; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 519; 37 Ohio Op. 248



June 2, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga county.

Clyde Terrill, defendant, appellee herein, hereinafter called the defendant, was arrested on an affidavit charging that on or about September 27, 1946, he unlawfully had in his possession a side of beef which did not bear the official stamp of the government inspector or of the city inspector of Cleveland, Ohio, contrary to an ordinance of such city (Section 794-1, Cleveland Municipal Code). Defendant was tried in the Municipal Court of Cleveland, found guilty and fined $ 100 and costs.

Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals, the conviction was reversed on the ground that Section 794-1, Cleveland Municipal Code, is unconstitutional.

The case is before this court following the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The City of Cleveland appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which reversed defendant's conviction for possessing beef that had not been inspected in violation of Cleveland, Ohio, Mun. Code § 794-1.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted in the trial court of possessing beef that had not been inspected in violation of § 794-1. The appellate court reversed defendant's conviction, holding that § 794-1 was unconstitutional. On appeal, the court reversed the appellate court's judgment and affirmed defendant's conviction. The court held that municipalities had the authority pursuant to Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3 to adopt and enforce such local police, sanitary, and other regulations as were not in conflict with general laws. The court determined that the preservation of the public health by the inspection of food was a legitimate exercise of police power. The court rejected defendant's contention that Cleveland, Ohio, Mun. Code § 794-1 was unreasonable because it criminalized the mere possession of meat that had not been inspected. The court ruled that § 794-1 was enacted to preserve the public health of the city. The court held that § 794-1 was not clearly an unreasonable exercise of police power. The court determined that the failure of § 794-1 to define the term "meat" did not render the statute unconstitutional because the term was defined in the city's health code.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for possessing beef that had not been inspected. The court reversed the appellate court's judgment reversing defendant's conviction.

 

319 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Indian Hill Acres, Inc. v. Kellogg


No. 31139


Supreme Court of Ohio


149 Ohio St. 461; 79 N.E.2d 319; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 482; 37 Ohio Op. 137



May 5, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton county.

This case originated in the Court of Appeals for Hamilton county.

The relator, Indian Hill Acres, Inc., is a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the state of Ohio, having its principal office and place of business in Cincinnati, Ohio.

The respondent C. A. Eberling is the superintendent of the waterworks of the city of Cincinnati and as such superintendent is in charge of the administration thereof. The respondent W. R. Kellogg is city manager of the city of Cincinnati and as such is the chief executive and administrative officer of the city and has general supervision and control over respondent Eberling.

The relator is engaged in the business of acquiring and developing land for residential purposes, and, at the time of the filing of the petition herein, it had platted and developed, from 226 acres of land which it owned, a subdivision known as Indian Hill Acres Subdivision in Hamilton county and in the vicinity of the city of Cincinnati. This subdivision consists of 88 acres of land divided into building lots, some of which have been sold, but most of which are still owned by the relator.

This subdivision [***2] is bounded on the east side by Miami road, and several roadways have been constructed within the limits of the subdivision to provide entrance to the numerous lots not contiguous to Miami road.

This subdivision lies within Sanitary Sewer District No. 1 of Hamilton county, Ohio, for which district the commissioners of Hamilton county established a water distribution system in 1925. As a part of such water distribution system the county commissioners caused a 16-inch water main to be laid in Miami road, which main extends the entire length of relator's frontage of land on Miami road, and assessed the real estate within the boundary of the water distribution system for the cost of such improvement.

This water main, together with other mains constructed as parts of the water distribution system, was connected with the water distribution system of the city of Cincinnati. Under a contract with the county commissioners, dated April 24, 1926, the city of Cincinnati agreed to furnish surplus water from its waterworks to certain water distribution systems established by the county commissioners, among which systems was Sanitary Sewer District No. 1. On October 10, 1930, a similar contract [***3] was entered into between the same parties for a period ending May 29, 1946, which contract rescinded and superseded the former contract.

In August 1946, the relator completed the construction of water main extensions along the three streets serving the subdivision. These main extensions were 6 inches in diameter and terminated at the 16-inch main located in Miami road. Plans for these water main extensions had been submitted to the waterworks department of the city of Cincinnati and had been approved by it on or prior to May 18, 1946, and prior to the termination of the contract of the city with the commissioners of Hamilton county.

In August 1946, the relator applied to the waterworks department of the city of Cincinnati to have these extensions connected with the main in Miami road so that these extension mains would become a part of and be served by the water distribution system of the county. The waterworks department of the city of Cincinnati did not grant this application for the reason that, by the provisions of an ordinance of the city of Cincinnati, designated ordinance No. 164-1946 and in effect on May 29, 1946, the city of Cincinnati had provided "that water shall not [***4] be furnished to any extension of existing mains outside the city." That ordinance provides further that under certain conditions the city manager is authorized to submit to council, for its approval, any case in which he feels that the denial of water service will result in great hardship, or he may submit the application of an owner desiring service who has indicated that he is willing that his land be annexed to the city of Cincinnati within a reasonable time after the granting of such service.

The city manager, complying with the above ordinance, submitted to council of the city of Cincinnati the application of the relator and stated that, in his opinion, denial of water service to these water main extensions was apt to result in great hardship and might result in serious economic disadvantage to the community in which the subdivision is located. On November 13, 1946, the council declined to adopt the ordinance so recommended by the city manager.

Thereafter, the relator demanded of respondent Kellogg that he instruct the city waterworks department to connect the relator's water main extensions to the main in Miami road, which the respondent city manager refused to do.

Thereafter [***5] the relator commenced this action in mandamus, alleging that the city of Cincinnati, by voluntarily electing to sell its surplus water to consumers located in Sanitary Sewer District No. 1 under contracts with the county commissioners of Hamilton county, assumed the same duty to the public comprising this water district as a public service corporation would have assumed under a franchise granted by the county commissioners, namely, to serve the public in this district without discrimination; that the provisions of ordinance No. 164-1946, so far as they prohibit the city manager from supplying surplus water to the water main extensions constructed by the relator, are unreasonably discriminatory against the relator and persons desiring to receive water by means of such water main extensions and are contrary to Sections 2 and 19 of Article I of the Constitution of Ohio and the 14th Amendment to the Constitution of the United States; that the city of Cincinnati, by permitting water main extensions outside the city limits to be attached to county water distribution systems supplied with water by the city only upon condition that the owners of such water main extensions execute and file [***6] with the city manager annexation agreements, is unlawfully discriminating against the relator and consumers served by such extensions.

Relator alleges that the respondent Kellogg, city manager, and the respondent Eberling, superintendent of waterworks, have duties as public officers of the city of Cincinnati to authorize and permit relator's water main extensions to be connected with the 16-inch main in Miami road, and to authorize and permit consumers of water who may be served by such water main extensions to be served upon the same conditions as other persons now receiving water through such water main distribution system.

The relator sought a writ of mandamus requiring the respondents to permit such connection.

The Court of Appeals granted a writ ordering the respondents to immediately proceed to permit relator to connect its water main extensions to the water main in Miami road and to permit consumers of water to be served by such water main extensions to make connections thereto and to secure water from the water main in Miami road by means of such extensions and connections.

The case is before this court upon the appeal of the respondents from the judgment and order of the [***7] Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent city officials sought review of a judgment entered in the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which granted relator developer a writ of mandamus requiring the city officials to permit the developer to connect its subdivision water main extensions to the city water distribution system.


OVERVIEW: After the developer's application to the city to have its subdivision water main extensions connected to a city water main was denied under an ordinance that prohibited the city from furnishing water to any extension of existing mains outside the city, it commenced an action in mandamus claiming that the provisions of the ordinance were discriminatory and unconstitutional. The court reversed the lower court's order granting the writ of mandamus and ruled that an express contract between the city and county to furnish surplus water to Sanitary Sewer District No. 1 where the subdivision was located had expired and the city, although it continued to provide water to the sewer district, could exclude those who could be served only through the connection of new extensions to the existing mains. The court found that the stated intention of the ordinance was to assure an adequate supply of water in the future to serve the possibly growing population of city consumers, that the ordinance was not in bad faith, arbitrary, or unlawfully discriminatory against the developer, and that the developer showed no clear legal right to the writ of mandamus.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower grant granting the writ of mandamus that required the city officials to permit the developer to connect its subdivision water main extensions to the city water distribution system.

 

320 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Wachendorf v. Shaver


No. 31044


Supreme Court of Ohio


149 Ohio St. 231; 78 N.E.2d 370; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 452; 36 Ohio Op. 554



March 17, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton county.

Pursuant to the provisions of Section 3526, General Code, there was filed on March 27, 1946, with the township trustees of Columbia township, Hamilton county, Ohio, a petition requesting that an election be held to obtain the sense of the electors of certain designated territory sought to be incorporated into a village. The territory sought to be incorporated included platted lands. Pursuant thereto, an election was held and a majority of the electors voted for incorporation. Thereupon the trustees certified their proceedings to the county recorder, as provided by Section 3530, General Code.

Subsequent thereto and pursuant to Section 3532, General Code, as modified by Section 3531, plaintiff, appellant herein, filed his petition and subsequently his amended petition in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton county, seeking an injunction restraining the county recorder from making a record and certifying a transcript thereof to the Secretary of State.

On May 13, 1946, Thomas F. Dunlap and George C. Taylor, agents for the incorporation petitioners, were made parties defendant. On June 6, 1946, the John Hilberg & Sons Company [***2] made application to become a party plaintiff and filed its petition seeking injunctive relief. Separate answers were filed by the county recorder and the agents for the petitioners.

The issues thus joined, the cause came on for hearing in the Court of Common Pleas, resulting in a finding and decree enjoining the recorder from certifying the record of the proceedings for incorporation to the Secretary of State.

Appeal on questions of law and fact was prosecuted to the Court of Appeals where the cause was heard de novo and a finding and decree was entered, denying and dissolving the injunction previously granted by the Court of Common Pleas.

Although urged in brief that the Court of Appeals was without jurisdiction to hear the cause as one in chancery and that Section 3526, General Code, is unconstitutional, it was stated in open court that those issues were not urged. Therefore, no consideration is given them.

The cause is before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Decree affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff challenger appealed from the order of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court and dissolved an injunction that prevented defendant county recorder from proceeding to act on the incorporation of a township into a village after an election by the voters on the petition of defendant incorporators. The lower appellate court held that Ohio Gen. Code § 3526 applied to platted and unplatted lands.


OVERVIEW: The incorporators petitioned the township trustees to hold an election to ascertain the sense of the voters as to whether the platted township should become a village. The voters approved, but the challenger claimed that by Ohio Gen. Code § 3517 et seq., the county commissioners had exclusive control over the incorporation of platted lands. On this appeal, the court found that Ohio Gen. Code § 3517 et seq., provided for the incorporation of platted lands and adjacent unplatted lands, by and through the county commissioners, while Ohio Gen. Code § 3526 conferred on the trustees of a township, jurisdiction of proceedings to incorporate villages out of any territory or portion thereof, instituted by petition to the trustees of the township in which the territory was located. The court held that nothing in § 3517 made the authority of the county commissioners over platted lands exclusive, and the plain language of § 3526 made it applicable to "any territory," not just unplatted lands. The court held that § 3526 was clear and unambiguous, so that the court could not expand or limits its terms, nor read § 3517 to limit its scope, because the statutes were cumulative.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the lower appellate court that dissolved the injunction issued by the trial court and allowed the incorporation to proceed.

 

321 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Burgstaller v. Franklin County Board of Elections


No. 31352


Supreme Court of Ohio


149 Ohio St. 193; 78 N.E.2d 352; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 448; 36 Ohio Op. 541



March 10, 1948, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: The twenty-nine other relators and their cause numbers are: Van Arsdell, Sr., No. 31353; Shepard, No. 31354; De Shetler, No. 31355; Knost, No. 31356; Smith, No. 31357; Stygler, No. 31358; Reynolds, No. 31359; Cahill, No. 31362; Becker, No. 31363; Wollam, No. 31364; Geddes, No. 31365; Hill, No. 31366; Allen, No. 31367; McCormick, No. 31368; Dundon, No. 31369; Shea, No. 31370; Schultz, No. 31371; Warning, No. 31372; Furniss, No. 31373; Myers, No. 31374; Westlake, No. 31375; Burrel, No. 31376; Earnhart, No. 31377; Wallace, No. 31378; Amon, No. 31379; Connor, No. 31380; Eger, No. 31381; Doyle, No. 31382; and Bowers, No. 31383.


PRIOR HISTORY: IN MANDAMUS.

This is one of 30 proceedings in mandamus instituted in this court against the same respondent. The petitions are all identical excepting for the names of the relators, their wards and the particular positions for which they seek election. All relators are represented by the same counsel. The causes were heard together and the determination of one applies to all.

Relator filed with respondent, the Franklin County Board of Elections, hereinafter called the board, a petition and declaration of candidacy for election as a member [***2] of the Democratic Central Committee of Franklin county. The petition form was properly executed and signed by five electors as required by Section 4785-70, General Code. The relator, on the same day, at the same time, filed another declaration of candidacy and petition form properly executed and containing the necessary signatures of five qualified electors.

The board found the "declaration of candidacy and petition" insufficient and rejected it because it was signed by more than five electors contrary to Section 4785-70, General Code.

Thereafter, the controlling committee of the Democratic Party of Franklin county filed a protest against the candidacy of the relator.

A hearing was had and the board made a final determination that the "declaration of candidacy and petition" was insufficient and rejected it.

Whereupon relator instituted this action in mandamus to compel the board to place his name on the primary ballot of the Democratic Party for the primary election to be held on May 4, 1948.

The cause is before this court on the petition and the demurrer thereto.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In one of 30 similar proceedings, relator candidate petitioned for a writ of mandamus to compel respondent county board of elections to put his name on a political party's primary election ballot. Upon the protest of the county controlling committee of the political party, the board rejected the candidate's petition and declaration of candidacy forms on the basis that they failed to comply with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4785-70 (1948).


OVERVIEW: The candidate filed with the board a petition and declaration of candidacy for election to the county central committee of a political party. The form was properly signed by five electors as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4785-70 (1948). At the same time, the candidate filed another candidacy petition that was also signed by five electors. On appeal, the court upheld the board's rejection of the forms because, in the aggregate, they failed to comply with the requirement of § 4785-70 that the candidacy petition be signed by five, but not more than five, qualified electors. The fact that the signatures were on more than one petition did not affect the issue because the court regarded all petition forms filed by the candidate as his petition. The court explained also that because elections belonged to the political branch of the government, the board's decision was final and not subject to judicial review unless procured by fraud or corruption, or unless there had been a flagrant misinterpretation or misapplication of a statute. Because the candidate claimed no fraud or corruption and the board correctly applied the controlling statute, the court denied the requested writ.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ of mandamus that was requested by the candidate.

 

322 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Dayton Rubber Mfg. Co. v. Glander


Nos. 31211, 31212


Supreme Court of Ohio


149 Ohio St. 67; 77 N.E.2d 605; 1948 Ohio LEXIS 429; 36 Ohio Op. 430



February 11, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

These cases were presented together and involve similar questions of law.

The facts are not in dispute.

In the first case the Dayton Rubber Manufacturing Company filed an application with the Tax Commissioner of Ohio for the refund of use tax in the sum of $ 657.10 assessed and paid for the period beginning January 1, 1940, and ending December 31, 1944, under the provisions of Section 5546-26, General Code, on monthly rentals for certain substitute business machines leased from the International Business Machines Corporation.

The application was denied by the commissioner.

On an appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals the order of the commissioner was affirmed.

The history of the second case is similar except that it involves an application for the refund of sales tax in the sum of $ 668.14 which the Remington Rand, Inc., claims was paid erroneously for the period beginning May 1, 1942, and ending August 31, 1945, under the provisions of Sections 5546-1 and 5546-2, General Code, on monthly rentals for machines leased by it to the Fisher Brothers Company. The commissioner allowed a refund of $ 217.74, representing the tax paid on rentals for [***2] original machines delivered before January 1, 1935, the date the sales tax first became effective; but the remainder of the claim for a refund -- $ 450.40 -- was denied on the ground that it represents the tax paid on rentals for substitute machines subsequently delivered. The order of the commissioner was affirmed by the Board of Tax Appeals.

The two cases are in this court for review on the claim that the assessments are unreasonable and unlawful.



DISPOSITION: Decisions affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant companies each challenged decisions of the Ohio Board of Tax Appeals upholding assessments made by appellee Tax Commissioner. The cases were presented together on similar questions of law. They came on for review on the claim that the assessments were unreasonable and unlawful.


OVERVIEW: Each company leased business machines. Their respective leases included provision for substitute machines if needed. In one case, the company applied for a refund of use tax paid on monthly rentals of substituted machines. The application was denied. The second case involved application for a refund of sales tax paid on monthly rentals of leased machines. Similarly, a refund for tax on substituted machines was denied. The only machines involved were substitute machines delivered after the effective date of the tax. The issue was whether and when these substituted machines were "purchased" and "acquired" by the companies. The court held that the leased machines were "purchased" under Ohio Gen. Code § 5546-25. The companies claimed they were "acquired" at the same time, when the leases were signed. The commissioner insisted that machines substituted later were acquired when they were delivered, after the tax became effective. The court agreed. The dates of the contracts were immaterial, as the contracts were executory until they were performed. Performance, not execution, constituted "acquisition." Substituted machines were acquired upon delivery. The decisions were affirmed.


OUTCOME: The decisions upholding the tax assessments were affirmed. The court found that they were neither unreasonable nor unlawful.

 

323 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lockett


C.A. No. 7809


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Summit County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8147



December 31, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO, CASE NO. 75 1 98


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County (Ohio) wherein he was convicted of aggravated murder and was sentenced to death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's conviction and sentence arose from a botched robbery of a pawnshop in which the proprietor was shot to death. Defendant argued that his motion to acquit at the close of the State's case in chief should have been granted because the State's case was based solely on the uncorroborated testimony of a co-conspirator. The court found that there was a reasonable inference to be drawn from the background of the parties and the testimony that four defendants conspired to find a way to get money; that it was natural that any suggestions as to how they could raise money would have emanated from defendant and his sister because the others were strangers to Akron; and that the testimony was corroborated by an independent witness who saw defendant run out of the pawn shop and by ballistics evidence. Defendant argued that the verdict on the charge of aggravated robbery was not supported by sufficient evidence. The court disagreed because part of the plan to rob the pawn shop was to use a gun, all of the participants knew the triggerman had live cartridges to put into the gun, and it was clear that the death was caused by the bullet fired from the gun held by the triggerman.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

324 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Ambrosia Nectar, Inc. v. Kosydar


No. 75AP-223


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8169



December 31, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Order Affirmed 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant debtor in possession sought review from an assessment by appellee Tax Commissioner of a delinquency charge assessment and penalty. The Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) had affirmed the final order of the Commissioner.


OVERVIEW: The debtor argued that the Board erred in affirming the final order of the Commissioner because the forfeiture assessment and penalty were barred by § 57(j) of the Bankruptcy Act. Section 57(j) of the Bankruptcy Act provided that debts owing to the United States or any state or subdivision thereof as a penalty or forfeiture were not to be allowed, except for the amount of the pecuniary loss. The debtor argued that the section only allowed penalties to the extent of any pecuniary loss and that inasmuch as the debtor had paid its tax with a penalty of 15 percent, the State had not suffered any pecuniary loss. The court held that the charge made by the Commissioner was not a penalty, but was revenue collectable by assessment and was subject to a penalty imposed upon it. The court also held that in accordance with § 397 of the Bankruptcy Act, 11 U.S.C.S. § 797 delinquency charges and penalties remained as personal liabilities of defendant and were non-dischargeable pursuant to § 17 of the Bankruptcy Act.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

325 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. Scott


Nos. 74AP-215, 75AP-226


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


47 Ohio App. 2d 287; 353 N.E.2d 858; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5881; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 352



December 23, 1975, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: A motion to certify the record was overruled by the Supreme Court of Ohio, May 13, 1976.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The City challenged a judgment from the Franklin County Municipal Court (Ohio), which dismissed a complaint against defendant that alleged that defendant violated Columbus, Ohio, Code § 2307.04(B) that prohibited the reckless solicitation of another person to engage in offensive sexual activity. The trial court held that the ''reckless" portion of the ordinance was an unconstitutional attempt to punish speech.


OVERVIEW: Defendant solicited the complainant, another male, to engage in homosexual activity. Defendant was indicted under a city ordinance that prohibited a person from soliciting another person to engage in sexual activity when the offender knew such solicitation was offensive to the other person or the offender was reckless in that regard. The trial court dismissed the complaint on the ground that the ordinance was an unconstitutional attempt to punish speech. The City argued that the ordinance merely prohibited recklessly offending another person by a solicitation to engage in sexual activity and that a complaint based on such an ordinance should not have been dismissed by the trial court on the grounds of a constitutionally insufficient culpable mental state. The court affirmed the judgment because the uttering of words that were ''rude'' or ''insulting'' could not be prohibited, although vulgar or offensive. The court held that in the same way in which invitations to engage in sexual activity were not necessarily obscene, such invitations were not necessarily "fighting words." The court held that in fact such invitations could easily be classified as loving words.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.

 

326 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Esquire Bar, Inc. v. Liquor Control Comm'n


Nos. 34148, 34149


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6981



December 23, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM COMMON PLEAS COURT, No. 917,093 917,094



DISPOSITION: Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a corporate holder of a liquor license, challenged a judgment of the Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court (Ohio), which affirmed a decision of appellee, the Ohio Liquor Control Commission, to suspend the corporation's license to operate a tavern. The Commission charged the corporation with two unrelated violations of Ohio Liq. Control Comm'n Regs. LCc-1-52, where two employees allowed a woman to perform with exposed breasts.


OVERVIEW: The Commission held a hearing on the corporation's case. Upon the advice of counsel, the corporation stipulated the truth of the facts alleged in each charge. The stipulation included the element of "improper conduct." The corporation contended that the stipulated facts did not constitute a violation of LCc-1-52. The corporation also claimed that both the regulation and the charges were unconstitutional. The Commission heard no evidence other than the stipulations and held that the allegations of the director of liquor control were supported by the evidence. The trial court affirmed, finding also that the order of the Commission was supported by reliable, probative, and substantial evidence. The court affirmed, rejecting the corporation's argument that the trial court erred in failing to explicitly state that the Commission's order was "in accordance with law." However, the court found that the trial court's journal entry implicitly stated that the Commission's ruling was "in accordance with law." Further, the corporation had stipulated that it's agent had knowingly permitted "improper conduct," which admission satisfied all the elements of LCc-1-52.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

327 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Diana


Nos. 75AP-210, 75AP-211


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8084



December 23, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgments Affirmed 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed an order of Franklin County Common Pleas Court (Ohio), which overruled their motions for a new trial and for acquittal, after convicting them of operating gambling activities for profit, of acquiring, possessing, controlling, or operating a gambling device, and of altering, destroying, concealing, or removing documents or things, with purpose to impair their value or availability as evidence in a proceeding or investigation.


OVERVIEW: Based upon confidential information and an investigation, police officers obtained a search warrant for premises upon which defendants allegedly conducted gambling operations. The officers discovered paraphernalia related to gambling operations and found defendants in the process of destroying records and documents by burning them, chewing them, and flushing them in the toilet. Defendants were convicted after a jury trial, and they appealed their convictions, alleging that the trial court erred in failing to suppress evidence because the warrant was defective, that their right to avoid self-incrimination was violated by the seizure of their personal papers, that the prosecution should have had to elect which charges to proceed under at the beginning of trial, and that there was insufficient evidence to sustain the convictions. The court affirmed, finding that there was sufficient evidence to find that defendants were operating a numbers bank, that any devices, including paper and an adding machine, could be considered devices used for gambling, even though they were used for other purposes, and that personal papers were not protected under the Fifth Amendment if they were illegal.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendants' convictions for conducting gambling operations and other gambling-related offenses.

 

328 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


City of Columbus v. Scott


Nos. 75AP-215, 75AP-226


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8080



December 23, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Whereupon, for the foregoing reasons, the judgment of the trial court is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The City sought review of a decision of the Franklin County Municipal Court (Ohio), which dismissed the criminal charges of importuning against defendant based upon the fact that the law was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Columbus, Ohio, City Code § 2307.04(B) stated that no person could solicit another person to engage in sexual activity with the offender, when the offender knew that such solicitation was offensive to the other person, or was reckless in that regard. Defendant was arrested and tried under the ordinance. The trial court dismissed the complaint, finding that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The City appealed. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that there was no question that whatever consenting adults might choose to do privately, in this area of human activity, was legal in Ohio at the present time. The court opined that the ordinance made a criminal offense of certain social interrelationships and of protected free speech rights of otherwise consenting adults. Additionally, the court found that the ordinance lacked definite standards and was constitutionally vague, as well as indefinite. The court articulated that the ordinance also involved two separate intentions: one, of the person using the words; the other, of the individual hearing them.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

329 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cuyahoga County Bd. of Mental Retardation v. Association of Cuyahoga County Teachers of Trainable Retarded


No. 34094


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


47 Ohio App. 2d 28; 351 N.E.2d 777; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5861; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 168



December 11, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee employer filed an action against appellants, employees and their union, to enjoin them from striking. After issuing a preliminary injunction and ordering the employees to return to work, and after appellants filed an affidavit of disqualification, the Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) vacated its order and appointed a mediator to effectuate a settlement. Appellants challenged the propriety of the entire proceeding.


OVERVIEW: Appellants claimed the trial judge was disqualified because of his prior affiliation with the employer and also because his brother was a member of the employer's board of directors. After appellants filed an affidavit of disqualification, and after receiving a letter from the Chief Justice of the Ohio Supreme Court, which directed the trial judge to take no further action, the trial judge issued several rulings in the case. Appellants argued that the trial court judge erred by participating in the proceeding because his bias and prejudice disqualified him. The court reversed the judgment and granted a judgment for appellants. The court held that the trial judge had a mandatory duty from the beginning of the proceedings to disqualify himself from the case, and that his each and every subsequent act, being in violation of his clear and mandatory duty, was utterly void and without effect. The court stated that the mere filing of an affidavit of bias and prejudice had at least a temporary effect; it deprived a trial judge of the power to proceed on the case until such time as the affidavit of disqualification was ruled upon by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.


OUTCOME: The trial court's judgment, which appointed a mediator to resolve the parties' labor dispute, was reversed.

 

330 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Tucker


Case No. 1033


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh Appellate District, Columbiana County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6382



December 10, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order from the trial court (Ohio), which accepted defendant's guilty plea and convicted him of aggravated murder with a specification of aggravated robbery.


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved to enter a plea of guilty to aggravated murder with a specification of aggravated robbery. The trial court accepted the plea, convicted defendant, and sentenced him. Defendant sought review and argued that the trial court failed to comply with the requirements of Ohio R. Crim. P. 11 in accepting defendant's change in plea. The court found that the trial court had erred in failing to inform defendant specifically that the State had to prove defendant's guilty beyond a reasonable doubt and that defendant could not be compelled to testify against himself, but that the error was not prejudicial because defendant's counsel was competent and told the trial court that they had informed defendant of the effects of his plea. The court also found that defendant's plea was made intelligently and voluntarily.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

331 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Vincenzo


Case No. 159


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh Appellate District, Noble County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6385



December 10, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the County Court, Noble County, Ohio, which convicted him of a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.21(A)(1), the trespassing statute. The subject real estate involving the trespass was a ranch. Defendant had entered upon this land to dismantle an old mining shovel under an arrangement with an individual. Defendant had been previously warned that he was on property not owned by this individual.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant claimed that the trespass statute was unconstitutional. He contended that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2901.01 was not sufficiently definite to apply to defendant, or any other defendant, as to what trespassing consisted of; in that, in the instant case, defendant did not knowingly enter upon the premises of another, and if he did, he felt that he had a privilege to do so. Defendant further argued that the statute failed to state with definiteness and certainty the acts that were prohibited upon the property of another. The court found that defendant had misconstrued the section in question. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2901.01 did not prohibit acts upon the property, but simply prohibited going on or remaining on property. In this sense the wording of the statute was clear, explicit, and not unconstitutional. Further, an unlawful entry was not indispensable to a conviction under the terms of the Ohio trespass statute. Pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2909.21, remaining upon the premises of another without legal authority after being notified to leave was a misdemeanor.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

332 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


City of Cincinnati v. McCormick


No. C-75027


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6080



December 8, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Municipal Court of Cincinnati, Ohio, which denied his motion to suppress evidence and convicted him of possession of marijuana.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was standing in a group of people when a police officer approached him. The officer claimed that defendant had been holding a bottle prior to the time that he approached defendant but not at the time that he confronted defendant. The officer arrested defendant for prowling, searched his person, and seized a marijuana cigarette from defendant. The trial court overruled defendant's motion to suppress the marijuana on the grounds that defendant had committed a misdemeanor, the possession of an open flask and an alcoholic beverage in a public park, in the presence of the officer. Defendant entered a plea of no contest. On appeal, the court reversed the judgment and ordered that defendant be discharged, finding that the search of defendant's person was not incident to a lawful arrest and was a violation of his constitutional rights under U.S. Const. amend. IV. The court noted that the alleged offense of prowling was not an offense because it had been held unconstitutional by the Ohio Supreme Court. The court found that the conclusion of the trial court that defendant had committed a misdemeanor in the presence of an officer was not sustained by the record.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and ordered that defendant be discharged.

 

333 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Prophett v. Buckner


No. C-74276


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6122



December 8, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS HAMILTON COUNTY, OHIO

 

334 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Trustees of Howland Township v. Bd. of County Comm'r


Case No. 2258


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Trumbull County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8163



December 8, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant township trustees sought review of a judgment from the Court of Common Pleas of Trumbull County (Ohio), which ordered annexation proceedings to continue and refused to enjoin appellee city from conducting hearings on annexation petitions.


OVERVIEW: The township trustees sought to enjoin the city from advancing various pending annexation proceedings. The trial court enjoined the city from certifying annexation documents but refused to enjoin the city from conducting hearings on annexation petitions. Upon review, the court reversed. The court found that the township trustees were not entitled to an injunction against the city where their reliance upon case law that declared annexation statutes unconstitutional was insufficient because the cases that were relied upon had been reversed on appeal.


OUTCOME: The court reversed a judgment that ordered annexation proceedings to continue and that enjoined the city from certifying annexation documents. The court affirmed part of a judgment that refused to enjoin the city from conducting hearings on annexation petitions.

 

335 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Mosher v. City of Dayton


Case No. 4900


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second Appellate District, Montgomery County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6345



December 4, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant handgun owners sought review of the judgment from the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County (Ohio), which, after sustaining their objections to a city ordinance prohibiting the sale or possession of handguns because it was vague and impractical, found Dayton, Ohio, Ordinance No. 24780, which required registration by handgun owners, to be within the framework of the constitution, valid, and enforceable.


OVERVIEW: The owners sought to restrain as unconstitutional two ordinances of the City of Dayton. The trial court found Dayton, Ohio, Ordinance No. 24746, which prohibited the sale or possession of handguns identified as "Saturday Night Specials," to be vague and impractical and sustained the owners' objections. However, the court found that Dayton, Ohio, Ordinance No. 24780, which required the registration and possession of an identification card by owners of handguns, to be valid and enforceable. On appeal, the court disagreed with the owners' argument that U.S. Const. amend. II should have been interpreted as though the constitution guaranteed the right to bear arms to the individual rather than to the people. The court noted that the amendment's reference to a militia to protect the security of a free state and found that to argue that U.S. Const. amend II contained an individual rather than a collective state right destroyed the right to a militia and ignored the purpose clause of the second amendment. Lastly, the court held that each sovereign state had the natural and reserved power to regulate arms in the interest of the welfare of its people.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

336 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Sonnie


No. 5-209


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Lake County


46 Ohio App. 2d 164; 346 N.E.2d 791; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5841; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 254



December 1, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Appeal denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The trial court (Ohio) dismissed a criminal charge against defendant pursuant to his motion for discharge for delay in trial under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.73. The State filed a petition for permission to file a bill of exceptions. The trial court's attorney filed a memorandum in response seeking denial of the State's petition. The court considered the merits of the State's petition.


OVERVIEW: The issue before the court was whether the State had a right of appeal from the trial court's dismissal of defendant's case on speedy trial grounds. The court opined that double jeopardy principles barred the State's appeal. Pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.73(D), defendant's discharge pursuant to § 2945.73(B) for failure to bring him to trial within 270 days after his arrest barred any further criminal proceedings against defendant based on the same conduct. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.70 provided that the State lacked a right of appeal from anything other than a ruling on a motion to quash, a plea in abatement, a demurrer, a motion to suppress evidence, or a motion in arrest of judgment. The State failed to cite any statute or rule allowing its appeal from a dismissal on speedy trial grounds. Accordingly, the court denied the State's petition for leave to appeal.


OUTCOME: The court denied the State's petition for leave to appeal.

 

337 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Edwards


C.A. No. 7784


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Summit County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7876



November 26, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO, CASE NO. 75 1 52


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a decision of the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County, which sentenced defendant to death in the electric chair and to a term of seven to 25 years in the penitentiary pursuant to his conviction by a jury for the crimes of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery.


OVERVIEW: Defendant shot and killed a local businessman while committing a robbery at the place of business. On appeal, defendant argued that the trial court erred in not suppressing his statements to the police. The court affirmed the judgment. In doing so, the court held that the statements were voluntary. The court noted that although defendant was in custody for nine and one-half hours, his first incriminating statement was made less than one hour after the initial questioning began, the periods of interrogation were not lengthy nor was the interrogation continuous. Further, defendant was 21 years old and had a high school education. Also, the trial court's finding that defendant did not fall within the class of persons excused from capital punishment under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(B)(3) was not something that fell within the trial court's discretion. It was a finding based upon evidence, and it amply sustained the trial court's ruling. While there was evidence indicating that defendant was below the average in intellectual functioning and was educationally deficient, he was not mentally deficient or retarded. Educational deficiency did not equate with mental deficiency.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.

 

338 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Grubb


C.A. No. 7849


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Summit County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7899



November 26, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO, CASE NO. 74 11 1186



DISPOSITION: The judgment is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County (Ohio), that convicted him of gross sexual imposition contrary to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.05(A)(3). Defendant asserted that the evidence was insufficient to prove his guilt beyond a reasonable doubt and that the provisions that defined sexual contact in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2907.01(B), 2907.05, were unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of gross sexual imposition contrary to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.05(A)(3), for having had sexual contact with a minor as defined by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.01(B). The court affirmed defendant's conviction and sentence, finding that there had been sufficient evidence to prove his guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Defendant could not raise an issue for the first time on appeal. Further, the court found that the enactment of § 2907.01(B), accomplished a legitimate legislative purpose and that statute was not vague or uncertain.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction and sentence.

 

339 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Gilbert


C.A. No. 7788


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Summit County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7835



November 19, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO, CASE NO. 75 2 226



DISPOSITION: The judgment is modified and, as modified, the judgment is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order by the Summit County Court of Common Pleas, Ohio, which convicted defendant of felonious assault, abduction, theft and possession of a hallucinogen for sale.


OVERVIEW: The night all of the alleged offenses occurred, defendant claimed at trial that he had been smoking marijuana and taking LSD tablets. He went to a house party of a friend where he smoked more marijuana and drank alcohol. When he left the party, defendant stole a truck, which subsequently stalled. The victims, a husband and wife, recognized the truck and offered assistance. While in the victims' vehicle, defendant put pulled a knife on the victims. A passing motorist called the police and defendant was arrested at the scene. Defendant blamed his acts on his consumption of alcohol and drugs. The court found that defendant by force and threat of force restrained the wife of her liberty. He held a knife to her neck and threatened to kill her. Further, defendant's actions constituted an abduction of the husband. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court regarding defendant's conviction. However, the court found that the trial court's sentence did not follow the applicable statute and had to be modified.


OUTCOME: The judgment is modified and, as modified, the judgment is affirmed.

 

340 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


City of Akron v. Estes


C.A. No. 7808


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Summit County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7782



November 19, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE AKRON MUNICIPAL COURT, SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO, CASE NO. 430837



DISPOSITION: The judgment is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision by the Akron Municipal Court, Summit County, Ohio, which convicted defendant of peeling and did unlawfully violate Akron, Ohio, City Code § 931.32; operating unsafe vehicle in violation of Akron, Ohio, City Code § 438.01; and speeding in violation of Akron, Ohio, City Code § 434.03.


OVERVIEW: After defendant made a stop, he drove from the stop by accelerating his vehicle in such a manner as to cause the tires to make a loud noise. An officer said he followed defendant one block to an intersection where, after making a stop, defendant again drove forward by spinning his tires and causing a loud noise. Defendant drove forward and after the officer stopped a short distance who cited defendant. The court stated that there was sufficient credible evidence with respect to speed to justify the trial court's judgment. The trial court could accept or reject defendant's statements where they contravened the officer's testimony. Because the trial judge chose to believe the officer, the court could not say he was in error and now rejected that testimony. An arrest ticket contained in detail the specific items deemed improper and because they were also a part of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 438, the court believed that this charge was not vague for a lack of standard. The requirements were readily found in ch. 438, denominated in the Akron City Code as "safety and equipment."


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

341 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Edgeworth


C.A. No. 7947


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth Appellate District, Lucas County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8339



November 14, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] S.M.C. No. 75-TR-C-1035



DISPOSITION: Motion To Dismiss Appeal Overruled 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to Ohio R. Crim. P. 12(J), the State sought review as of right of the judgment of the Sylvania Municipal Court (Ohio), which granted a motion of defendant to suppress evidence. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the appeal for the reason that the State failed to comply with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.68 et seq.


OVERVIEW: The evidence suppressed was the result of a breathalyzer test and the use of the video tape taken of defendant at the time of defendant's arrest. Defendant contended the State's appeal had to be dismissed because the State did not comply with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.68 et seq., which required application for leave of the appellate court to file a bill of exceptions, notice to the trial judge concerning such application for leave and, upon leave being granted, filing a bill of exceptions as prescribed by law. The court overruled the motion to dismiss and held that Ohio R. Crim. P. 12(J) spelled out in detail the conditions necessary, time limit and procedure controlling such an appeal as of right by the State. Since Rule 12(J) provided an appeal as of right from an order granting a motion to suppress, logic required that further appeal procedure had to be pursued as outlined in the appeals as of right procedure in Ohio R. App. P. 4(B), 9, 10 and 11, and not limited in any manner by the discretionary review procedure provided by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.68 et seq.


OUTCOME: The court overruled defendant's motion to dismiss the State's appeal.

 

342 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Macdonald


No. 34194


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6617



November 13, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM COMMON PLEAS COURT, (Criminal), No. 9092


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which entered a judgment of conviction on a jury verdict that found defendant guilty of armed robbery.


OVERVIEW: Defendant appealed his conviction for armed robbery, alleging that his right to a speedy trial had been violated. The court agreed. Defendant was arrested for violation of federal criminal charges after being released on bond for the instant offense. But the state located defendant and requested that a capias be issued detaining defendant on the armed robbery indictment. The state made no further move toward prosecuting defendant for six months, violating defendant's right to a speedy trial pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2945.71 and 1945.72. Accordingly, the court held that defendant must be discharged.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction and ordered that defendant be discharged.

 

343 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Tozzi v. Curry


No. 34233


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6658



November 13, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM SOUTH EUCLID MUNICIPAL COURT, No. 5860



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the trial court


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant driver sought review of a judgment of the South Euclid Municipal Court (Ohio), which found against the driver on the driver's petition for review of the suspension of his license by appellee, the Registrar of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.


OVERVIEW: The driver was arrested for operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. At the police station, the driver refused to submit to a breathalyzer test. He was notified by the Registrar that his license was suspended as a result of his failure to submit to the breathalyzer test. The driver filed a petition for review, but the trial court entered judgment against him. On appeal, the driver argued that the trial court erred in finding that the driver had refused to take a test and in not finding in favor of the driver by reason of the fact that the arresting officer failed to comply with the provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.191. In affirming the trial court's judgment, the court held that the trial court correctly found that the driver had refused the test where evidence showed that the driver by his own direct statements refused to take the test on two separate occasions after having been read the implied consent form. The implied consent form, which was read to the driver, contained the requisite information as to the consequences of refusal in compliance with § 4511.191.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

344 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Strub


No. 1032


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh Appellate District, Columbiana County


48 Ohio App. 2d 57; 355 N.E.2d 819; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5888; 2 Ohio Op. 3d 40



November 13, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the trial court (Ohio), which convicted defendant of aiding and abetting an aggravated murder. In seeking review, defendant challenged the evidence's sufficiency and claimed that the trial court had erred in barring an examination of the jurors with respect to the death penalty and in charging the jury that defendant could be found guilty as an aider and abettor even though charged as a principal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was present when a friend robbed and killed another person. Thereafter, defendant was charged with aggravated murder. When defendant was convicted as an aider and abettor, defendant sought review, challenging the evidence's sufficiency and claiming the trial court had erred in barring the jurors examination with respect to the death penalty and in charging the jury that defendant could be convicted as an aider and abettor although charged as a principal. In holding that the trial court had not erred in barring the jurors examination with respect to the death penalty, the court noted that because the penalty of death was no longer a jury question, it did not follow that jurors should be questioned about capital punishment. Moreover, the court held Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.25(C), which allowed such questioning, was inapplicable. The court also held that in light of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.03(F), a party charged as a principal could be found guilty of complicity. Finally, the court upheld the evidence's sufficiency, which included defendant's failure to aid the victim, defendant's sharing in the fruits of the crime, defendant's flight, and spoliation of evidence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment which convicted defendant of aiding and abetting an aggravated murder.

 

345 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Hodory v. Wood


No. C-75356


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6341



November 10, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Reversed 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant county commissioners sought review of a judgment from the Hamilton County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which granted plaintiff property owners' request for a permanent injunction enjoining the commissioners from taking any action to zone or rezone the property owners' land for commercial purposes.


OVERVIEW: The property owners filed a declaratory judgment action to enjoin the commissioners from taking any action to zone or rezone their property for commercial purposes. The trial court declared the zoning resolution for single family use only was invalid and granted the property owners a temporary restraining order without bond. The property owner's filed a motion to extend the temporary order, a motion for a preliminary injunction, and for a permanent injunction. The commissioners filed a motion to dissolve the temporary order and for relief from the final judgment. The trial court granted the property owners' request for a permanent injunction and the commissioners appealed. In reversing the trial court's judgment, the court held that the trial court erred. The court found that the trial court did not have jurisdiction to enjoin the commissioners from taking a legislative act to rezone property. The court stated that there was error in granting the injunction based on the prior declaratory judgment because the injunction granted greater relief than a request for declaratory relief justified.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment.

 

346 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Nenoff v. Thompson


C.A. No. 7840


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth Appellate District, Lucas County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8308



October 31, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM Common Pleas COURT, NO. 203720 & 206839


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the ancillary administratrix of the estate of a decedent, filed a motion for reconsideration of a judgment entered on behalf of defendant tortfeasor in two related actions arising out of an accident. The motion raised 13 assignments of error.


OVERVIEW: Following an accident, the administratrix filed two actions against a common defendant. One of the actions was for wrongful death; the second action was a survivorship action. Following a consolidated trial, the jury entered a verdict for defendant in both cases. The administratrix filed a motion for reconsideration. The court considered only assignment of error number 12 which claimed that the trial court prejudicially erred in requiring the administratrix to meet the requirements of an unconstitutional guest statute. The assignment claimed that the trial court erred in its instructions to the jury. However, the court held that the administratrix was barred from asserting such an error on appeal because she failed to object to the trial court's instructions to the jury. The administratrix also failed to request a negligence charge from the trial court. Under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2321.03, the administratrix could not take advantage of errors she induced and that the administratrix was required to object to an alleged omission in the trial court's charge to the jury. As such, the court denied the administratrix's motion for reconsideration.


OUTCOME: The court denied the administratrix's motion for reconsideration.

 

347 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Terry


C.A. No. 2333


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Lorain County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8106



October 29, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF LORAIN COUNTY, OHIO, CASE NO. 18342


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision from the Court of Common Pleas of Lorain County (Ohio), which convicted defendant of a theft offense that was committed with a deadly weapon and which sentenced defendant to a term of four to 25 years in the reformatory.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of using a deadly weapon during a theft offense and was sentenced to a term of four to 25 years. He sought review. The court affirmed. It found that defendant was not denied a speedy trial under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.71 because the 90 period was tolled by defendant's request for a continuance of the pre-trial hearing. The refusal to admit a photograph was within the sound discretion of the trial. The trial court did not abuse its discretion when it denied the admission of the exhibit because the photograph was not an accurate representation of the subject matter. The trial court did not err when it allowed the jury to view the entire video-taped testimony of a witness because the review of the testimony on videotape was no different than a review of a transcript of a witness's testimony. Finally, defendant was properly convicted of the gun charge under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.01 because the jury was warranted in concluding that the weapon was operable and capable of inflicting death when defendant threatened to shoot the witness in the head.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions for using a deadly weapon during a theft offense.

 

348 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Zoz


No. C-74157


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6454



October 27, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Hamilton County Common Pleas Court (Ohio) terminated defendant's probation and sentenced him to one year in a correctional facility. Defendant appealed from that judgment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was found guilty of conspiring to sell a hallucinogen and was sentenced to a one-year term in a correctional facility. Defendant's motion for suspension of sentence was granted and he was placed on probation subject to his compliance with certain conditions including, the regulations of a "halfway" facility. Thereafter, defendant was dismissed from the facility for failure to observe its rules. The trial court terminated defendant's probation and ordered his incarceration after a hearing. On appeal, the court held that Ohio's revocation of probation provisions were not unconstitutional, per se because they provided for a preliminary and a final hearing. However, the court found that defendant did not receive a proper final hearing. In addition, the court found that defendant's counsel was not permitted to introduce into evidence a report prepared by the probation officer and he was not permitted to cross-examine the officer on the report. Therefore, the court held that defendant was entitled to a final hearing.


OUTCOME: The judgment finding that a probation violation had occurred and the order executing the previously suspended sentence were reversed. The cause was remanded for a final hearing in accordance with law and consistent with the opinion of the court.

 

349 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Moore v. Dague


No. 75AP-200


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


46 Ohio App. 2d 75; 345 N.E.2d 449; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5826; 75 Ohio Op. 2d 68



October 7, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, an alleged illegitimate son of a decedent, appealed a judgment from the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) that dismissed his will contest suit against defendants, an executrix of the decedent's estate and others, for lack of standing to bring the suit.


OVERVIEW: The son claimed that he was the sole person entitled to inherit the estate if the decedent had died intestate. After the trial court sustained the executrix's dismissal motion on a claim that the son lacked standing because he was not an heir at law, the son appealed. Affirming, the court said that the trial court did not err in finding that the son had no standing to maintain the action. The son claimed no basis for his right to maintain the will contest other than his claim that he was an illegitimate son. Under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2741.01, a will contest action could be brought only by one who had a direct pecuniary interest in the estate of the decedent that would have been defeated or impaired if the will admitted to probate was a valid will. An illegitimate child did not per se have an interest in the will of his natural father and, thus, had no standing to maintain a will contest. There was no invidious discrimination constituting an unconstitutional denial of the equal protection of the law in the application of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2105.17, which denied to the illegitimate child a right to inherit from a natural father unless he provided for such inheritance.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

350 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Powrie v. Youngstown Bd. of Educ.


Case No. 75 C.A. 28


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh Appellate District, Mahoning County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6243



September 30, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parents filed a complaint praying that appellee board of education be permanently restrained from implementing an "open transfer plan" passed by a resolution of the board. At the close of the parents' case, the board made a motion for dismissal, arguing a failure to prove abuse of discretion or fraud, and a failure to prove irreparable harm. The trial court (Ohio) sustained the motion. The parents sought review.


OVERVIEW: The board adopted the "open transfer plan," which allowed students to transfer to a school outside of their neighborhood school for racial balance if appropriate space was available at the other school. The parents argued that the trial court erred in finding that they had failed to prove an immediate or irreparable injury. Finding no error in the trial court's judgment, the court affirmed. The evidence failed to indicate any present or threatened real, certain, substantial, serious, and direct injury. There was evidence that implementation could possibly cause an inconvenience because a student might have to attend a school other than his neighborhood school. Such evidence would not support an injunction. An injunction would not be granted where damage was trifling, fanciful, sentimental, or the result of a mere inconvenience. The parents also argued that the resolution, which was passed by the board establishing the transfer policy, was violative of Ohio Rev. Stat. Ann. § 3313.48. The court disagreed. The resolution applied to those who were willing to voluntarily transfer schools. It did not threaten the right to attend the most convenient appropriate school.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

351 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Williamson v. Ralston


Case No. 75 C.A. 16
