Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh Appellate District, Mahoning County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6210



September 24, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed in Part and Reversed in Part


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a passenger and his wife, appealed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Mahoning County (Ohio), which found in favor of defendants, a first driver and a second driver, in an action for personal injury damages. The passenger argued that the Ohio Guest Statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4515.02, was inapplicable and that the trial court erred in refusing to instruct on the law governing speed under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.21.


OVERVIEW: The passenger was riding in the first driver's car on the way to work when the car was involved in an accident with a car driven by the second driver. The passenger and the first driver were employed by the same company, and the passenger had paid the first driver for the ride to work. The passenger and his wife filed an action against the first driver and the second driver, and the trial court returned judgment in favor of the first driver and the second driver. Plaintiffs appealed, and the court reversed as to the judgment in favor of the first driver but affirmed the judgment in favor of the second driver. In light of a decision of the Ohio Supreme Court holding the Guest Statute unconstitutional, the trial court's charge to the jury on the Guest Statute was in error, and the error was prejudicial. However, the trial court did not abuse its discretion under Ohio R. Civ. P. 44.1(A)(2) in failing to take judicial notice of a city speeding ordinance because there was no evidence as to the characteristics of the thoroughfare in which the accident took place. Therefore, there was no prejudicial error in regard to the verdict in favor of the second driver.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the verdict and judgment as to the first driver, and it remanded to the trial court for a new trial on the action against the first driver. It affirmed the verdict and judgment in favor of the second driver.

 

352 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hancock


No. 75AP-151


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8482



September 23, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Whereupon, for the foregoing reasons, the judgment of the trial court is affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, Franklin County (Ohio), which convicted him of two counts of aggravated murder, a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01, and sentenced him to punishment by death.


OVERVIEW: A jury convicted defendant of two counts of aggravated murder. He contended that the trial court erred in overruling his motion to order the State to elect no more than one specification for each count in the indictment, that the trial court erred in overruling his motions for acquittal, and that § 2929.04 violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution and Ohio Const. art. I, § IX. The court held that the trial court did not err in denying defendant's motion to order the State to elect no more than one specification because Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2929.04, 2941.14 specifically allowed for more than one count for aggravated murder. The trial court did not err in overruling defendant's motions for acquittal at the close of the State's case, at the conclusion of all evidence, and after the jury returned the verdicts because the evidence was sufficient to sustain the convictions. The court was bound by prior United States Supreme Court decisions that the death penalty per se was constitutional and therefore was required to sustain the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

353 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Jacobs v. Bd. of County Comm'rs of Hamilton County


Nos. C-74572, C-74611


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7314



September 22, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners challenged the judgment of the Hamilton County Common Pleas Court (Ohio), which dismissed their declaratory actions against appellees, certain local land-use decisionmaking bodies, in which the property owners sought determinations as to the constitutionality of adverse rulings that limited development of the property owners' real estate.


OVERVIEW: When the property owners sought rulings from the respective local land-use decisionmaking bodies for certain developments on their real estate, their attempts failed. After the property owners filed declaratory actions, the common pleas court dismissed both complaints on the grounds that the property owners failed to exhaust their administrative remedies. The property owners filed appeals, and the appeals were consolidated. The court reversed the judgments of the common pleas court, holding that a complainant must normally exhaust all administrative remedies before seeking a declaratory judgment where the asserted unconstitutionality of a land-use decision was the fundament of his complaint. Further, an alternative to the declaratory judgment action was the Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506 judicial appeal. However, declaratory relief was proper where the record indicated either that there was no administrative remedy available that could provide the relief sought, or that the remedy which was available was unnecessarily onerous. Because the records did not contain those indications, the actions were remanded for further development of the records.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgments and remanded the actions for further proceedings.

 

354 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. George


No. 75AP-110


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


50 Ohio App. 2d 297; 362 N.E.2d 1223; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5924; 4 Ohio Op. 3d 259



September 18, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of criminal convictions rendered by the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County (Ohio), finding him guilty of violating state securities law, as set forth in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1707.44(C).


OVERVIEW: Defendant contracted to supply distributors with uncut, pre-recorded reels of tapes, which the distributors were to package and sell back to defendant for resale. The erstwhile distributors paid defendant for this privilege, but defendant did not fulfill the agreement. Defendant was convicted of selling unregistered securities under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1707.44(C). On appeal, the court held that the transaction met the definition of a "security" under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1707.01(B), and was not an unregulated investment contract. No ex post facto violation occurred, because the appellate district's controlling case law was issued, in an "unpublished" format, only six days before defendant's crime. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2503.20, stating that only reported cases were officially sanctioned by Ohio courts, was directory, not mandatory. However, on the facts presented, defendant did not receive fair notice that his actions were criminal in nature. The court accordingly reversed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed. Although defendant's due process rights were not violated per se by the fact that controlling case precedent was released in unpublished form only six days before he committed criminal acts, he was not given fair notice of the status of the law he was bound to follow.

 

355 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Turner


Nos. 75AP-233, 75AP-247


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8472



September 16, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgments Affirmed 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed a decision from the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which convicted them of aggravated robbery and kidnapping.


OVERVIEW: Defendants argued that the trial court erred in denying their motion to suppress evidence seized after a search of their apartment. The court found that the search was conducted after defendants gave their consent. The door to the freezer was open, and the police observed a sock with a gun stuffed within it. Also, defendants were already under arrest, because the victim had identified them as his assailants, and the search was incident to that arrest. One defendant's wig, which he used to disguise himself as a female hitchhiker, was properly introduced into evidence when the arresting officer identified it. The criminologist's testimony, that the hair on the trigger guard of the weapon was similar to that of the wig, created a permissible inference that the hair had come from the wig. The trial court, which was the trier of fact, was unlikely to be confused by the meaning of the wig. The trial court did not abuse its discretion by refusing to refer the case for a presentence investigation before sentencing one of the defendants.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision.

 

356 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Leis v. William S. Barton Co.


No. C-74277


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


45 Ohio App. 2d 249; 344 N.E.2d 342; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5814; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 387



September 15, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part, and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State filed a civil action to abate a nuisance consisting of the sale of allegedly obscene material. Defendants, a lessor and lessee, appealed a judgment from the Hamilton County Common Pleas Court (Ohio), which found that certain materials were obscene, ordered the store closed for one year under the statutory padlock scheme of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3767.01 et seq., and subsequently granted the lessor's application to reopen the premises.


OVERVIEW: At the nuisance hearing the trial court refused to admit defendants' evidence about contemporary community standards and prurient appeal. At the hearing on the application to abate the closure order, the lessor repeatedly offered to seek the trial court's prior approval of any new tenant, and the trial court required the lessor to prevent a nuisance from being established as part of the release order. Defendants claimed that the terms of the covenant to abate included an impermissible prior restraint and that the blanket exclusion of evidence was prejudicial error. Affirming in part, the court held that § 3767.01 et seq. as judicially construed was constitutional. The court agreed that the terms of the covenant to abate were impermissibly broad under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3767.04, but overruled the assignment of error because the lessor agreed to them. Reversing in part, the court held that it was error not to allow defendants to introduce competent, non-repetitive evidence that bore upon the absence of any of the elements of the Miller obscenity test because to hold otherwise would make the trial court, sitting in equity without a jury, the sole arbiter of community standards.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in part, based upon the trial court's erroneous blanket exclusion of defendants' evidence regarding the elements of the Miller obscenity test. The court affirmed the remainder of the judgment and remanded the cause for further proceedings not inconsistent with the court's decision.

 

357 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Spangler


No. 305


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Clinton County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7297



September 15, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS JUVENILE DIVISION CLINTON COUNTY, OHIO


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment of conviction and sentence entered by the Juvenile Division of the Common Pleas Court of Clinton County (Ohio). Defendant was charged under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2151.41 with acting in a manner tending to cause unruliness in two minor children. The trial court denied defendant's motion for acquittal at the close of the State's case and entered a judgment of guilty.


OVERVIEW: The complaint charged that defendant kept the children out until the early morning hours, consuming alcoholic beverages with then and encouraging them to participate in acts of malicious destruction of property of another. Specifically, the State charged that the minors accompanied defendant and others to a scene, where defendant vandalized a police chief's car and later returned and picked up defendant after the mission was accomplished. On appeal, defendant argued that the evidence was insufficient to sustain the conviction and that the judgment was against the manifest weight of the evidence. He also argued, inter alia, that § 2151.41 was unconstitutionally overbroad and vague. The court held that: (1) the vandalizing of the car was both immoral and criminal, and the exposure of the minors to such misconduct violated § 2151.41; (2) any person of common intelligence who wanted to understand § 2151.41 would have no trouble understanding it; (3) neither was § 2151.41 over broad whereas it, as former Ohio Gen. Code § 1639-45, was previously before the court and found not unconstitutional for the lack of uniform operation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the trial court.

 

358 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Dacey v. City of Kent


Case No. 630


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Portage County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7946



September 15, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant executrix challenged the decision of the Portage County trial court (Ohio), which granted appellee city's motion to dismiss the executrix's declaratory judgment action seeking to declare a city zoning ordinance unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The trial court found the executrix failed to state a claim upon which relief could be granted in that she alleged no justiciable controversy. She appealed. Construing the complaint most favorably to the executrix, the court agreed that the parties were not entitled to litigate questions that might never affect them to their disadvantage. The general rule was that a court, under a declaratory judgment proceeding, did not have the right to determine whether a statute, ordinance, or regulation was abstractly valid or invalid. The executrix's complaint contained no allegation of a justiciable controversy; it merely alleged that the zoning ordinance classification in which the executrix owned a parcel of property was unconstitutional. Since the complaint's allegations did not set forth facts that gave rise to a disputed right-duty relation between the parties that placed the executrix in a position of peril or insecurity, it was deficient.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision that granted the city's motion to dismiss the executrix's declaratory judgment action.

 

359 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Tull


Case No. 75 CA 15


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second Appellate District, Miami County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6040



September 9, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a juvenile, challenged a judgment from a juvenile court (Ohio), which found him guilty of using offensively coarse language in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2917.11(A)(2) and adjudicated him delinquent. The trial court determined the statute was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant ordered a young girl to leave a sidewalk so defendant and other juveniles could operate a motorbike. The girl's mother protested. Defendant called the mother a "fucking bitch" and further stated, "If you don't like it, call the fucking pigs, use my fucking phone, you fucking bitch." The trial court adjudicated defendant a delinquent. On appeal, the court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2917.11(A)(2) was unconstitutional. The trial court impermissibly injected a requirement of fighting words, taken from § 2917.11(A)(3), into § 2917.11(A)(2). Such judicial legislation was a denial of notice of a new charge and of due process. The two subsections defined two distinctly different crimes. One was directed exclusively to a choice of language and the second to language or conduct likely to provoke a violent response. Because defendant was not charged under § 2917.11(A)(3), the juvenile court could not adjudicate defendant a delinquent based on a violation of § 2917.11(A)(3), and § 2917.11(A)(2), as construed by the juvenile court was unconstitutional. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2917.11(A)(2) was overbroad and facially invalid when applied to the facts.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment from the juvenile court finding defendant a delinquent.

 

360 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Laytart


Case No. CA-74-24


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second Appellate District, Fayette County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6011



August 28, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of conviction and sentence pronounced by the Common Pleas Court of Fayette County (Ohio) for grand theft of a bicycle in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2913.02.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the trial court should have granted his motion for acquittal, but on review, the court disagreed. It found that the trial court did not err when it allowed testimony of a witness to be repeated to the jury after it commenced deliberation. The court found that a statement taken by a police officer was properly admitted because the statement was voluntary and defendant never filed a motion to suppress. Furthermore, the statement was exculpatory and did not prejudice defendant. The court rejected the claim that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2913.02 was unconstitutional in permitting evidence of a prior conviction of a theft offense to be taken into account. Finally, the court found that the indictment sufficiently followed the words of the statute and was not defective. While the court found that the trial court failed to comply with Ohio R. Crim. P. 5(B)(4), the court found that the error was harmless. Also, the court found that because defendant was represented by counsel from the time of his indictment, there was no merit to a claim that he was denied a right to counsel under the terms of the procedural rules, including Ohio R. Crim. P. 22.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

361 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Brown


No. 75AP-178


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8462



August 28, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County (Ohio), following a jury trial, in which he was found guilty of the sale of a hallucinogen (marijuana), in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3719.44(D).


OVERVIEW: During the cross-examination of a police officer, it was brought out that the officer had made a written summary following the purchase of the marijuana as to what had transpired and that the summary was in the possession of the State. A bench conference ensued. The court affirmed defendant's conviction. Although the procedure of conducting the in camera inspection of the statement was not fully in accord with the criminal rules, the court found no prejudicial error that flowed from the trial court's denial of the use of the statement by defense counsel during cross-examination because the statement was completely consistent with the police officer's testimony on direct examination. Finally, the court declined to declare the law that provided the punishment for the sale of marijuana of a minimum sentence of 20 years and a maximum 40 years (with a minimum imprisonment requirement of a maximum of 10 years) unconstitutional. The court found that the question of the law's constitutionality was mooted by passage of Am. Sub. H.B. 300.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for the sale of a hallucinogen.

 

362 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Robinson


No. 75AP-130


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


48 Ohio App. 2d 197; 356 N.E.2d 725; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5895; 2 Ohio Op. 3d 171



August 26, 1975, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: The judgment in this case was affirmed by the Supreme Court of Ohio, in 47 Ohio St. 103.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County (Ohio), following a jury trial, in which he was found guilty of aggravated murder.


OVERVIEW: Defendant shot his nephew in the head following an altercation. A physician testified that the nephew's intoxication at the time was heightened by amphetamines. Defendant claimed self-defense. A jury found defendant guilty of aggravated murder. The court reversed defendant's conviction because the trial court committed prejudicial error when it charged the jury that defendant had the burden of establishing self-defense by a preponderance of the evidence. The trial court also committed prejudicial error when it instructed the jury as to the circumstances when self-defense was legally justified. The net impact of an imminent danger requirement left a finding of guilty of involuntary manslaughter. Furthermore, the trial court erred when it failed to give defendant's requested instruction on circumstantial evidence. Circumstantial evidence was necessary to the issue of intent. Therefore, the failure to include a circumstantial evidence charge was prejudicial error. Finally, the trial court did not abuse its discretion when it did not declare a mistrial after one witness gave an unresponsive answer. Defendant was not prejudiced, and the jury was instructed to disregard the answer.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction for aggravated murder.

 

363 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Royster


No. 75AP-195


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8460



August 26, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Affirmed by State v. Royster, 48 Ohio St. 2d 381, 358 N.E.2d 616, 1976 Ohio LEXIS 766 (1976)
Post-conviction proceeding at, Decision reached on appeal by State v. Royster, 3 Ohio App. 3d 442, 3 Ohio B. 521, 446 N.E.2d 190, 1982 Ohio App. LEXIS 10936 (Ohio Ct. App., Franklin County, 1982)
Magistrate's recommendation at, Habeas corpus proceeding at Royster v. Mausser, 2015 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 151092 (S.D. Ohio, Nov. 6, 2015)



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which sentenced him to death pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2929.02-2929.04 following his conviction of aggravated murder with specifications of aggravation, kidnapping, rape, aggravated robbery, and grand theft.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant alleged that his motion to limit imposition of sentence to life imprisonment should have been granted because the Ohio statute under which his death sentence was imposed was unconstitutional. He also alleged that his statement to police should have been suppressed because he did not make a knowing, intelligent, and voluntary waiver of his constitutional and Miranda rights. The court held that the Ohio and the U.S. Constitutions recognized, referred to, and provided for capital offenses. Furthermore, the U.S. Constitution permitted a person to be deprived of life if he was afforded due process of law. The court pointed out that the means, manner, or circumstances of inflicting the death penalty could constitute cruel and unusual punishment. However, the death penalty could not be found per se to constitute cruel and unusual punishment without violating the Constitution. The court also held that defendant's ability to understand and respond to questioning was not indicative of a person who was not able to comprehend and understand an explanation of rights. Therefore, the court concluded that defendant waived his rights knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

364 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Akron Falls Cars, Inc. v. City of Cuyahoga Falls


C.A. No. 7720


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Summit County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7716



August 20, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENTS ENTERED IN THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO, CASE NOS. 72 9 1963, 72 10 2090 and 72 10 2113


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant car dealer challenged a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County (Ohio), which affirmed a decision of a city's board of zoning appeals denying a variance for the dealer to store and display motor vehicles outside a main building in conflict with Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, Ordinance 142-1971. The dealer claimed that the denial violated its constitutional rights and that the ordinance was invalid, illegal, and void.


OVERVIEW: Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, Ordinance 142-1971 was adopted to authorize a change of zoning for the dealer's property from multifamily and commercial to a designation as a 2-E automotive service district. It established conditions and declared an emergency. The zoning change was requested by the dealer's principal and property owner who made certain promises to the city's planning commission including that no vehicles would be stored or displayed outside. On review, the court found that it could take judicial notice of ordinances in its district, that Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, Charter art. VIII, § 2, allowed the board to hear and decide appeals, that the evidence showed that many neighbors objected to the adoption of Ordinance 142-1971, and that there was no denial of due process. The court ruled that the 2-E district was established first and existed moments before the dealer's property was declared part of such a district, that the dealer had urged the adoption of Ordinance 142-1971, and that the dealer was estopped from attacking the ordinance's validity because the dealer had aided in procuring the legislation and had benefited from its adoption.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

365 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Allen


No. 33909


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6492



August 14, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM COMMON PLEAS COURT, (Criminal), No. 3334



DISPOSITION: Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision by the common pleas court (Ohio), which convicted him of two counts of armed robbery, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.01, and imposed concurrent sentences of four to 25 years. Defendant claimed that his rights of compulsory process and due process were denied by the trial court's refusal to allow him to assert an alibi defense based on a failure of notice. He claimed it was totally impossible to comply.


OVERVIEW: The State objected to defense counsel's references to alibi evidence based on defendant's failure to file a notice of alibi under Ohio R. Crim. P. 12.1. Defense counsel admitted the failure to file, claiming that he had been retained less than two weeks earlier and that he first learned of defendant's intent to assert an alibi on the trial date. He said the evidence would be testimony from defendant's common law wife that he was with her when the robbery was allegedly committed. Though the trial judge indicated that he could continue the case to allow notice to the State, neither party asked for a continuance, and the trial judge sustained the State's objection. The court found that because Ohio R. Crim. P. 12.1 only required prior notice of defendant's intention to present an alibi, defendant himself determined whether or not his alibi witness could testify by either complying or failing to comply with the notice requirement. It held that the notice of alibi statute did not violate defendant's right of compulsory process and that the exclusion of his alibi evidence was a discretionary decision that did not violate defendant's right to due process of law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision with costs against defendant.

 

366 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Chambers


Case No. 2276


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Trumbull County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7906



August 11, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] We reverse the judgment of the Common Pleas Court and enter final judgment for the appellant herein


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State of Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles sought review of the judgement from the Common Pleas Court (Ohio), which set aside its order suspending the license of appellee driver.


OVERVIEW: A car owned by the driver, but not driven by the driver, was involved in an accident. The other party involved in the accident sent the Bureau a motor vehicle accident report. The Bureau then sent the driver a letter informing him that it knew that he had no automobile liability insurance policy and that he could either submit to a release from liability, deposit an amount to cover the costs of any possible judgment, or request an administrative hearing. The driver chose none of the alternatives but sent the Bureau a letter disclaiming liability. Thereafter, the Bureau suspended the driver's operator's license and registration. The driver successfully appealed to the trial court. On appeal, the court found that the trial court erred in conducting an evidentiary hearing and in failing to grant the Bureau's motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust administrative remedies. The court reasoned that the driver failed to avail himself of the opportunity for a hearing before the Bureau; therefore, no record other than the complaint of the injured party against the driver, the Bureau's letter to the driver, and the notice of suspension existed for the trial court to review.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

367 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Thompson v. Wilson


No. 7693


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth Appellate District, Lucas County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8188



August 8, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] TRIAL COURT NO. 73-1942

 

368 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Taylor


Nos. 2296, 2297


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Lorain County


47 Ohio App. 2d 171; 352 N.E.2d 604; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5871; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 259



August 6, 1975, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: A motion to certify the record was overruled by the Supreme Court of Ohio, December 12, 1975.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the trial court (Ohio), which convicted him of six counts of criminal offenses, which included kidnapping, rape, and aggravated robbery.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's attorney requested a continuance and subsequently withdrew as counsel. Defendant was subsequently appointed new counsel. Defendant was found guilty of four counts and pled guilty to the two remaining counts. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that defendant waived his right to a speedy trial under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.73. The court stated that a voluntary agreement by defense counsel for a trial date beyond the 90-day period constituted a continuance pursuant to § 2945.72(H).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

369 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Kodish v. Public Employees Retirement Bd.


No. 75AP-111


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


45 Ohio App. 2d 147; 341 N.E.2d 320; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5801; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 167



August 5, 1975, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: A motion to certify the record was overruled by the Supreme Court of Ohio, December 5, 1975.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff state employees sought review of an order from the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which dismissed their amended complaint for failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted. The employees claimed that defendant public employees retirement board unconstitutionally withheld interest on their returned contributions.


OVERVIEW: The employees were all present and former unclassified employees of the state who had or were contributing to the public employees retirement system and whose pay was withheld and deposited in the system. The employees claimed that the board unconstitutionally failed to pay interest on the contributions that were returned to those employees who terminated service prior to retirement or death. The trial court dismissed the employee's claim for failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted, and on appeal, the court upheld the dismissal. The court rejected the employees' claim of entitlement to interest on the returned contributions. The court held that the board properly construed Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 145.01 to mean that the employees had a vested right only to their own contributions but had no right to interest for use of the money while such was within the hands of the system. The court also held that the employees were not prejudiced by the board's lack of procedural rules and regulations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the employees' amended complaint.

 

370 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Masheter v. Viny


Nos. 33301, 33302, 33303


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6943



July 31, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM PROBATE COURT, No. 765,829 765,747 731,378



DISPOSITION: Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State of Ohio challenged the judgment of the probate court (Ohio), which granted an allegedly excessive award to appellee property owners in an appropriation proceeding. Among the State's contentions was its assertion that the trial court improperly permitted expert appraisal witnesses and councilmen to testify as to the reasonable probability of a zoning change which would have been necessary for the owners' planned development.


OVERVIEW: The State sought review of the trial court's judgment, contending that the appropriation award granted to the owners was excessive based on the actual market value of the property taken by the State for use in highway construction. The State contended that the court erred in admitting the testimony regarding the reasonable probability of a zoning change which affected the property appraisal value of the undeveloped property. The court on appeal affirmed the judgment of the trial court based on its determination that the State failed to show that it was prejudiced by the testimony pertaining to the probability of rezoning. The court found that the jury's award was reasonable and well within the range established with admissible expert testimony. The admission of the testimony was harmless error under the circumstances which allowed the trial court jury to consider that as an element in its determination of the property's fair market value and arriving at a value that the appellate court found was not unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

371 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hayes


Case No. 4753


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second Appellate District, Montgomery County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5984



July 25, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the Dayton Municipal Court (Ohio), which overruled her motion for discharge on a charge of soliciting for sexual activity for hire in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.24 that classifies such offense a misdemeanor of the third degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's motion for discharge on a charge of soliciting for sexual activity for hire in violation of § 2907.24 which classifies such offense a misdemeanor of the third degree was dismissed. Defendant on appeal argued that the trial court erred in overruling her motion for dismissal, failing to discharge her, ordering her to stand trial, and judging her guilty. On appeal, the court affirmed the decision. The court held that the trial court continued the cases for trial on a date beyond the 45-day period specified in § 2945.71. The court stated that the trial court was not required to hold a hearing and show affirmatively the necessity for a continuance based upon a specific reason. The court reasoned that it was difficult to understand how the interests of society or of the accused would have been served by discharging the accused for failure to try her within 45 days following her arrest. The court stated that there was a presumption that the trial court acted reasonably in continuing the case for trial beyond the 45-day limit specified in § 2945.71.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

372 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Apple v. City of Strongsville


Nos. 33034, 33047


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6827



July 24, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM COMMON PLEAS COURT, No. 906,122



DISPOSITION: Judgment Reversed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant City sought review of the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which found, in a declaratory judgment action, that the residential zoning of appellee property owners' land was unconstitutional and has no relation to the public health, welfare, safety, and morals.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the City argued that the trial court's judgment was against the manifest weight of the evidence. The court found that because it was an action to declare the zoning unconstitutional, the burden was on the property owners to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the residential zoning bore no real and substantial relation to the public health, safety, morals, or general welfare, or was clearly erroneous. The court held that the property owners' did not present sufficient evidence to overcome the presumption that the legislation bore a real and substantial relation to the public health, safety, morals, or welfare. The court found that the property owners' witnesses' testimony went solely to the issue of the economic feasibility of developing the land as residential property. The court reversed the trial court's judgment because proof of economic feasibility to develop residentially, without more, was not sufficient to establish constitutionality.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment.

 

373 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Davis


C.A. No. 7698


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Summit County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7081



July 23, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF SUMMIT COUNTY, OHIO, CASE NO. 74 10 1047


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Summit County Court of Common Pleas, Ohio, which convicted him of felonious assault. Defendant contended that the trial court erred in admitting evidence of a prior act of defendant and in failing to instruct a jury to disregard the prosecutor's improper reference to defendant as a "mean son of a bitch."


OVERVIEW: Defendant was on trial for assaulting a deputy sheriff. He testified that the deputy's injury was the result of an accident. The prosecutor introduced evidence of an earlier incident in which defendant assaulted a different deputy sheriff. Upon review, the court found that evidence was admissible because defendant perjured himself on the stand and the prosecutor introduced contradictory evidence, which conformed to the requirements of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.59. Defendant failed to demonstrate that the prosecutor's remark during closing arguments was so offensive and prejudicial as to deny defendant a fair trial. Given the length of the comment, the nature and extent of the evidence, and the nature of the crime, the remarks of the prosecutor were not improper to the extent that they denied defendant a fair trial. The trial court did not err in overruling defendant's challenge of a juror for cause because he did not use his peremptory challenges to remove the juror to which an objection for cause had been raised.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for felonious assault.

 

374 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Provens v. Ohio Real Estate Com.


No. 75AP-62


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


45 Ohio App. 2d 45; 341 N.E.2d 329; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5791; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 87



July 22, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, an applicant seeking to take a state examination to become a licensed real estate broker, appealed a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which affirmed an order of defendant Ohio Real Estate Commission denying the applicant the right to take the examination.


OVERVIEW: The applicant had been working for a licensed real estate broker for almost three years, in which time she had secured clients, obtained listings, and closed 15 sales transactions. She handled sales contracts and paperwork to obtain financing, and she attended closings. The Commission denied the applicant's request to take a real estate broker's license examination, contending that she did not fulfill the requirements of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4735.07(E) in that she lacked sufficient experience to the Commission's satisfaction. On appeal, the court reversed and remanded, finding that the Commission's action was arbitrary and an abuse of discretion. The court could find no rules or regulations promulgated by the Commission to define "sufficient experience" as used in § 4735.07(E). By failing to define the term, the Commission could act capriciously and without any standards. The court noted that the legislature had enacted a new law substituting new standards in the section, but the validity of that law was not before the court. The court added that the Commission's failure to enact rules and regulations did not invalidate the statutory authority that it had to do so.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and remanded the cause for further proceedings.

 

375 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Browning v. Patrick


No. 75AP-56


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8412



July 22, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Motion Sustained 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant injured party sought review of the decision of the trial court (Ohio) that entered judgment in favor of appellee individuals. The injured party filed a motion to certify the appeal to the state's Supreme Court because the judgment was in conflict with a case from a different appellate district.


OVERVIEW: The lower court entered judgment in favor of the individual's in the action initiated by the injured party. The injured party then filed a motion to certify the appeal to the state's Supreme Court because the judgment was in conflict with a case from a different appellate district. The court granted the motion to certify because it found that the conflict did exist. Pursuant to Ohio Const. art. IV, § 3(B)(4), the court determined that once if found a conflict to exist, it had to certify the record of the case to the supreme court for review and further determination. The court found that the motion was timely filed and the fact that the injured party simultaneously filed a notice of appeal to the supreme court did not affect jurisdiction of the court to certify since the notice of appeal was required also.


OUTCOME: The court granted the injured party's motion to certify the appeal to the state's Supreme Court because the judgment in favor of the individuals was in conflict with a case from a different appellate district.

 

376 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


City of East Cleveland v. Moore


No. 33888


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6722



July 18, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM EAST CLEVELAND MUNI. COURT, No. 163,307



DISPOSITION: Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the decision of the East Cleveland Municipal Court (Ohio), which found her guilty of violating an ordinance restricting occupation of a dwelling unit to one family because it was found that defendant, her sons, and grandsons constituted more than one family.


OVERVIEW: On review, defendant argued that the trial court erred in overruling her motion for dismissal upon the grounds that the ordinances in question were unconstitutional as violations of her rights to freedom of association, travel, privacy, equal protection under the laws, and due process of law. The court affirmed. The court found that the ordinance did not involve the rights of association, travel, or privacy, nor any other "fundamental" right guaranteed by the United States Constitution. The court determined that defendant failed to present the trial court with any evidence to support her contention that the ordinance was violative of the equal protection and due process clauses. The court concluded that, because defendant presented no evidence to rebut the presumption of legislative validity, the ordinance bore a real and substantial relation to public health, safety, or welfare, and was, therefore, valid.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the conviction.

 

377 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


City of Dayton v. Kinnison


Case No. 4813


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second Appellate District, Montgomery County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5971



July 11, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of her conviction for petty theft by a municipal court in Montgomery County (Ohio). Defendant's case was not tried within the time provided by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.71 and there was no journalized entry regarding the reason for delay. The trial court overruled defendant's motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: The court found that the trial court's pending case load was responsible for its inability to try the case within time. Although Ohio Mun. & County Ct. Superintendence R. 5(A), 5(B) required trials within the time provided in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.71 and further required that any extension of time should be journalized in an order, those rules had not been adopted at the time in question. The fact that the delay here was caused by the condition of the trial court's docket was acknowledged by counsel for the defense and justified the delay under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.72 (H). The record indicated that the trial court complied with the provisions of the statute with reference to a continuance at the time of assignment for trial.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for petty theft.

 

378 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


SMC, Inc. v. Laudi


No. 33710


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


44 Ohio App. 2d 325; 338 N.E.2d 547; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5772; 73 Ohio Op. 2d 378



July 10, 1975, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: A motion to certify the record was overruled by the Supreme Court of Ohio, October 24, 1975.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant City of Brooklyn, Ohio sought review of a judgment from a Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which was entered in favor of appellee landowner in his action appealing a decision from the Board of Zoning Appeals, which decision held that the Board was without jurisdiction to hear the landowner's appeal of a building inspector's denial of a permit to build a restaurant. The trial court ordered that the permit be issued to the landowner.


OVERVIEW: The City challenged the trial court's jurisdiction to test the constitutionality of the City's zoning ordinances in the landowner's action, which was initiated by administrative appeal pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506. The City also challenged the trial court's refusal to allow the City to introduce evidence in addition to that which was in the transcript of the proceedings before the Board. The court remanded the case, holding that the trial court had jurisdiction to consider the constitutionality of the City's zoning ordinances as applied to the landowner's property in his appeal from the Board pursuant to § 2506, even though the Board correctly ruled that it did not have jurisdiction to hear constitutional issues. The court determined however, that although the City chose not to present evidence before the Board, it was wrongly prohibited from presenting evidence to the trial court. The court concluded that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506.03 did not limit to the landowner the right to request such additional evidence and that instead, either party could have requested, or the trial court on its own motions could have required, that additional evidence be presented.


OUTCOME: The court remanded the case to the trial court with instructions to permit the parties to introduce additional evidence and to try the case as an original action based upon the transcript of proceedings before the Board and such additional evidence as the parties might have offered.

 

379 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In Re Appeal of Woods


No. 75AP-96


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8393



July 10, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant neighbors sought to overturn the judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County (Ohio), which held that they could not rely on Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506.01 to challenge rezoning enacted by a city council. Appellee city and intervenor association opposed the neighbors' appeal.


OVERVIEW: The city council granted a zoning variance on a parcel of land to permit a drug treatment center in a residential district. The neighbors opposed the rezoning and filed a § 2506.01 appeal. The lower court dismissed the action for lack of jurisdiction, and the court affirmed. The court held that legislative acts could not be appealed pursuant to § 2506.01 and that the action of the city council was a legislative act and not a quasi-judicial act. The court ruled that because the city council initiated the rezoning of the parcel and was not acting in an appellate administrative capacity, it was acting in a legislative capacity, and the neighbors could not challenge the city council's action under § 2506.01.


OUTCOME: The lower court's judgment that it had no jurisdiction over the neighbors' challenge to the city's rezoning of the disputed parcel of land was affirmed by the court.

 

380 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


McClung v. Bd. of Educ.


Case No. CA-75-5


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second Appellate District, Fayette County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5970



July 9, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In his action for declaratory judgment and injunctive relief against defendant school board to prevent the publication of the school's yearbook without his picture as a student in the graduating class, plaintiff student appealed a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas of Fayette County (Ohio) in the school board's favor.


OVERVIEW: The student's photograph was excluded from the yearbook because of the length of his hair. The student contended on appeal that the trial court's judgment violated his rights under the Ohio Constitution, the United States Constitution, the statutes and common law of Ohio, and that the judgment was against the manifest weight of the evidence. The court found that the student's constitutional issues were insufficiently developed and went on to consider the issue of whether the regulation of hair styles of male students was reasonably necessary to a valid educational purpose within the meaning of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3313.20. The court found no causal connection between long hair and disruptive behavior or that persons with long hair were any less responsive to ordinary discipline. The court concluded that the school board's regulations were not essential, and that, absent health and safety factors which could suggest specific health rules and safety devices similar to that worn by women in dangerous activities, the regulation of the length of hair for boys and not for girls was not reasonably necessary to maintain discipline or to operate a public school.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and granted the student's request for an injunction until his photograph was included in the yearbook.

 

381 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


United States Auto Raceways, Inc. v. Village of Valley View


No. 33822


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6522



July 3, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM COMMON PLEAS COURT, No. 925,300



DISPOSITION: Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation sought review of a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which denied the injunctive relief requested by the corporation in its action against appellees, a village and its officials, alleging that Valley View, Ohio, Codified Ordinances § 709.05 was an invalid exercise of the police power.


OVERVIEW: The corporation operated a speedway, at which it conducted concerts. The village enacted § 709.05 in order to limit the number of spectators at such concerts. The corporation claimed that § 709.05 was unconstitutional and invalid because it was unreasonable, discriminatory, capricious, and an abuse of legislative authority. The corporation sought to enjoin the enforcement of § 709.05. The trial court denied the injunctive relief and specifically held that § 709.05 was a valid ordinance. On appeal, the court affirmed, concluding that the village's determination that attendees at the speedway concerts would be limited to the actual seating capacity of the facility was reasonable. The village did not abuse its discretion in imposing the limitation nor chose a method of regulation that was unrelated to the health, safety, and welfare of the community. Rather, the village sought to legislate against a recurrence of the traffic and property damage difficulties experienced at other concerts. The limiting of the number of tickets sold to the number of grandstand seats available was a reasonable method of preventing such a recurrence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

382 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati Gas and Elec. Co. v. Davies


Nos. CA 74-10-0086, CA 74-10-0087


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Butler County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7474



June 30, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL ON QUESTIONS OF LAW FROM COURT OF COMMON PLEAS BUTLER COUNTY, OHIO


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant/cross-appellee power companies (agencies) sought review of a judgment from the Court of Common Pleas, Butler County (Ohio), which denied the power companies' appropriations for easements over the land of appellee landowners and which denied the right of appellee/cross-appellant adjacent landowner to intervene.


OVERVIEW: The agencies sought to appropriate easements over the lands owned by the landowners by separate actions under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 163 et seq. The landowners denied that the parties had been unable to agree as to compensation, denied the necessity of the appropriation and specifically alleged many other reasons why the appropriation should be disallowed. The adjacent landowner sought to intervene. The trial court found for the landowners and denied the adjacent owner the right to intervene. On appeal, the court affirmed denying the right to intervene, but reversed judgment for the landowners holding that the trial court erred in finding that although the line was necessary, there was no need to put it in the route chosen. The court held that there was no evidence in the record to justify finding that the agencies had abused their discretion in putting the lines where they had, in failing to get approval from their respective boards, or to have the environmental report before them when making their decision. The court held that the evidence supported a finding that the agencies had not acted in bad faith and that their decisions were reasonable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the denial of the adjacent landowners to intervene but reversed the judgment of the trial court which found that the agencies were guilty of bad faith or of abuse of discretion in their attempts to lay out and construct the power lines.

 

383 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Restaurant Promotors, Inc. v. Kosydar


No. C-74385


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7479



June 30, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a decision by the Ohio Board of Tax Appeals, which granted the motion to dismiss filed by appellee Ohio Tax Commissioner. The Board dismissed the taxpayer's appeal for lack of jurisdiction.


OVERVIEW: In its notice of appeal to the Board, the taxpayer claimed, inter alia, that the Commissioner erred in rejecting evidence offered by the taxpayer, used methods that were unlawful and contrary to that required for good accounting and tax reporting, admitted evidence that had been objected to by the taxpayer, failed to properly weigh the evidence, and used unrepresentative evidence. The Commissioner filed a motion to dismiss the taxpayer's appeal to the Board on the ground that the taxpayer failed to comply with the mandatory requirements of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5717.02 by not specifying the error or errors complained of. The Board held that the Commissioner's order was specific and exactly detailed his computations of the taxpayer's tax liability. On appeal of the Board's decision, the taxpayer argued that its property had been taken without due process, that the Commissioner's motion to dismiss should not have been granted, and that § 5717.02 was unconstitutional. The court held that § 5717.02 did not take the taxpayer's property without due process of law, was not vague or arbitrary, and did not violate the taxpayer's equal protection rights.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision.

 

384 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Staten v. Tax Comm'r, Gerald S. Collins


No. 75AP-114


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8373; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 365



June 30, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] The decision of the Board of Tax Appeals is reasonable and lawful and is affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a decision of appellee Ohio Board of Tax Appeals, which affirmed a sales tax assessment issued against the taxpayer.


OVERVIEW: A sales tax assessment was issued against the taxpayer. The taxpayer filed a petition for reassessment with the tax commissioner. The commissioner conducted a hearing thereon and affirmed the assessment. The taxpayer then appealed the commissioner's decision to the Board, which affirmed the commissioner's assessment in full. On appeal, the taxpayer argued that the Board erred in finding that the taxpayer was a vendor and in finding that the test checks on which the assessment was based were for a representative period. The court affirmed the Board's decision, holding that the Board's finding that the taxpayer was a vendor was neither unlawful nor unreasonable. In addition to acquiring a vendor's license and a liquor permit for the subject location, the taxpayer also signed several sales tax returns as the vendor. The taxpayer failed to produce credible evidence that he was not the vendor. Finally, there was ample evidence to support the Board's finding that the test check employed by the commissioner in determining the assessment was representative.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision.

 

385 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Marathon Oil Co. v. Bd. of Zoning Adjustment


No. 75AP-77


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


44 Ohio App. 2d 402; 339 N.E.2d 856; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5780; 73 Ohio Op. 2d 525



June 30, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant oil company challenged a decision from the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which affirmed appellee zoning board's decision to raze an abandoned service station.


OVERVIEW: The zoning board determined that the oil company was the owner of an abandoned service station. Based on the finding, they sought to demolish the building, pursuant to Columbus, Ohio, City Codes § 3379.14(a). After the zoning board's decision was upheld on appeal, the oil company sought review. Specifically, the oil company contended that § 3379.14(a) was unconstitutional. In reversing, the court found that the statute violated the oil company's due process rights. Under § 3379.14(a), abandoned service stations constituted a nuisance per se. Once the zoning board determined that the service station in question was abandoned, there was no further determination as to whether or not the building was in fact a public nuisance. The owner of property, other than a service station, was entitled to have a hearing on the question of the existence of a public nuisance. It was unreasonable to require the razing of the building itself without a factual determination regarding its status as a public nuisance. Therefore, the court determined that § 3379.14(a) was unreasonable, arbitrary, and unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision in favor of the zoning board.

 

386 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Haddox v. Houser


No. 75AP-265


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


44 Ohio App. 2d 389; 339 N.E.2d 666; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5779; 73 Ohio Op. 2d 464



June 26, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN HABEAS CORPUS: Court of Appeals for Franklin County.



DISPOSITION: Writ granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner sought a writ of habeas corpus on the ground that he should have been released because his time served prior to trial was greater than the sentence for the crime. He had been found guilty of sexual imposition.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner was charged with rape. He spent 186 days in jail awaiting trial. He then withdrew his former plea of not guilty and entered a plea of no contest to the lesser included offense of sexual imposition. He was sentenced to the maximum jail term of 60 days. He filed a timely request to get credit for time served. The trial court denied the request. Petitioner then sought a writ of habeas corpus. The court granted the writ, holding that if petitioner had been originally charged with a misdemeanor, he would have been released under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.73(C)(1) based on time served. Had he been found guilty of the felony for which he was charged, he would have been credited with time served under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2967.191. Further, had he been able to post bond, he would not have been incarcerated for the 186 days. The court held that there was no logical reason for distinguishing between misdemeanor and felony convictions in crediting time, or for distinguishing between misdemeanors upon the basis as to whether a felony or misdemeanor was the original charge.


OUTCOME: The court granted the writ.

 

387 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Ellington


No. 33735


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7010



June 26, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM COMMON PLEAS COURT, No. 10453 Cr.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which convicted defendant for rape and aggravated assault. He contended that he was denied his right to a speedy trial, that he was denied a fair trial by being forced to appear in prison clothing, and that the trial court placed an unreasonable limitation upon his counsel's closing argument.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was tried with a codefendant. He was held in jail in lieu of bail and appeared at voir dire and opening statement in prison clothing. He appeared in civilian clothing during the trial. The trial court limited defense closing arguments to 20 minutes. When the codefendant had finished, nine minutes were left for defendant. The court held that there was no abuse of discretion because defendant's counsel was able to cover the issues in that time and did not request additional time. The court held that defendant's appearance in prison garb was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. During the time defendant was incarcerated waiting for trial, the speedy trial statute was amended. The old statute required that he be tried within two terms after his arrest. The amendment required that he be tried within 90 days. The court held that he had to be tried within the shorter time limit after the effective date of the amendment. His trial complied with the requirement.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

388 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Rogers


No. C-74384


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


44 Ohio App. 2d 289; 337 N.E.2d 791; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5768; 73 Ohio Op. 2d 329



June 23, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Hamilton County Municipal Court (Ohio), convicting her of endangering her child in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2919.22(B).


OVERVIEW: Defendant's child's principal noticed bruises on her body and informed protective services. A police specialist followed up and found similar bruises. Defendant was charged after the investigation. Defendant was convicted, her sentence was suspended, and she was placed on probation. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that § 2919.22(B) was not unconstitutionally vague and overbroad since a person of ordinary sensibilities and intelligence should have been capable of ascertaining its meaning and abiding by its proscriptions. The word "corporal" in the statute embraced the entire body, and not merely the trunk. Also, the judgment was not contrary to the manifest weight of the evidence because abundant probative and credible evidence supported the conclusion. Photographs of the child's injuries were properly admitted because they were relevant and probative. Because the photographs tended to diminish the severity of the injuries, the photographs inured to the benefit of defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the conviction.

 

389 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Miami Valley Assocs., Inc. v. Jackson Township Bd. of Zoning Appeals


No. 554


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Clermont County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7436



June 23, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant township sought review of an order from the Court of Common Pleas of Clermont County, Ohio, which granted judgment in favor of appellee corporation that had claimed that the township's resolution revoking its permit to construct a mobile home park was unconstitutional, illegal, arbitrary, capricious, unreasonable, and unsupported by the evidence. The appeal was the second appeal concerning the zoning issue.


OVERVIEW: The zoning board initially approved the corporation's application for the construction of a mobile home park. The township filed an action against the corporation claiming a violation of its zoning regulations. Following appeal, the zoning board rescinded the permit. The corporation then filed an appeal in trial court, which found that the recision of the permit was unlawful and ordered the zoning board to re-issue the permit. The township again appealed. The sole issue on appeal related to the action taken by the zoning board in rescinding the permit, which it had originally issued. The validity of the original permit had been fully adjudicated and decided by the court. The court held that the original permit was unlawfully issued, contrary to the zoning resolutions, and the corporation was enjoined from using its land based on the permit granted. Because the original permit was held to be invalid, the action of the zoning board rescinding the permit was immaterial because the permit was invalid and nonusable in any event. Hence, any issues relating to the manner in which the permit was revoked were rendered moot by the court's previous decision.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

390 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hardy


No. C-74563


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7444



June 23, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Hamilton County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which found him guilty and convicted defendant for violating the intimidation statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2921.03. He was sentenced to imprisonment of three to 10 years.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was accused of having sent a threatening letter to a city police chief, referring to different groups that would be targeted by the "Symbionese Liberation Army." He was convicted in part based on an employment application. The employees to whom he submitted the application testified before the grand jury as to defendant's identity. Because defendant argued no challenge to the validity of the grand jury's indictment, the court found that his arrest and prosecution were based on probable cause and that the application was admissible. The court rejected defendant's challenge to the constitutionality of the intimidation statute and held that defendant did not have to also be accused of bribing a public official to be guilty of intimidation, although the two crimes could be related. The court held that the speech contained in the letter was not protected by the First Amendment because the threats in the letter created a clear and present danger to the safety of the police chief to whom the letter was addressed. However, the court suggested that defendant's sentence may have been too strong, and remanded the case with that comment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment which convicted defendant and remanded his case to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

391 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Nenoff v. Thompson


C.A. No. 7840


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth Appellate District, Lucas County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6974



June 20, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM Common Pleas COURT, NOS. 203720 & 206839


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Common Pleas Court of Lucas County (Ohio) entered judgment in favor of appellee driver. Appellant administratrix challenged the trial court's judgment.


OVERVIEW: After the trial court entered judgment in favor of the driver, the administratrix argued that she was prejudiced because the surviving spouse and the decedent's children could not be present during the selection of the jury, but were excluded from the courtroom on motion for separation of witnesses. On appeal, the court found that there was no objection to the exclusion of the surviving spouse and the children. In addition, the court found that the administratrix failed to illustrate how she was prejudiced. The court also found that the administratrix was fully apprised of the driver's testimony. The court determined that by filing the lawsuit, the administratrix placed in issue the earnings of the decedent prior to his death. The court also determined that the administratrix waived any objection at trial relative to the selection of the jury. The court found that the cross-examination of the driver was in depth on all matters which were relevant and competent. The court also found that the trial court was correct in limiting the administratrix in rebuttal to rebutting the evidence produced by the driver and in not permitting her to re-open her original case.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

392 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cumming v. City of Kettering


No. CA-4640


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second Appellate District, Montgomery County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5957



June 19, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, city and state attorney general, appealed from the decision of the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County (Ohio), which found for plaintiff owner in his action against them, in which he alleged that the city's zoning ordinance was unconstitutional as it applied to his property.


OVERVIEW: The owner held title to three platted lots located in the city. The city's zoning ordinance imposed residential zoning on the property, restraining the owner from putting any commercial business on his property other than a gas station. The owner filed suit against the city and the state attorney general, alleging that the zoning ordinance was unconstitutional as it applied to his land. The trial court found for the owner, holding that the zoning ordinance exceeded the police powers of that city and was unconstitutional. The city and the state attorney general appealed and the court reversed. The court held that the trial court's conclusion of discrimination was contrary to law and against the weight of the evidence, and that the owner had purchased the property with actual or constructive knowledge of the zoning restrictions. The court found that the opinions of the expert witness were improperly received because the so-called expert was in no better position to give an opinion as to the matters therein than a layman.
