The court held that the owner produced too few facts to bolster his argument and that the presumption of the validity of the zoning ordinance was not overcome.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the lower court, granting final judgment for the city and the state attorney general.

 

393 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Butler County Citizens Comm. to Preserve Our Scenic and Historic Areas v. Dayton Power and Light Co.


No. CA 74-06-0055


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Butler County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7644



June 16, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM COURT OF COMMON PLEAS BUTLER COUNTY, OHIO


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a 245-member citizen committee, appealed a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas of Butler County (Ohio), which dismissed their amended complaint seeking injunctive and other relief in opposition to the proposed construction of an overhead high voltage circuit lines by defendants, two utility companies and their presidents and Public Utilities Commission of Ohio.


OVERVIEW: The utilities proposed to jointly construct a 33-mile overhead double circuit transmission line initially energized at 345,000. The citizens, through a committee to preserve scenic and historic areas, claimed that the proposed transmission line would unreasonably and adversely affect public health and welfare by creating an electromagnetic field and a corona discharge which would endanger and adversely affect the citizens, their community, and their livestock. The citizens sought injunctive relief and an order requiring the Commission to perform its duty to protect the public. On appeal, the court affirmed in part the dismissal of the complaint as to the Commission in the absence of any authority for the Commission to guide or direct the utilities in such a project. The court reversed in part the dismissal of the complaint against the utilities and their presidents by finding that, given the serious allegations of the amended complaint as to whether the proposed power lines adversely affected the public's welfare under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.65(B)(3), the citizens were entitled to a day in court and an opportunity to marshal their evidence in support of their contentions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part the dismissal of the citizens' amended complaint against the Commission, and reversed in part the dismissal of the amended complaint against the utilities and their presidents, and remanded the action to the common pleas court for the framing of the issues and the trial of the case.

 

394 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Simpson


No. 33506


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 6742



June 12, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM COMMON PLEAS COURT, No. 6859 & 6860 Cr.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the decision of the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which, after a jury trial, found him guilty of selling an automobile with altered identification numbers, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4505.19(D), and concealing a stolen motor vehicle, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4549.04(E).


OVERVIEW: A confidential informant told police that defendant, among others, was operating an auto theft ring. Defendant was indicted with violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4505.19(D), selling an auto with altered identification numbers, and with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4549.04(E), concealing a stolen motor vehicle. Defendant's subsequent motion to suppress was denied. Defendant was found guilty on all counts. Defendant appealed and the court affirmed. The court held that the fact that title to one of the vehicles was in defendant's wife was immaterial in the light of the fact that he himself had sold the car. The court found that it was not necessary that defendant knew the owner of the car, only that he had knowledge that it was stolen. The court found that the doctrine of ex post facto did not apply because the diminished knowledge requirement of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4549.04 was not effective until after the date that defendant committed the offenses. The court held that it was not alleged that the informant was a participant in the acts to the extent necessary to prove defendant's guilt, but that the arrangement by which the car was obtained was relevant to the charges against defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions for selling an automobile with altered identification numbers, and concealing a stolen motor vehicle.

 

395 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Harris


No. 74AP-580


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 8265



June 10, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, Franklin County (Ohio) in which he was convicted of aggravated murder, punishable by death pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(A)(7). The defense based its case primarily on the claim that defendant was under the influence of drugs and alcohol, that he was paranoid, and that he was not guilty by reason of insanity. Defendant contended on appeal that his confession was coerced.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the court found no evidence to support defendant's argument. Defendant did not contradict the evidence that he had been fully advised of his rights. He voluntarily chose to waive his rights, and he voluntarily made a statement without the presence of his attorney. In fact, he chose not to follow his attorney's advice to remain silent. Furthermore, the police were careful to protect defendant's constitutional rights. Accordingly, the trial court did not err in overruling the motion to suppress. Defendant contended that the new law providing for the death penalty, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2929.02 to 2929.04, was unconstitutional. Bound by United States Supreme Court decisions, the court upheld the constitutionality of the mandatory death penalty. Under the new law, the death penalty was to be imposed unless the trial court found evidence of one of the three mitigating circumstances set forth in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(B)(1), (2), or (3). This was not the case here, however. For example, the court found no evidence of any psychosis or mental deficiency, even though insufficient to constitute an insanity defense, of defendant at the time of the commission of the crime.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

396 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Risner v. State


No. CA 74-08-0071


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Twelfth Appellate District, Butler County


45 Ohio App. 2d 5; 340 N.E.2d 433; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5784; 74 Ohio Op. 2d 9



June 9, 1975, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant State challenged an order from the Court of Common Pleas of Butler County (Ohio) that set aside plaintiff operator's driver's license suspension, which had been ordered by the Registrar of Motor Vehicles after the operator was convicted of failing to stop and disclose his identity at the scene of an accident in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4507.16(E).


OVERVIEW: The operator was tried and convicted of a traffic violation, after which the registrar suspended his driver's license. The operator appealed the suspension to the trial court, which set aside the suspension after concluding that the suspension without a pre-suspension hearing was unconstitutional. On appeal, the court reversed, holding that the registrar was required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.31 to suspend the operator's license because of his conviction under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4507.16(E). The operator had already received a hearing in his trial of the criminal charge, from which he had available an opportunity to appeal, and once he was convicted, the registrar had nothing further to consider in order to suspend the operator's license. Due process did not require any further hearing.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's order and affirmed the suspension.

 

397 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hartbarger


Case No. CA 74-01-0001


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Butler County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7630



June 9, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was arrested in Middletown, Ohio and charged with a burglary that had been committed in 1969. He was released on bond and did not appear for trial. On November 27, 1971, he was arrested in Brentwood, Ohio and charged with burglary. The Butler County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) convicted him of the 1969 burglary, after a trial by jury, and sentenced him to serve a life term. Defendant filed an appeal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant appealed his conviction for the 1969 burglary. The court affirmed. There was sufficient evidence as to each of the elements of the crime of burglary to warrant a conviction. The evidence of the breaking and entering in the night season by two men, dressed as they were with a flashlight and gun, was a prima facie case of burglary. The additional evidence of the subsequent burglary added valuable evidence as to defendant's intent when he broke into the first house. The trial court properly admitted into evidence the commission of the second burglary, a similar act, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.59. The evidence as to the second burglary was relevant because it helped establish the element of intent and defendant's method of operation. The evidence showed that defendant gained had entrance to both homes in the same manner and that he possessed a screwdriver in both instances. Defendant had not objected to the statute on constitutional grounds in the trial court and thus had waived any objection. In any event, the Ohio Supreme Court had found that the statute was not unconstitutional on due process grounds.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

398 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati Board of Realtors, Inc. v. Cincinnati


No. C-74354


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Hamilton County


47 Ohio App. 2d 267; 353 N.E.2d 898; 1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 5879; 1 Ohio Op. 3d 341



June 9, 1975, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: This judgment was affirmed by the Supreme Court of Ohio, in 46 Ohio St. 2d 138.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff sought a judgment declaring that the certificate of housing inspection ordinance of defendant city was unconstitutional and an injunction against its enforcement. The Hamilton County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) entered summary judgment for plaintiff, and the city appealed.


OVERVIEW: A city ordinance required a homeowner to obtain a certificate of inspection from the director of buildings and inspections before entering into a contract of sale. Except when an inspection certificate was delivered to the buyer, the ordinance required a seller to warrant that the property complied with the building code. Paragraph (D) contained a presumption concerning a buyer's knowledge of deficiencies in the property and included two exceptions, and paragraph (F) stated that a failure to comply was a misdemeanor. The trial court ruled that the ordinance was unconstitutional and enjoined its enforcement. On appeal, the court held that the imposition of a criminal penalty on an owner who refused to consent to an inspection was unconstitutional under the Fourth Amendment, and that the ordinance's period of limitations was invalid because it conflicted with state law. The exceptions in paragraph (D) were severed from the ordinance as arbitrary and invalid. The court modified the judgment by removing the injunction against enforcement of the ordinance with respect to those provisions found valid and continued the injunction against the invalid provisions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment in part and reversed it in part. The judgment was modified to declare that the ordinance's criminal penalty was unconstitutional, that a certain presumption was arbitrary, and that the period of limitations was invalid due to a conflict with state law.

 

399 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Board of Trustees v. Miami Valley Assocs., Inc.


No. 540


Court of Appeals of Ohio, First Appellate District, Clermont County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7595



June 2, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of trustees filed a lawsuit against appellee corporation in the Common Pleas Court of Clermont County (Ohio) demanding an injunction and declaratory relief to prevent violations of the Jackson Township zoning resolutions regarding the regulation of trailer lots. The trial court denied the injunction and issued a declaratory judgment that the lot size provision in the township ordinance was invalid. The board of trustees appealed.


OVERVIEW: The corporation sought a permit to construct a mobile home park. The board of trustees argued that the proposed construction violated the township's zoning ordinances regarding lot sizes. The trial court found that the lot size set forth in the zoning resolution of the township was unconstitutional. The trial court ruled that the State had preempted the regulation of trailer lots, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3733.02(A), and Public Health Council, Department of Health, State of Ohio, Regulation HE-27-08, which provided that mobile home lots shall have a land area of not less than 3,600 square feet. The court disagreed, reversed the trial court's judgment, and granted the board of trustees an injunction. The court stated that the township had broad authority under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 519.02, to develop a comprehensive plan of zoning. And, the State had not preempted the field concerning the original location of trailer parks so as to preclude township trustees, who had properly enacted zoning regulations, from requiring larger lot sizes than the minimums required by public health regulations. Thus, the township's zoning ordinance regarding lot size was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court in favor of the corporation was reversed, and the corporation was enjoined from using its land in violation of the township's zoning ordinances.

 

400 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Eaton v. Serval Auto Sales & Serv., Inc.


Case No. 624


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Geauga County


1975 Ohio App. LEXIS 7657



June 2, 1975 


NOTICE:

PURSUANT TO RULE 2(G) OF THE OHIO SUPREME COURT RULES FOR THE REPORTING OF OPINIONS, UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS MAY BE CITED SUBJECT TO CERTAIN RESTRAINTS, LIMITATIONS, AND EXCEPTIONS.



DISPOSITION:  [*1] Judgment Affirmed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant owner sought review after the Court of Common Pleas of Geauga County (Ohio) entered a judgment permanently restraining the owner from conducting a junk yard and/or automobile wrecking yard on its premises. Appellee township had initiated the action. The owner filed an appeal.


OVERVIEW: The owner had secured a zoning permit in 1972. Thereafter, the township revised the zoning resolutions and added certain amendments. The amendments defined "junkyard" and "automotive graveyard," which were accordingly prohibited. The trial court granted the township's petition for a permanent injunction. The court affirmed. The section of the zoning ordinance on which the owner had relied did not apply. The applicable section was Township of Newbury, Ohio, Zoning Res. § 403.6, which governed permitted uses in a business district. The permitted uses in a business district did not include a junkyard or automobile graveyard. The owner had not raised the constitutionality of the resolution in its answer to the complaint. The defense of unconstitutionality of a statute was an affirmative defense, which had to be pled pursuant to Ohio R. Civ. P. 8(C). Defendant had waived the defense. The fact that the prior owner had operated in about the same manner as the owner was unavailing. A use permitted to a former operator, improperly conducted, did not benefit the owner. Zoning was first passed in Newbury Township in 1948; to be a non-conforming use, the use had to date back to 1948.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.
